PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing in the Pacific
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned expresses the widespread community outrage throughout Australia at the decision of the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French Parliament in the strongest terms Australia's opposition to this decision.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Colston (from 3,570 citizens) and Senator Chris Evans (from 515 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Chemicals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to phase out aerial spraying in accordance with recommendation 89 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing in the Pacific
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Australian Senate Assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of certain residents of Perth in the State of Western Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the grave environmental and health consequences arising from the recent decision by the Government of France to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate note that those petitioners whose signatures appear below:
(a) are appalled at the political arrogance of the recent decision by the Government of France to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific;
(b) commit themselves to a voluntary boycott of the consumption of all goods made in France until such time as the French Government reverses its decision;
(c) call on the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to initiate the diplomatic action necessary to bring about a reversal of the French decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are;

disturbed by the fact that every month between 600 and 1200 people (most of them civilians) are killed or maimed by landmines, and their health and maintenance costs are being incurred in countries with insufficient resources to meet the most basic needs of all their people,

concerned that the cost of clearing and de-activating of landmines is one hundred times the financial cost of manufacture, and the human cost is being borne by people who have suffered displacement, war, tribulation and hunger,

and we are greatly concerned that there remains between 85 and 100 million unexploded mines scattered over 62 different countries, inhibiting the ordinary movement of civilians and the farming of fields as people return to their former homes as wars cease.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:
ensure that the overseas aid budget contains a substantial allocation for de-mining training programs,
ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora persuade more countries to become party to, and gratify, the Inhumane Weapons Convention

ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora promote and support an amendment to Article 6 of Protocol II to prohibit the use, development, production, stockpiling and transfer of landmines.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing in the Pacific
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We register our strongest protest at the decision by the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
The decision to resume testing is without regard to strident opposition from not only the people and nations of the South Pacific, but also many other countries around the world.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TAB.TAB: (i)winter cereal crops in the north-west of New South Wales are doomed to fail, or be substantially reduced, if the area does not receive rain in the next 3 to 4 weeks,

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(b)highlights to drought-ravaged farmers that the ALP's drought policy of assuming that producers can become drought-proof and self-reliant between long-term cyclical down-turns is labelled totally misguided by this report;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—During the winter recess, in my capacity as Chair of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I attended the Fifth Australasian and Pacific Conference on Delegated Legislation. This conference is held biennially and its venue is shared amongst the participating jurisdictions. This year it was held in Darwin on 5 to 7 July. I was accompanied by Senator Jacinta Collins, Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan AM, the committee's legal adviser, and members of the committee's secretariat. Senator Minchin was to attend, but was prevented from doing so by the sudden onset of appendicitis.

PARA.TAB: At the outset, I express my appreciation to the hosts of the conference. In particular, I thank Mr Rick Setter MLA, chair of the Northern Territory parliament's Subordinate Legislation and Tabled Papers Committee, and the secretary of that committee, Mrs Helen Allmich, who is also Serjeant-at-Arms of the Northern Territory parliament. Their hospitality set the atmosphere for a successful conference. I am certain that I also speak on behalf of Senator Jacinta Collins and committee staff when I congratulate Mr Rick Setter and Mrs Allmich on their hard work in organising the event. It was apparent from the comments of other participants at the conference that these two convenors' generosity of spirit had been extended to each and every person who attended.

The conference was officially opened by His Honour the Administrator of the Northern Territory, the Hon. Austin Asche AC, QC, who spoke on the importance of properly drafted delegated legislation and the role of delegated legislation. His Honour stated that `delegated legislation is the what, why, when, how, where and who of legislation'.

The aim of the conference is to bring together the committees, organisations and individuals involved in the scrutiny of legislation throughout jurisdictions in Australasia. This year, the conference was attended by about 70 delegates from the Commonwealth, states and territories. Delegates from New Zealand also attended. It was unfortunate that representatives from the Hong Kong parliament had to cancel at the last moment. I look forward to their attendance at the next conference. Understandably, delegates from the Queensland committee had to withdraw due to the state election campaign, but they were ably represented by the committee staff members.

The conference serves as an ideal forum for committee members and staff to exchange information and expertise. Papers are formally presented on matters of interest or on scrutiny issues requiring special attention. The papers presented at this year's conference were of high quality and, with the concurrence of the Senate, I propose to seek leave to table the bound volume containing those papers when they become available. I will mention the papers' contents briefly.

The Hon. Bruce Donaldson MLC, Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Delegated Legislation in Western Australia, presented a paper entitled `Subordinate legislation in Western Australia: investigation and proposals for reform'. The general theme of the paper was to summarise the observations of the committee in relation to the scrutiny procedures in certain foreign jurisdictions. The committee had visited Washington, London and Paris in a bid to acquire `a better understanding of the nature of subordinate legislation and systems of scrutiny'.

Mr Richard Northey, the Chairman of the New Zealand Regulations Review Committee, presented an informative discourse on the apparent increase in use of Henry VIII provisions in New Zealand subordinate legislation. He suggested the increase is attributable to the complex reforms of the past decade. He concluded with a statement of commitment to vigilance in scrutinising Henry VIII clauses in relation to transitional provisions and to require officials to appear before the committee to justify the need for such provisions in legislation.

The Hon. Robert Lawson QC, MLC, Chairman of the Legislative Review Committee in South Australia, spoke about a code of conduct for members of parliament. He prefaced his paper with humorous comments about the perceived level of trustworthiness of politicians. The results of a survey he referred to claimed that politicians ranked second last in the public's perception as to the trustworthiness of various professions. Politicians, he told the conference, came in just ahead of ministers. In a light vein, he queried, if the survey's findings were valid, why so many members of parliament aspired to become ministers. Mr Lawson proceeded to deliver an overview of recent proposals in relation to codes of conduct for members of parliament and to examine some of the arguments for and against the introduction of such codes.

Other papers relevant to the scrutiny of delegated legislation were presented by or on behalf of the Victorian, Queensland and New South Wales committees. Mr Murray Thompson MP from the Scrutiny of Acts and Regulations Committee in Victoria presented a paper, the philosophical considerations of which were reflected in the title, `Introducing the new act: the more things change, the more they stay the same'.

Ms Jill Hall MLA, the Chair of the Regulations Review Committee in New South Wales, had prepared a paper entitled `New regulatory reform horizons for New South Wales—but some problems still remain'. It was extremely unfortunate that Ms Hall suffered from severe laryngitis for the whole of the conference—a most disturbing affliction for a member of parliament. Her paper was presented by Mr Bob Harrison, also an MLA from New South Wales.

In the absence of the ebullient Mr Jon Sullivan, the Chair of the Joint Standing Committee on Delegated Legislation in Queensland, Ms Louisa Pink, that committee's research director, outlined developments in relation to the legislation making and scrutiny process in the post-Fitzgerald era. Brian Davison, an MHA from Tasmania and a member of the Tasmanian parliament's Standing Committee on Subordinate Legislation, presented a report summarising that state's regulatory review program.

On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I presented a paper on legislation by incorporation. This involved an examination of section 49A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. The paper focused on the history of the section, its relevance to scrutiny and its role in safeguarding democratic rights and freedoms.

Other papers presented were of more relevance to the scrutiny of primary legislation. Mr Victor Perton MP, Chairman of the Scrutiny of Acts and Regulations Committee in Victoria, argued the case against `no compensation' clauses. Mr Perton made other considerable contributions to the conference, including formal replies to two of the papers presented by other members of the conference.

Two papers were presented by senators who are members of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Senator Troeth, the chair of that committee, whose paper was provocatively entitled `Don't come the raw prawn', expounded the efforts of the committee to uncover `attempts by executive governments to encroach on the legislative function of parliaments'. Senator Ellison presented a well-prepared and thought provoking examination of the abrogation of privilege against self-incrimination.

Other matters were formally raised at the conference. Mr David Kinley, a senior lecturer in law at the Australian National University, addressed the conference in relation to a perceived need for increased vigilance towards the scrutiny of legislation for matters affecting human rights. Mr Rick Setter MLA discussed the passage of the legislation which made history recently in the Northern Territory—namely, the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995. This paper was confined to a discussion of the parliamentary procedures which guided the passage of the bill and did not in any way attempt to debate the subject matter of the bill.

Professor Dennis Pearce and Mr Stephen Argument informed the conference of their intention to produce a second edition of Professor Pearce's book, the well-known and respected text, Delegated legislation in Australia and New Zealand. Ms Jean Baker of the Office of Legislative Drafting of the Attorney-General's Department addressed the conference in relation to the provisions of the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994, which, hopefully, will one day be before the Senate for debate.

The conference also marked the official launching of a discussion paper entitled `The scrutiny of national scheme legislation and the desirability of uniform scrutiny principles'. This paper was prepared by a working party comprised of the chairs of all scrutiny committees in Australia. The paper promotes informed discussion and invites comments from interested persons and organisations.

At its conclusion, the conference resolved to congratulate Professor Pearce and Mr Stephen Argument for their proposed revision of the text on delegated legislation. It also formally resolved to note matters which had been discussed, and recorded that the discussion had been beneficial and of great value to the participants at the conference. The next conference is scheduled to be held two years hence in Adelaide.

I cannot conclude this report without giving special mention to the guest speaker at the formal dinner, Her Honour Justice Sally Thomas of the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory. Justice Thomas recounted some of her experiences in hearing evidence given by Aboriginals and explained some of the difficulties confronting Aboriginals in participating in the judicial system in terms of cultural differences. She concluded her inspiring speech with an entertaining poem she had composed about legislation and the place of scrutiny in the democratic process. The poem reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I speak tonight of legislation, subordinate and delegated.
The parliament may legislate, prorogate and delegate,
The executive administrates, officiates and agitates,
The judiciary contemplates and then . . . invalidates.
Through these three arms of government, we live our daily lives,
For the betterment of all mankind our laws will seek to strive,
Spare a thought for those who serve on committees far and wide,
Who examine every bill and act to ensure our rights are not denied.
Delegated legislation and parliamentary bills,
Are scrutinised most carefully to avoid autocratic ills.
In an age of legislative proliferation and complex regulations,
We need to recognise the role of such committees cogitations.
So I salute you one and all for your care and dedication,
To my ultimate independence as a citizen of this nation.
Justice Thomas's poem was most appropriate for the occasion and a fitting end to my report on the conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I last spoke on this matter in the Senate, I raised the concern that had been expressed in relation to the definition of a small company as opposed to the definition of a large company. The government, which has been critical of the coalition in relation to the delay in this bill, has really found that there was cause for delay, because during the non-sitting period concern was expressed by people such as the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Motor Trades Association on this very aspect of the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill.

PARA.TAB: People are not saying that the bill itself is flawed or bad. They are just saying that there is one aspect which needs to be looked at, namely, the ramifications which will flow from that arbitrary definition. So that in hindsight the delay was indeed worth while and, if it serves the purpose of having a definition which is more properly defined, then small business will only benefit from this.

I say to the business community that they need to look at this aspect of the bill and that the feedback we get from the community is essential—as legislators we have to rely on what the community tells us. If the business community says that this will have practical problems, then we have to be alive to those problems. I believe that the reference of this aspect to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee is worth while and will serve the interests of the wider community in that respect.

I did mention that there are positive aspects of the bill. On behalf of the coalition, I welcome the use of plain English in the drafting of this bill and I also welcome the somewhat different layout of the bill. These innovative aspects make it easier for the average person to pick up such a piece of legislation and understand it. Although this is a rather complex area of the law, one would expect that, even if one drafted it in the simplest terms, one might still have problems with the ins and outs of it. Nonetheless, the use of plain English is to be welcomed.

Other aspects of the bill are also welcomed. The permitted share buyback amendments allow a company to purchase its own shares and modify the rules on buybacks. In the past it has been considered that a purchase by a company of its own shares was undesirable. In this bill it is now considered that permitted buybacks allow a company which is in a good financial state to take advantage of market conditions and repurchase its shares.
I believe it will be necessary to keep an eye on this aspect of the bill. However, it is an amendment which is quite welcome and I support it.

Another amendment relates to the formation of a proprietary company and allows for a company to be formed by one person. The current provisions allow at least two people to act as directors. We can have a situation where a person involved in a business ropes in his or her spouse or partner to be a silent director. That is quite artificial. This amendment is a good one; it is commonsense and it will make things easier.

I also applaud the small business guide which will be incorporated in the bill and which is well overdue. It summarises the main provisions of the law. A lot of people in the small business sector have a good many laws, acts of parliament and regulations to deal with and anything which can make their understanding more simple can only be welcome. I believe the Joint Standing Committee on Corporations and Securities has recommended the inclusion of this guide and, furthermore, that there be some review of it after it has been in operation for a reasonable time.

Generally, I think the bill simplifies the various regulatory and reporting provisions which touch on small companies. The coalition supports this bill, save for the aspect of the definition of small and large companies.

This bill was due for debate in the last session of parliament, and in fact it came on during the last day of the parliament. There has been some criticism that the bill was not dealt with at that time. However, as I recall it, there was a censure motion of Senator Bolkus, the Minister representing the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), on foot relating to the tabling of documents by Senator Bolkus and that censure motion occupied the debate on that day. That was the reason for the delay in the first instance. Nonetheless, in hindsight, the delay has benefited small business and will only improve the bill when the legal and constitutional affairs committee has a look at the definition.

I say to the small business community that another couple of weeks will be of benefit to them because, after all, it is our duty as legislators to get the legislation right, not to just rush bills through for the sake of having them rushed through. Our task is primarily to get the legislation right and ensure that the flow-on effects do not have unintended consequences. I believe that the definition of a large company could well catch many businesses and thereby cause them to have to comply with these onerous reporting conditions. As the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry pointed out, that could well involve an extra $25,000 per year in auditing costs.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The First Corporate Law Simplification Bill was presented to the parliament on behalf of small business and, as the name suggests, it was to simplify the company procedures that would allow small business to understand in simplistic terms the criteria of the legislation which they have to meet. There are many aspects of the bill with which the National and Liberal parties agree and entirely support. But there is one aspect of the bill that has sounded alarm bells right through the small business community.

PARA.TAB: It is absolutely fortuitous that there was a censure motion on the last day of sitting that prevented this bill coming before the parliament and being voted on. The bill as it stands would have terrible implications for many of Australia's small business people. I can understand where the government is coming from, but they are wrong. You cannot prevent people doing business with each other.

This bill is trying to remove the possibility of creditors losing money when a company goes bankrupt. If you put those restrictions on business what happens is that businesses will never be able to trade. The bill would require, and this is the part of the bill that the National and Liberal parties are concerned about, a great many small businesses—and I do not know how many, but I suspect about 100,000 small businesses—to use auditing processes which would cost them between $25,000 and $30,000.

For many small businesses out there at the moment who have survived the holocaust of the Keating high interest rates and the depression and for those who are just hanging on, any extra costs could be the straw that breaks the camel's back. The National and Liberal parties are totally opposed to this issue and will not, if possible, add to the cost of small business in Australia.

What the government has said, in trying to strike a definition, is that if the consolidated gross operating revenue for the financial year of a company and its entities exceeds $10 million then it is deemed to be a big company. If the consolidated gross assets at the end of the financial year of the company and its entities exceed $5 million then it is deemed to be a big company. If the company and its entities at the end of the financial year employ more than 50 people then it is deemed to be a big company. If a company satisfies two of the three criteria then it is required to have an audit done by a professional auditing firm which could cost between $9,000 and $20,000. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Motor Trades Association of Australia and the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry believe that this could cost anywhere between $25,000 and $40,000.

There are 800,000 to 900,000 small businesses in Australia. Some 45 per cent of those are corporatised companies or proprietary limited companies. If 45 per cent of the 800,000 to 900,000 companies are corporatised many of them would fall into the big category. I have had representations from a representative of one firm in Townsville. He took this legislation to his accountant. At present this firm is paying $9,000 a year in auditing fees. He was told by his accountant that it would cost $32,000 to comply with this legislation. They were the accountant's official figures. That person runs a very successful business and, I suppose, he can afford that. It would hurt and damage him, but I think he could get through.

There are many other companies that just could not afford that extra $30,000 to keep them in the game. I have a statement here from someone who owns an engineering firm in Western Australia. He says that he has taken this piece of legislation to his accountants who have informed him that the cost would be an additional $50,000. So as far as this bill being helpful to Australia's small business is concerned, it is really putting a lot of weight in their saddle.

I am very grateful to Senator Vanstone for giving this particular piece of legislation the opportunity to go to a Senate inquiry. It is now up to all the people who are going to be affected by this legislation to make submissions. As my colleague Senator Ellison said a few minutes ago, we are the people who are elected to examine legislation but we must get feedback from the constituents who are worried about it.

Unfortunately, the feedback on this bill came in very late in the piece—about last week sometime. We had to scramble to try to unwind the mess that the government had put through. I do not know where Senator Schacht stands on this legislation but his department was absolutely lacking when it scrutinised the legislation on how it affects small business. Senator Schacht comes in here and tells us that he is the minister for small business and that he is their voice, but for him to allow this piece of legislation to go through cabinet shows that he has not been looking for anything in this legislation that would disadvantage small business.

As I said before, the legislation was put out to help small business. In many ways it does. The small business community, along with COSBOA's Rob Bastian and many other people, has been seeking this simplification process with the government. Unfortunately, this legislation nearly got through. It escaped getting through only due to the vigilance of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Motor Trades Association of Queensland and one or two other organisations. It was a very close call for small business, and is one now that I think we can get to a Senate inquiry.

If the government can see the error of their ways—which I believe they will when it is presented to them by accountants who will be asked to make submissions—and they are told of the consequences this legislation will impose on small business, I am very hopeful that they will amend the bill. If they do not, I feel quite confident that the National and Liberal parties will move an amendment. I am sure the Democrats and the Greens would support it. I can see no reason why any person who thinks or is remotely concerned about small business would inflict that additional cost of $25,000 on small business.

Most of the thrust of opposition has come from the Motor Trades Association, and that will affect many of the car dealers in Australia. If you think about it, a $10 million turnover is not a very high turnover in today's terms. Employment of 50 people is not huge. Many companies would have assets of $5 million. It will affect not only the motor traders but also many small businesses.

I was talking to one of my Senate colleagues last night, and we picked on a small town in Queensland. Together we could identify around five small businesses in a small sugar town of about 5,000 people that would be affected by this legislation. The owners or proprietors of those businesses would fall into the big category and would have to pay an additional $20,000 to $25,000 accountancy costs.

Madam Acting Deputy President West, I know that you are a representative of rural New South Wales. You know the desperate plight of many small businesses in rural Australia at the moment. You would know that, because of the drought, low commodity prices and because many small businesses have given credit out, they are in desperate stages themselves. If this bill were to go through in its present form, it would affect not only car dealers but also hardware dealers. Many hardware dealers have over 50 people and inventories of over $10 million and $5 million in assets. They are not huge companies, just family companies that have been there for many years, that have supported the towns, that have played their part in the small business of Australia.

There would also be many hotels that would fall into that category. A huge number of builders would fall into the category and would then have to pay an extra $20,000 to $25,000 accountancy fees. Small business has been indeed fortunate that this bill was delayed on the last day of the last session of parliament and that we have just headed this disaster off at the pass. Small business can breathe again.

I think it is a bit over the top when the Attorney-General's Department puts out a press release accusing the arrogant Liberals of holding legislation hostage when they are telling the business community, `Don't negotiate with the opposition. We'll look after you. Don't talk to the opposition. Don't do anything with the opposition. They can't help you. This is a matter of privacy between you and us.' While they were trying to stab small business in the back, they were putting out press releases accusing us of holding up the legislation. That is totally irresponsible of the Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch. It shows his total and utter contempt for small business in Australia.

It absolutely disappoints me that the Attorney-General's Department could hold the gun at small business's head and say `Don't go and talk to the opposition.' For goodness sake, we live in a democracy. This is not Russia. Fancy having an Attorney-General that is supposed to support the freedom of all Australians telling a certain group of business people, `Don't talk to the opposition or the Democrats, we'll look after you,' when they had no intention whatsoever of looking after small business.

Small business will not be disappointed in the government. They know that the government is their enemy. They know that the ALP has no understanding or comprehension of small business at all. They will just say, `We wouldn't have expected anything more from the ALP.' I will leave my presentation at that, because I believe many other people want to address this bill. In closing, I want to say that it is a joke for the ALP and the government to tell the small business associations—not such small businesses, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, which represents big business too—`Don't go and talk to the opposition or anyone else.' It is an absolute dereliction of the Attorney-General's duty as the chief law officer in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many good things about this legislation, particularly the simplification elements—and I am particularly talking about exempt proprietary companies. There are many exempt proprietary companies that have been for years unnecessarily burdened by the enormous costs of compliance with the Corporations Law. There is no doubt that one of the most offensive and intrusive roles of government is to impose enormous costs of compliance on the private sector, particularly on small businesses struggling to survive in a very competitive economic environment, an economic environment in which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is happy to say, `This is as good as it gets,' as they struggle to survive.

PARA.TAB: The costs of compliance in many instances and across many areas of federal legislation are ludicrously and unnecessarily high. I have to say that I commend the government for responding to a parliamentary committee's request that corporation—particularly exempt proprietary company—reporting be addressed properly. The great bulk of exempt proprietary companies exist not for the purpose of heavy trading with the public but for private purposes and are not involved in exposing members of the public to risk in doing business with them.

There are many family companies that are there for the convenience basically of the family, so that people have an equal or an adjudged share, depending on their shareholding, in the assets of the family. It is absurd that these people have been required to meet some of the quite significant requirements of the Corporations Law. I must say that I have sympathised with that expenditure and with the unnecessary effort that has had to be put in, particularly in providing key financial data or an audited report, depending on the circumstances.

Having said that, there is no doubt that many companies have abused the system. They have been able to abuse the system because the Australian Securities Commission has been inundated with annual returns from the hundreds of thousands of small businesses that are incorporated in Australia, from exempt proprietary companies, to the extent that the ASC has admitted repeatedly at Senate estimates hearings that it does not have the capacity, let alone the desire I think, to examine the accuracy—even on a spot check basis, the way the Taxation Commissioner does—of returns put in to the Australian Securities Commission by exempt proprietary companies.

For that reason the Prime Minister's piggery group, for example, kept putting in false and misleading annual returns, saying wrongly that they had earned profits when they had suffered losses and saying they had a surplus on shareholders' funds when they had deficits. It is because of this that the Prime Minister's piggery was able to get away with deceiving the Australian public for years about the true nature of how much the piggery was losing, curiously enough at a time when the Prime Minister managed to hold on for three years while the piggery lost millions of dollars; and then he sold out, at a profit, to foreigners. He hid that by using some devices, by selling it through his partner, so he would not have to be seen to be in a potential conflict of interest requiring Foreign Investment Review Board approval. The whole thing is a disgrace.

It is about time this Prime Minister did get up and acknowledge that his whole piggery venture was shrouded in breaches of the law; in fact, in breaches of five sets of laws. He has never at any stage distanced himself from those breaches. He has never said, `Look, I am sorry about this. I am sorry that my partner has been criticised by the Danish partners in this venture for having brought them into disrepute into Australia. I am sorry about that. I regret that these things happened.' Not on your life; he is too arrogant to regret anything. One of the reasons—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Far be it from me to try to do something about Senator Michael Baume's single-minded obsession, but we are, in fact, debating the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill. I think it would be a reasonable action on your part to draw that to Senator Baume's attention and ask him to address the substance of the bill that is before the Senate.

—On the point of order: the point I was making was that there is no capacity to check the accuracy and the breaches of the law by the Prime Minister's piggery group because the Australian Securities Commission has been inundated with requirements that are now being changed. It is specifically relevant to the matter.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—There is always a fine line in these matters between relevancy and irrelevancy. Usually in these debates, particularly on seemingly uncontroversial legislation, you are entitled to stray rather far, but I would ask Senator Baume not to stray too far and wide.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I have no intention of straying too far; I am just concentrating on this particular snout in this particular trough.

PARA.TAB: As I was saying, the inundation of the Australian Securities Commission with annual returns—most of which are unnecessary and which impose a ludicrous burden on the Securities Commission—has prevented the Securities Commission from properly examining the fraudulent activity of so many companies which deliberately put in false annual returns. Because the Securities Commission under this proposed change is going to get rid of that burden of having to require key financial data and so on coming in, it will at last have the opportunity—and I encourage the ASC to use that opportunity—to direct its attention to checking those returns that come in, perhaps on a spot check basis. This would ensure that the sort of misreporting, deception and fraudulent activity, such as took place in the Prime Minister's piggery group in the matter of their false reports to the ASC, can be properly checked in future.

It will not then depend on a member of parliament going in and searching through the matters on the public record to establish just how false and inaccurate the returns have been and, for example, how they were in breach of the Securities Commission's own recommendations by failing at one stage to put in the appropriate audited returns. Those audited returns demonstrated that the previous returns put in by the Prime Minister's piggery group partner, Mr Constantinidis, were false. That is why that is so relevant. These changes will stop people like Mr Constantinidis, acting on behalf of Mr Keating as his half owner in the piggery group, putting in false returns with impunity. The ASC will now be able to focus on these matters, instead of being inundated with a whole lot of unnecessary annual returns, because of this legislation getting rid of that burden.

There are, nonetheless, some problems. While I commend the government for reducing the cost of compliance for a whole range of proprietary companies, I still say there are offensive and enormous costs of compliance over a whole range of other governmental activities. For instance, the taxation legislation involves compliance costs which are absurd and a disgrace to small business. A survey of accountants revealed recently that the cost of collecting sales tax, for example, by small business is on average some 25 per cent of the sales tax actually collected. But the taxation commissioner does not carry that cost; small business does.

Alleged simplifications have taken place in the past—the tax legislation, for example. I can remember this government saying it was going to simplify the tax act. When it came to government the tax act was 1,100 pages long. It has been `simplified' into 3,347 pages. The costs of compliance to business are absolutely absurd. I have some concerns. While this legislation is going to make it certainly much cheaper and much more reasonable for small proprietary companies, particularly family companies, to meet their reporting obligations, there is a cut-off level. That cut-off level causes me some concern.

For example, large proprietary companies will have to put in detailed audited returns. There is some merit in that. The question is: at what level do you become a large company? According to the act, large proprietary companies are those which meet at least two of the following criteria: their gross operating revenue must be $10 million a year or more, their assets must be $5 million or more and the number of employees 50 or more. There is one crucial error in that trilogy—the word `assets'. That is so irrelevant. I simply cannot understand how it can have got through parliamentary committees and the appropriate authorities and the government—although the government has been there so long it probably does not have the capacity to examine legislation properly anyway.

The word `assets' is totally irrelevant. The correct word, the word of relevance, particularly to people who do business with companies, is `liabilities', the external liabilities. That should be the judgment. Assets fail on almost every ground when you look at them as the criteria. Assets can be `revalued'. Assets are subject to subjective valuation. The piggery company's assets got trebled in size by a revaluation, not assisted by any registered valuers. Paul Keating's piggery company suddenly got revalued upwards, despite the fact that it was deteriorating. Unfortunately pigs' urine does have some kind of an impact on buildings. They increased the value of the buildings—not the land, not the property—in a ludicrous, nonsensical dressing up of the accounts to try to make them look more presentable. Yet here we have the government having assets, which are subject, as I said, to subjective fiddling, being the criteria. What we will see here are assets being fiddled down. A building bought 30 years ago may well appear in these accounts at cost.

You might have the view that that is a good way of understating your assets. This sort of incompetence does not impress me, particularly when we look at the concerns of people doing business with a corporation, with a group. What they want to know is the liabilities. You cannot fiddle your liabilities. Liabilities are liabilities—what you owe. You cannot revalue them. Sure, you can make provisions against them. I cannot see how you can fiddle your liabilities.

What is particularly relevant is that if you have liabilities as the criteria, say $5 million worth of liabilities, you should then say `external liabilities'. If the liabilities are owed to the owner of the company, then the owner of the company is at risk. That happens in many instances for a whole lot of reasons. Or it may be liability to a group—for example, a motor dealer whose liabilities are to the motor company to which he is franchised. If those liabilities were excluded—in other words, they are in-house liabilities—then we would not have the sort of problem that Senator Boswell and Senator Macdonald, certainly in discussions with me, have raised about motor distributors, for example, in small Queensland towns suddenly being held to be major proprietary companies and caught under the quite proper and significant reporting requirements.

I want to stress: it is so easy to fix this mess. All you have to do is make it `external liabilities'. As I said, why the government has not done that, I presume, can only be because of the massive lack of commercial experience by people in government who are making laws about how to run businesses and who have never been exposed to the reality of business themselves. I hope that it is not too late in the process. Certainly, I hope there will be a Senate committee meeting, presumably on Friday, about this simple change which will properly exclude, hopefully, those people who should be excluded from this process and who are unintended consequences, if you like, of this kind of legislation.

I want to stress: there is a very sound case indeed for requiring larger companies to come clean. I think the ASC estimates that about only two per cent of exempt proprietary companies would be required to meet these new commitments. There is a very good case for that to happen. Let us recognise this: giving people limited liability by allowing them to incorporate their businesses should bring with it appropriate and offsetting accountability. So it is not good enough to say, `I've got a company. I don't have to reveal anything. I don't have to report properly. I don't have to do all the things that should be offsetting, if you like, the great benefit I have got of limited liability.'

There is a real and great need for accountably in Australia, particularly judging by some of the disgraceful behaviour of some builders, for example, to their subcontractors. In so many instances in Australia, buildings have been put up at the cost of subcontractors who have to carry the can when the builder goes broke. We have had too many examples of this sort of thing to fail to recognise that there is a clear need for accountability when you have limited liability. But the big question is: how accountable should you be?

What I find difficult is that there is, in this legislation, an inadequate description of what makes up a group of companies that would enable it to be classified as big. We have seen the criteria, which I said should be changed from assets of $5 million to liabilities of $5 million, with gross operating revenues of $10 million; liabilities, let us hope, of $5 million; and the number of employees at 50. What is to stop a dishonest group splitting itself up so that it escapes this criteria? The legislation says:

SPEECH.PARA: the consolidated gross operating revenue for the financial year of the company and the entities it controls (if any) is $10 million or more.

It says `the entities it controls'. There is no definition here about control—at least I could not see one in the legislation. It would seem to me that there is a real risk. If a person as an owner of a company were to directly own as well company B in which company A, the one he owned, has an interest, who actually owns that ultimate company? Is it the original owner? Is it the company he owns?

PARA.TAB: The big question is that there appear to me to be loopholes through which dishonest people could fiddle this arrangement to diminish the appearance of ownership. It says `the company'; it does not say `a person who controls'. In clause 3, on page 46 of the bill, it says `large proprietary company'. What concerns me is that this is a loophole that should be closed.

I say that because once again we can learn from experience. We can look at the Keating piggery group. They hived off a company in order to avoid the industrial relations law. They hived off a company so they would not have more than 16 employees. It was a member of the group, but they changed the ownership so that it appeared to be held by another member of that group. I might say that, as a result, they underpaid three workers—and this was while Mr Keating was a half owner, of course, but you expect that from a Labor leader, cheating his workers—and then pretended they were not the real employer at all, hiding the name of the real employer when action was taken against them. So we have seen from the experience of the Keating companies that this kind of legislation can be got around if someone has a mind to do so.

My final concern is that existing companies which appear to be of note do not need to meet these new requirements. For example, the Keating piggery group—allegedly no longer held by him, although there is a curious option to repurchase—can escape these requirements if they choose to stick by the old rules; in other words, if it has its accounts audited and decides not to be in it. Why is there this escape hatch? Why does this need to be grandfathered? There is a real need for improvement in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contents of this First Corporate Law Simplification Bill and its course through parliament demonstrate how necessary it is to be forever vigilant when looking at what this government proposes. This bill has the general support of the coalition and, I think, widespread support in the business community.

PARA.TAB: If you read the explanatory memorandum and the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), you could not help but agree with the proposals that are put forward. In relation to proprietary companies the explanatory memorandum mentions that single director companies will now be allowed, and I think that is a worthwhile amendment. The memorandum says that a comprehensive guide for small business will be included. I have had a look at that, and I think that is very worthwhile. Before coming to parliament I did a little bit of legal work advising small companies in a small country town, and I think that will be very useful for people who use a company set-up to operate their businesses.

The explanatory memorandum goes on to say there will be reduced accounting and financial reporting. What a great innovation that will be for small business people. The annual general meeting becomes optional. I might say, without giving away any secrets, that those things were more done in name than in actual form in the past, so I think the legislation has eventually caught up with practice. That in itself is a good innovation. The explanatory memorandum also goes on to say that small proprietary companies will not have to prepare annual accounts unless required to do so by the ACS. For most proprietary companies, or for what were previously exempt proprietary companies, that is also appropriate.

So, on the face of it, this legislation—which has the aim of achieving significant simplification of the text of the law, simplifying the substance of the rules and eliminating unnecessary and redundant legislation—is a good one. Certainly on that basis the Liberal and National parties support it.

But, due to the Labor Party's own mismanagement and failures, this bill was not brought before the chamber prior to the Senate rising at the end of June. The Attorney-General, quite wrongly and mischievously, accused the opposition of holding up this bill and, in doing so, said that small business people would be shattered as a result of our action. First of all, it was not true that it was our action; it was due to the government's own incompetence. Secondly, in hindsight, it is particularly fortunate that the bill was not rushed through and that the Senate exercised its normal right to scrutinise these things in depth because it has transpired that the bill is not all that it seems to be.

My colleagues who have spoken before me have highlighted the principal concern that has been exposed in the last parliamentary break. The thing that concerns me and others on this side, but would come as no shock to those trying to deal with this Labor Party government, is that a group of people who have an interest in this bill, a small business representative group, approached the government with an argument about what needed looking at. I am told—and some of my colleagues have related this experience as well—by some of those people involved that these groups went before the government and its advisers and were told that the argument seemed to be a good one. They were told by almost a wink and a nod that their concerns would be looked after.

When these groups said, `If you are going to look at these, perhaps the Liberal and National parties and the minor parties should also be advised and we should circulate our material to them,' the advisers and government representatives said, `Don't do that. Don't tell them about it. We'll fix it up. We'll look after it. Don't you worry about that.' The wink and the nod was given that it would all be okay. It then transpires that nothing happened. These people relaxed because they understood that the government was going to address these concerns. Nothing happened and, as a result, it was only in recent times that the Liberal and National parties became aware of these concerns.

I did not intend to speak on this bill. I thought it was a pretty simple matter. It was one that I supported, so I had not listed myself to speak. But several business people from North Queensland—in fact, a couple from my own home town of Ayr—raised this matter with me. For the government's and advisers' consideration, they say that not many companies and small businesses are going to be affected by this legislation, particularly the distinction between small and large proprietary companies. But in my own home town of Ayr, which is a prosperous and, we think, quite large country town—about 20,000 people in the district—without even contacting anyone, I know from my experience in a legal practice in that area that there would be three family companies at least—and, as I say, I know this from my own knowledge without doing any research, without talking to anyone—who are now caught by this definition and will now become large proprietary companies rather than exempt proprietary companies as they were.

I am told by those people that the additional cost to them of having things audited will be in the range of $10,000 to $30,000, and I see some other press reports saying $30,000 to $80,000. But many of these companies—not the ones I talk about, but small businesses who operate through companies—would not have operating profits of $30,000 a year. Yet this government wants those people to spend, in many instances, more than their total annual profit in going through these requirements. Perhaps I am being a bit harsh. Perhaps it is an unintended consequence that the government was not aware of. But I know the government was aware of it because these groups tried to talk to it and its advisers. They were given the wink and the nod and then completely ignored.

If this is as good as it gets, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has told small business, then a lot of these small business people that I know are in real trouble. This sort of insensitivity comes from a government which has no understanding or appreciation of small business, a government which is comprised of ministers, a vast majority of whom have never worked in private enterprise and who have always had the cheque coming in at the end of the week or the end of the month. People who have worked for the Labor Party, people who have worked for the union movement—and that is the majority of ministers—people in the Public Service or academia, people who have always had a regular income, simply cannot appreciate what it is like to be in small business.

This sort of legislation just makes it so much more difficult for small business to continue operating. We have an unemployment problem in Australia because small business, which is still the greatest employer of people, is simply scared stiff about doing anything while this government remains in control doing this sort of thing. There are lots of other reasons why they are concerned about this government's actions, but this piece of legislation is just one example of why small business is so petrified of doing anything while the Labor Party remains in government. And it is the reason why small business, almost to a man and woman, are desperate to get to the next election so they have the opportunity to get rid of this government and their colleagues in the corner, the Australian Democrats, who are so anti-small business and who have created the climate in which small businesses are incapable of making decisions for the future.

I digress, I know, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I must say this: that ridiculous unfair dismissals legislation has put so many small business people off employing people. Whether they should be concerned or not is another question and, I think, principally they should be concerned. But the fear of that legislation means that small business people, who are now working 18 hours a day seven days a week, would like to put on additional staff but are scared out of doing so. That again is typical of this government's insensitivity. We have heard that it is going to change that legislation but we have not seen anything about it.

Despite all the talk, all the typical sorts of promises you will get from the Labor Party between now and the next election, people in Australia have just given up believing the Labor Party. They don't believe Mr Keating—quite rightly, I might add. They don't believe Mr Carr. Of course, his major election promise was that there would be no tollway on those roads. What did we have? We got to a month, I think, before he reneged on his promise. Mr Keating only left it two or three days after the election to renege on his. We had Mr Goss going around with that disgraceful campaign in Queensland, saying that a coalition government would sell hospitals—a claim that he knew was abjectly false but he went around saying it. It is just part of the Labor Party tactic: say anything, do anything before an election to get yourself elected. Lie your way through an election campaign and, when you get elected, when the people fall for those lies, change your mind.

I don't know why I am giving advice to the Labor Party but they would know this from their own polling: people in Australia no longer believe the Labor Party or any of their people. So it will not matter what Mr Keating says in the major speech he is going to make tomorrow—people just won't believe him, and rightly so. But, Mr Acting Deputy President, I digress. This legislation and the way it has been handled simply indicates again this government's insensitivity to the needs of small business.

With the resources that are available to an opposition, we are not in a position to go through this in any detail, but I doubt the government's estimation that not many companies are involved in this. As I say, in my small country town in North Queensland, without even trying to look or talk to people about it, I know three family businesses who would be caught. Multiplying that across Australia, there are a hell of a lot of small family businesses who have incorporated to run their business who would be caught by this legislation and would face additional accounting fees of between $30,000 and $80,000 to comply with this. So I say to the government and their advisers: please have a look at this; you have the resources, we don't.

As Senator Vanstone mentioned yesterday in her speech at the beginning of this debate, we want this legislation to go to the Senate committee on Friday. That committee could look at it. Those who have a real concern with this would have the opportunity to put their case and convince not only the government but the opposition of the strength of their argument. They could put forward some facts and figures that, unfortunately, with the very limited resources the government of the day gives us, we are not in a position to present.

If this matter is referred to the committee it will give those groups of small business people the opportunity to come forward and say, `This is where you are wrong. Here are some of the facts. This is what we think you should do. This is how you should do it.' It will then be up to the Senate committee, and ultimately the Senate, to determine whether there is a way in which this legislation can be amended to overcome some of the fears that have been expressed.

Apart from the definition of what is large and what is small, this seems to be a reasonably good piece of legislation. However, it needs some clarification. Perhaps the minister, in responding, could indicate just how much of the corporate entity these proposals take in. Where there are a number of proprietary companies in a group, do the three requirements—assets of less than $5 million, operating revenue of less than $10 million, and fewer than 50 employees—apply to the whole group or to each individual company in the group.

It has been suggested to me that, where companies operate through trusts, the determining factor on whether the bill applies to trusts is the independence of the trustee. If there is a relationship between the shareholders and directors of a trustee company and the beneficiaries of the trust the bill will apply. We might need to look at that provision because once we start including trusts in the same area as the corporate law we may be venturing into other areas.

In his second reading speech the Attorney-General acknowledged that somewhere along the line we have to set an arbitrary limit. I do not know that any of the submissions so far made to us have come up with any alternatives. It is a question of where we set the arbitrary limit. Many small businesses—particularly those in the group who have contacted me—have high operating turnover or revenue because of the high value of the goods sold. The actual profit involved is quite minimal.

Senator Baume mentioned the fact that having assets of $5 million or more as one of the criteria for determining whether one has a so-called large company is quite ludicrous. I do not know much about Sydney or Melbourne, but I suspect that if you owned your own property in Sydney or Melbourne you would be up to the asset value already. I have not carefully considered Senator Baume's suggestion that it should be on liabilities, but certainly those things should be looked at.
The attempt to try and simplify the corporate law is a good one and the Liberal and National parties have been calling for it for some time. We support the general thrust of the legislation.

I have said before that I think the small business guide will be very useful. The idea of enabling small businesses and companies to have only one shareholder and one director is an improvement. There have been a lot of difficulties with small businesses and small companies, particularly in the instance where one of the two shareholders or directors dies. When husbands and wives are the sole directors and sole shareholders of proprietary companies and one dies and by will leaves all of their assets, including their shares in the proprietary company, to the surviving spouse you had a situation where there was only one director and one shareholder. That posed some difficulties, but that will be overcome by these new proposals.

Whilst the coalition supports most of what is contained in this bill, there is the issue of what is a small company and what is a large company which needs to be looked at. I know that the Democrats are going to support the proposal to refer this issue to a committee, so it will go to a committee on Friday. I hope the government will accept the opportunity that will be given and make a genuine attempt to find a solution, in conjunction with the Liberal and National parties, the Democrats, the Greens and others, which will be of benefit to small business and provide the opportunity that small business in Australia needs—that is, cutting down the regulations and red tape and getting on with the business of earning money and employing people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues in this debate on the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill. As Senator Ian Macdonald has just said, it is a good proposal and it has the support of the coalition. It is sad that the government has taken so long to bring this matter forward. There is one relatively minor matter which we are asking the Senate to look at.
—You lot would not have had anything to do with that, would you—all the time-wasting we have had in this place.

—We are talking about this particular bill. I will go into the details of what your government has done in relation to the timing of this bill. This bill will provide a means for small businesses with single members or directors to avoid the need for annual general meetings. This will be a very good thing for lots of small businesses. We applaud that measure.

PARA.TAB: I should also point out that earlier this year when the matter was brought before the House it was referred to the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, of which I am Deputy Chairman. That committee examined several matters that were brought before it. We were given a very short time to look at the matter and we took evidence from 10 separate entities. As others have pointed out to the Senate yesterday and today, the most contention was about the definition of small and large proprietary companies.

I remind the Senate that the argument was really between the accountants' view that the law should reflect the reporting entity test which is accepted and well known in accounting circles, and the task force recommendation that there be a much simpler test. I point out to the Senate, as set out in the report of that committee of 2 March this year, that the committee recommended in favour of the simplified test for large and small companies being based on assets, revenue and the number of employees.

We recommended the three criteria approach rather than the accounting test approach. That decision was made based on simplicity of understanding for people in small business. In other words, it means that anyone running a small business can pick up the test, read and understand it and make a judgment themselves as to whether or not they qualify. Whereas, if you pick up the reporting entity test recommended by the accounting bodies, I defy anyone who is not an accountant to understand what that really is about. The net effect of that would be to throw everyone off to seek their accountant's advice rather than to make that decision.

The evidence we took persuaded the committee that that should be the guiding thing and that we should have clarity in the law. That is the position the committee supported. The government is staying with that position, which the coalition supports. Since then, and due to the inordinate length of time that the government has taken since the report of 2 March to bring the matter forward here in the Senate—and I will go into that timing in a minute—there has been some concern raised by businesses around the borderline.

I am sure it is an arbitrary test. We acknowledge that fact in the committee's report. With an arbitrary test, there will always be people around the borderline. There has been genuine concern expressed by a reasonable number of businesses who will be around the borderline as to whether or not they should be forced to go the route of having to incur audit expenses.That is a very real problem. That is why we in the coalition are proposing to have a very short inquiry on this matter, perhaps a Friday committee, to gather evidence and see whether in fact the hurdles that have been set in the bill are appropriate and whether or not the level of those hurdles should be changed.

The committee actually came to the conclusion that, of the three criteria set out in the bill, the turnover—that is, the revenue—and the assets were the important ones, which basically fits with international practice in comparison with the UK and particularly our neighbour New Zealand. We were less persuaded that the number of employees—that is, the 50 employees—was terribly relevant.

Be that as it may, I think it is important that we seek further advice about this matter. I am sure that can be resolved very quickly. The question really is how many companies are involved and whether or not it is important for that information to be out in the public arena. It now appears that lots of family companies would exceed the revenue turnover of $10 million as well as the gross assets of $5 million. So I think that is well worth reviewing.

I come now to the matter of timing. Again, I remind the Senate that the report was tabled on 2 March this year. If the government had regarded the matter as being urgent, it could easily have brought the matter forward from then. But what did in fact happen? The bill was read in the House of Representatives for the third time on 9 March. On 23 March this year, it was introduced into the Senate. But it was not until 29 June, as opposed to 23 March when it was introduced here, that the matter was brought forward for debate.

That was a government decision, yet the government knew that lots of small businesses wanted relief from this matter of reporting, particularly with regard to annual general meetings. The matter was urgent for the business community but the government deliberately decided not to bring it forward. Worse than that—and because of the way the government business was managed in the Senate in the last week of June—it was brought in on the second last day and was fouled up, if you like, in the procedure of the last day and a half. Hence, it did not go through.

To add insult to injury, the Prime Minister went out the next week and accused the coalition of holding up the passing of that bill. What an absolute hide to go out and tell such lies! We were not holding it up. We were happy for the bill to proceed, but we had to go through due and proper process in this place. For the Prime Minister to go out in the public arena and accuse the coalition of actually holding up the bill and therefore disadvantaging small business was really misleading the community. As a consequence, about a month ago I wrote a detailed letter setting out the facts of the matter to the National Small Business Forum, stating that the coalition was not to blame and could in no way be blamed for holding up this particular bill. We supported the bill, as I said before.

The good thing that has happened because of the delay—the government delay, not our delay—is that information has come to hand about concern about the definition of the criteria for large versus small. That is well worth spending a little time examining and examining urgently. I am sure that can be resolved. I know the government has had representations from the ACCI, motor traders and others pushing for a change in the criteria. Doubling the criteria was one proposal. Another proposal was an exemption in the Corporations Act—in other words an escape clause in the corporations code—to allow the ASC to grant exemptions from the auditing requirement. So there are a couple of proposals that the government has had before it.

With regard to the definition of the criteria for large versus small, it is well worth looking at urgently. I am sure we can come to a sensible solution. Given that, the coalition will certainly support this bill and see its passage through this place, with the support I understand of basically all the parties. That would be a good thing for small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly to the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1995 and to our amendments, though not too briefly. We have no substantial problems with the bill itself. We think it is a good measure to enable a simplification of the law and to help small business. We originally sought to put an amendment on corrupt practices to this bill because we were advised that this is the most appropriate piece of legislation for the requirement of a register on corporate activities. We had expected it to be debated early last session. When it became apparent that it would not reach the floor until the dying moments of the last session, I decided to withdraw my amendment in the interest of the timely passage of the bill since it was unlikely to get up.

PARA.TAB: Since that time we have heard from the Attorney-General's Department that the OECD has proposed a united approach by its members on the issue of paying bribes to corrupt officials—a measure based on the US corrupt practices legislation. If this goes ahead, it will be stronger than our amendment was intended to be since it will involve criminal penalties against companies paying bribes. At this point, we have decided to stay with our decision to withdraw the amendment in support of an anti-corrupt practices regime. I wish to speak briefly to the issue, though, and note that we consider international corruption to be an important issue on which action should be taken.

Our amendments were basically measures in support of the international effort to stop what are known as corrupt practices or illicit payments. This is directed against bribery and graft. It is also part of the Greens (WA) effort to ensure that trade is conducted in a socially responsible manner. We gave copies of our draft amendment to the coalition, to the Democrats, to Senator Harradine's office and to the Business Council of Australia before the budget was brought down to get feedback. I understand that the coalition decided not to support our amendment because they had not had time for detailed consideration. I also understand they support the principle of acting to stop corruption and bribery internationally. I have noted that the government is currently negotiating on the OECD proposal, and I hope that all parties will act cooperatively on this issue in the future.

Bribery and corruption is not normal market behaviour. It may go on but it distorts markets and does not allow free trading. An environment of corruption can exclude companies and products through various means and there is no way to get redress or to appeal. Ultimately, allowing corruption and bribery is one of the best ways to increase the costs of corruption, including the costs of bribes that have to be paid for by access to markets or to gain contracts.

There is nothing open or above board about bribery and graft and no way to appeal to a higher authority about what has occurred. The only thing to do is to try to up the ante, give a higher or bigger bribe and hope it will be effective. It is not a good way to do business. This is one of the reasons the Business Council accepts that an anti-corruption regime should exist.

I want to give an example that I have come across recently. It appears that Indonesia's environment laws are quite good on the surface. There are lots of areas where it would appear they have stronger environmental laws than Australia's—which, in some instances, would not be difficult. But the reality is that very few people abide by the letter of the law. An example was given of a request in recent times that Australian aid be used for an Australian company to go into Indonesia and clean up a river which was being polluted by dioxins from several pulp mills in the area. If we were to look at the law, we would probably find that all the pulp mills were acting against the law that existed and were liable to a number of criminal penalties.

But the problem was—and everybody understood it—that it was unlikely that those companies would ever be forced to abide by the law. It may be that the companies involved had already bribed officials or it may be that at some stage in the future it could be a means of raising money. Somebody could pick on a particular law and a particular company and say, `Well, you have broken this law. Unless you pay this certain amount we will prosecute.' The reality is that it is extremely difficult in that situation. But the fact that it is so accepted in Australia that a company should be requesting taxpayers' funds to clean up a situation that clearly was caused illegally, gives an indication of how accepted that practice has come to be.

The prospect of business representatives being thrown in gaol because the bribes weren't big enough is not something business looks forward to. The difficulties of trading in markets where it is not certain whom to bribe, how much to bribe or what they will get for a bribe is not something they like. Trading in markets where big players like Lockheed can significantly influence governments is not an easy task. It would be better if the terms and conditions of trade were clear.

Several nations are also trying to ensure that corruption does not become the norm. Nations like Singapore and Malaysia are strong opponents of corruption and they impose heavy penalties. But it is often not enough, especially where wages for government officers are hardly enough to cover living costs. In such a case, officers are prey to both greed and unscrupulous businesses even where their own governments impose substantial penalties.

The United Nations Economic and Social Council has adopted a draft international agreement on corrupt practices. Some nations have taken strong unilateral measures. The United States has passed its Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, making bribery by corporations operating overseas illegal and prosecutable under United States law.

The US may be big enough to take unilateral action and make bribery illegal. Australia, as a small international player, must accept that any attempt to make such actions illegal would compromise businesses trading in areas where corruption is the norm. So we have sought to take minimalist action to support the international move to ensure that anti-corruption actions will affect everyone equally and create a level playing field.

Our amendment seeks simply to establish a register of payments, gifts and so on to intermediaries. This is part of the provision under the United Nations agreement and we have used language equivalent to that in the agreement. In order to avoid a huge compliance burden, we have tried to set the sums recorded as equivalent to those which must already be recorded under AusTRAC.

As I have said, the Business Council has looked to our amendment and can accept it, although it is never happy when the government regulates. It too would like to see a situation where it did not have to operate in a corrupt environment, as long as it applied to everyone. It accepts that we have not imposed penalties and tried to set sums recorded at a level which would reduce compliance costs. Whilst I have withdrawn our amendment, I put the Senate on notice that this is an important issue and one that we will continue to pursue in the future. I think the Democrats, Senator Harradine and the coalition support us in this in general terms and hope that we can get non-partisan support for efforts to end corruption in international trade and to support those other nations, including many developing nations, who wish to stamp this out.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been said by other honourable senators on this side of the chamber, we in the coalition support the general thrust of the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1995. The problem is that the bill has unforeseen consequences in relation to audit provisions. I feel it is appropriate to discuss exactly what consequences we are talking about and why those consequences must be guarded against here in the Senate before the bill receives a third reading.

PARA.TAB: The basic problem comes with the threefold test which has been proposed for the definition of a large company or a small company. The threefold test says that a company is a large company if it meets any two of three criteria. Those three criteria are that it has a turnover in excess of $10 million; that it has gross assets, not net assets, in excess of $5 million; or that the company has 50 or more employees. I understand what the government is aiming at but quite clearly these thresholds are unacceptably low. It is very easy for a company these days to have a turnover of $10 million—and $10 million in turnover, I should point out, does not mean $10 million in profit. Many companies have far more turnover than that and run at a loss.

There is no relationship, as anybody in business knows, between turnover on the one hand and profitability on the other hand. So that in itself gives rise to a lot of concern. If we are to say that there should be an obligation to have a company audited solely on the basis of, say, turnover and gross assets—and gross assets can include, for example, inventory—then one of the problems is that we impose a massive cost on that company. That cost has in itself a number of consequences.
