The first is that that cost can drag a company from being profitable to being unprofitable, with all the attendant problems in terms of loss of work, loss of opportunities and so on.

Secondly, companies that remain profitable have a limited range of resources available to them in order to achieve their objectives. The simple question we have to ask ourselves is this: is the $20,000 or $30,000 in expected audit costs that these companies will have to bear the most efficient way those companies can utilise that money? Is this the optimum utilisation of that resource? I believe that the answer to that question is no; it is not the optimum utilisation of that resource. To answer that question we have to look at the rationale for saying that the company should be obliged to spend this money. The answer to that question is this: if this is not a publicly listed company, the only reason why you would want to have an auditor go over the accounts of the company is to ensure that the accounts are accurate for the benefit, not of shareholders, but of potential creditors of the company.

Do the creditors get real value from that company spending a minimum of $20,000 to $30,000 in additional accounting fees on auditing? I believe the answer is no. First of all, let us look at the sorts of companies that would be caught by this change in the legislation. I know private supermarkets that would get caught by this legislation. I know people who sell fruit and vegetables who would get caught by this legislation. I know even of a pie shop in North Queensland that would probably get caught by this because it sells a lot of pies to the army.

It is very easy to have a turnover of $10 million and to have gross assets of $5 million or more, but gross assets do not really tell us anything at all about the company. We should be looking at net assets or we should be looking at liabilities because, if you are talking about protecting the interests of potential creditors, surely the liabilities are a more important threshold test than their gross assets. It obviously has not been thought out in proper depth.

What are we to do to the baker who just happens to have $5 million in gross assets because he owns the site for the business—he might be mortgaged, but he technically owns the site—the factory and the baking equipment, which all come into the category of gross assets, and, because he happens to sell pies to the army when they go to Rwanda, gets caught up because he has more than $10 million in turnover? What are we to do for that baker? Is it right that we should say to that person, who in all probability trades with most of his or her creditors on a cash basis anyway, `We are going to subject you to additional audit costs'? Is that the best way to encourage that business to succeed? The answer to that, quite clearly, has to be, `No, it is not.'

Let us look at the situation of a company which sells fruit and vegetables and which might have two or three retail outlets and either its turnover exceeds $10 million or, because maybe it has some truck drivers and some backroom staff and does some wholesaling as well, it has 50 employees or more at some time in the year. Are we to say to that company, `We are also going to oblige you to undergo this audit process'? There is going to be nothing achieved.

The people who sell or consign the fruit do it on the basis of two or three consignments a week, so they are only at risk for one consignment, two consignments or maybe three consignments at most, and the company trades mainly on cash terms; yet, in spite of this, every year they are going to have the auditors crawl through each of the outlets and through the retail section. They will be sitting there counting apples, oranges, lemons and bananas. And for this privilege we, in our infinite wisdom here in the Senate, are going to say to them, `You can pay $20,000 to $30,000 minimum additional cost.' That is absolutely absurd!

This is supposed to be corporate law simplification. This does not sound to me like corporate law simplification; this sounds like corporate law complexity, for the simple reason that there is a problem with the definition. That is why I believe it is incumbent upon this Senate to take the opportunity to refer the matter to a Senate committee for quick examination and to report back.

There are those on the government side who would say, `This is merely another attem pt by the opposition to hurt small business by delaying this legislation.' Nothing could be further from the truth. The reason this problem has arisen only now is not because of the opposition; the problem arises, honourable senators, because of the conduct of the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch).

Why do I say that? When the small business organisations went to the Attorney-General to outline their concerns, to say to him, `This bill and this provision will have the effect of subjecting many thousands of small businesses to additional operating costs,' he and his department said to them, `Give us your thoughts. Give us your full submission. But don't go to the media about it just yet and don't go to the opposition because I am sure we can do something about it.' That was basically, I understand, the thrust of the discussion.

Of course the Attorney-General did nothing about it, because the provision in its original form is still in the bill as it sits before the Senate today. Had the Attorney-General not so misled the small business lobby organisations, they would have come to the opposition and we could have raised the issue when it went to the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. It was only as a result of the careful examination by Senator McGauran—I acknowledge his contribution to that committee's report in his dissent—that we realised there was any problem at all.

We in the opposition were generally of the belief that the bill's aims were good aims, were good intentions and were worthy of support. And indeed they are, but the task of the Senate is not to rubber stamp legislation and say, `Do we think the bill as a whole is good or bad?' Part of our task is to ensure that where there are unforeseen consequences of the legislation, those unforeseen consequences should and must be eliminated. So Senator McGauran deserves the congratulations of all honourable senators for the fine work he did in putting in his dissent.

The point remains: had the small business lobby organisations not been dissuaded by the Attorney-General from taking their concerns to the opposition or to the media, as was entirely their right, then maybe the situation could have been rectified much earlier. Maybe the situation could have been resolved before the second reading debate on the bill was resumed in this chamber yesterday. Maybe that is what should have happened.

It is not the opposition who are at fault for the delay in the passage of the legislation. Ultimately the fault for the delay in the passage of the legislation lies with the Attorney-General because he had the opportunity to fix the matter up. He did not do it.

Furthermore, the opposition would have had the opportunity to address the matter much earlier. We were never given that full opportunity because the Attorney-General misled the lobby groups for his own political advantage, not for the good governance of this country. Let us remember one thing: the task of the Attorney-General is to oversee legislation in the best interests of the country, not in the best interests of Mr Michael Lavarch or of the Labor Party. Quite clearly the Attorney-General has failed in his duty to ensure that that took place. There was no way in which the opposition could address this matter any earlier than yesterday because the parliament was in recess and it was not possible for the opposition to further refer the matter to a Senate committee for quick examination.

The delay is a delay which we do not like and which we would like to not have had exist, but it is a delay which, unfortunately, must now take place if we are to do our proper duty, as senators of the parliament of Australia, and ensure that the legislation to which we give our agreement is good legislation. That is the key. People get hurt when parliament does not do its job properly. That is why we are here debating this at the moment.

If we are going to talk about the general concept of auditing, it is also appropriate that we talk about the general disclosure provisions. Even if these accounts are audited, I do not think it really makes much difference at all to a potential creditor of a company. I say that as one who has had enormous experience in talking with insolvency practitioners, in working with the insolvency profession and in talking with credit managers. In reality, the change that occurred at the time the Corporations Law was introduced was a change which eliminated the previous reporting requirements on companies. Previously companies were obliged to file every year their profit and loss statement and their balance sheet. Those documents were public documents that were available from the then National Companies and Securities Commission, now the Australian Securities Commission. Senator Jones, on the other side, in his former life before coming into the Senate, in his business dealings with other people, may have had cause to look at these documents.

The system provided people with financial information on which they could make their own assumptions. At the end of the day, business people are in the business of making judgments and making assumptions about other people with whom they do business. A good businessman or a good businesswoman is good at making those assumptions; a poor one is poor at making those assumptions.

The problem is that the change in legislation which was brought in by the Corporations Law meant in many cases that those profit and loss and balance sheets were not generally available to the public. Instead, when you scrutinised a company, you merely got the summary financial data, and the summary financial data does not provide enough information on which to make a balanced or accurate judgment. You need to look not just at what are the net assets or the net liabilities or the total assets or the total liabilities; you need to look at exactly what they are. You need to look at how many of the liabilities are current liabilities; at how many of the liabilities are non-current liabilities; at which of those liabilities are liabilities to directors and shareholders, because a corporate manager can then form a view as to whether those liabilities are likely to be called; at which of them are secured and over which assets are they secured. These are the things that people need to know.

If a company has a lot of current liabilities and a small amount of non-current liabilities, yet all its assets are tied up in real estate, you could form the view that the company may have difficulty meeting its short-term liabilities as and when they fall due. In fact, an increase in current liabilities with the same asset structure—that is, an asset structure that is tied up in fixed assets—is perhaps indicative of the fact that the company is trading whilst it is on the road to becoming insolvent. None of this information do we glean from the current system of having summary financial data. If we have summary financial data which is audited, it still makes no difference because the core information is not available to the people who have to make the decision.

Maybe I am a voice in the wilderness, but I honestly believe that we would be better off going back to the system of obliging people to file their profit and loss and balance sheets every year and making those documents public documents, as then we would not need to have auditors. In reality, it is then a matter of the business people being provided with sufficient information and being able to make the decisions themselves.

In a private enterprise system—even in a free enterprise system, something I distinguish—we have to be careful we do not develop the mollycoddle mentality which says, `We will have people who will be responsible for your bad decisions.' Of course, if you have all these companies audited, people will say, `Look, the auditor is to blame; I am not to blame.' All you will see will be a blow-out in suits where creditors of companies which become insolvent go and sue the auditor. Really, that does not aid the administration of the legal system in this country, and it really does not focus business on what is important. Business ought to be focused on making good business decisions; business should not be focused on whether they are likely to win by suing this auditor or that auditor of a company which has become insolvent. That is not what business should be about. Business should not be about litigating; it should be about going out and doing business.

I think the general thrust, the philosophical concept, behind the legislation is flawed, and it does not do anything to achieve the objective of giving people better information on which to make business decisions. All it does is put somebody else in their place, somebody else they can blame. At the end of the day this country, be it in business or otherwise, will only succeed when Australians are willing to take responsibility for themselves.

If I may address a comment to the gallery through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, I say to the students who are watching today that this is very important. We all have to be responsible for ourselves, and legislation which undermines the principle of self-responsibility is, I believe, bad legislation for the country. I believe that we can rectify this problem but that it does need to go to a Senate committee. It needs proper examination, and the small business sector of this country needs to have confidence that its concerns will be addressed by this parliament at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the title of the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill suggests, it is the first bill to emerge from the government's corporate law simplification program, which was announced in the 1993 budget. The program began quite well with the appointment of the simplification task force—a task force that was made up of many specialists in plain English and in corporate law and parliamentary draftsmen. It undertook a consultative process with extensive community consultations and distributed its findings far and wide amongst the public inviting public comment.

PARA.TAB: Following the work of the task force, the bill was referred to the committee to which I belong, the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. It was referred after the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) on 8 February 1995 in the House of Representatives. The committee sought public response from many bodies representing those that would be interested in corporate law and we undertook many public hearings. As the Senate can see, there has been, generally speaking, a thorough, properly canvassed and balanced undertaking by the government and the parliament to hear as many views as possible.

Generally speaking, it has been accepted that the bill, in its entirety, is a step forward in simplifying corporate law. But as has been properly announced by this side of the house, there are, nevertheless, still many controversial and very hard to accept propositions contained within it. The main objection relates to the proposed change to the law for the proprietary companies—the distinction between exempt proprietary and non-exempt proprietary companies is now to be removed.

The stated effect of this change is to eliminate the current requirement on small companies to prepare financial reports for filing with the Australian Securities Commission. The bill contains those all-important three criteria. There is now a new distinction between large and small proprietary companies, based on the company's gross operating revenue not to exceed $10 million, assets not to exceed $5 million, and the number of employees to be 50 or more. Should a company meet any two of these three requirements, it is obliged to submit fully audited accounts.

In fact, it is this arbitrary definition of small and large that is in dispute, particularly as it will place an extra financial burden on the companies once exempt but which now fall within the category of large. Those companies now deemed to be large have previously had no need, nor any want, to produce costly audited accounts. Neither shareholders nor the public had any use for these audited accounts, nor will they in the future.

As has been stated by previous speakers, the Australian Chamber of Commerce has put together the estimated costs, on average no doubt, of what the new audit requirements will impose—it is between $25,000 and $40,000 per company. Many of these companies are family companies for which there would be no public benefit in undertaking a costly audit procedure. The Chamber of Commerce highlights the motor trades as being one area that will be particularly affected.

With that $25,000 to $40,000, it can be argued that you could start from a benchmark of about $12,000, but that would still be an added cost of $12,000 for the smallest companies. However, $12,000 would be a more reliable figure for the smallest companies—those fish and chip shops that Senator O'Chee spoke about and the very small bread shops. Those small businesses would face an additional audit cost of around $12,000, but that would be $12,000 that they would not have and an unnecessary $12,000.

The corporations and securities committee undoubtedly found the question very difficult to resolve and they spent a great deal of time pondering the matter. In fact, they even conceded that the small versus large test is as arbitrary a test as the other options put forward. Nevertheless, they finally recommended that the small versus large test be given preference, particularly as there is a perceived safety net for the small versus large test as they saw it. That perceived safety net is: firstly, there is an ASC discretion, both to require a small company to prepare accounts and to relieve large companies of reporting requirements—so the ASC can step in either side of that grey area; and, secondly, company members will be able, by virtue of the provisions which allow five per cent of the shareholders to do so, to require a small company to prepare accounts. So that was their idea of a safety net. It probably finally convinced them to recommend the most arbitrary test of small versus large.

As Senator O'Chee so graciously pointed out, I have tabled my own dissenting report in the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities report on this key matter, rejecting the so-called small versus large test applied to reporting entities.

It is also a matter of objection by the powerful representative bodies of: the Institute of Chartered Accountants; the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants; and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. During the committee hearing I judged a more compelling case was put forward by the accounting bodies to support the reporting entity test over the small versus large test. The reporting entity test is defined as, and is, Australian accounting standard 1025. So it already exists in accounting standards and the Corporations Law, and was put forward as the preference of the accounting bodies. The reporting entity test is defined as an entity:

SPEECH.PARA: in respect of which it is reasonable to expect the existence of users dependent on general purpose financial reports for information which will be useful to them for making and evaluating decisions about the allocation of scarce resources, and includes but is not limited to the following:
(a) a listed corporation;
(b) a borrowing corporation;

Albeit arbitrary, as a far more accepted and understood test not only in the marketplace but in the Corporations Law as it stands and as an accounting standard, it seems infinitely more acceptable to the marketplace.

PARA.TAB: My support for the reporting entity test is substantially based on the fact that: firstly, the test is a well-established and accepted accounting standard; and, secondly, it is simpler or at least no more arbitrary than the small versus large test, given the three required size factors, namely, gross assets, revenue and employment are extremely arbitrary—and, as pointed out by Senator Baume, the asset valuation can easily be manipulated. For example, the directors' valuations at best are never reliable—they can be based on historical factors and not current values, and all this can place it under the threshold of $5 million.

If you were to seek an independent valuation of your assets—the most up-to-date valuation undertaken by a real estate firm—it would cost you another $10,000 to $12,000. That would enable you to meet the auditing requirement which would cost you another $10,000 to $12,000 or more. The costs are piling up.

What about revaluations from year to year as your assets gyrate up and down in this most uncertain marketplace? One year you are producing audited accounts and the next year you are not. What is the benefit of an audited account if it has no continuity? One year you seek to pick up the audited accounts and they are not there because the directors have fallen under the threshold. This ludicrous situation can occur.

The second criteria concerns the employment factor, and this is the most ludicrous of all. It is very hard to understand exactly how this is going to work because that has never been spelt out. The factor of 50 employees or more will defer employment. If you have 48 or 49 employees—just under the 50 benchmark—are you really going to employ that extra person, or those extra two or three people? If you do, the moment you employ one extra person at an average salary of $15,000 to $18,000 you hit the threshold of 50 employees and that is another cost that you will have to audit to your accounts. That extra person will not only cost you his salary or wage, but he will cost you the auditor's fee of between $12,000 and $14,000.

It is going to be very difficult for small business to make the decision to employ that one extra person because the business simply hits the 50 threshold and has to go into auditing accounts. It is detrimental to employment. This is a key matter in the legislation that has not been properly tackled by the government. The government has tried to snuff out any controversial public comment on the matter by seducing the lobby groups by dealing only with them and leading them on to believe that they would get a proper result, but dumping them at the last moment. How these lobby groups and representatives of small business were hooked on this matter is bewildering. I thought they would have shown a bit more experience in dealing with the government on small business matters.

Perhaps the small business representatives have spent too long in Canberra and have forgotten just how this government treats small business and the Australian public. The government has lied to small business and to the Australian public many times over. We are now in a situation where we have to try and save them. We do that by supporting Senator Vanstone's proposed amendment to send this matter to a Friday committee where we can further scrutinise this very important matter in relation to small and large businesses.

Having outlined the main concerns I restate that, generally speaking, there is no doubt that this bill as a whole is significant to the Corporations Law and is generally supported. I urge the Australian Democrats and the Greens to support Senator Vanstone's proposed amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been clearly stated by a number of people contributing to this debate, the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill simplifies the provisions in the corporate law on share buybacks, proprietary companies and company registers. In each area the bill achieves significant simplification of the text of the law. It also simplifies the substance of the rules, eliminating unnecessary or redundant regulations. It is the first bill in the corporate law simplification program. There may be three or four more bills over the next few years.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps I could pick up on some of the points raised by speakers during the debate and make some comments in response. I will conclude my remarks with more general comments on the bill. This might assist the opposition.

In relation to Senator Margetts's proposed amendment, I make the point that the government appreciates the withdrawal of that amendment, which was strictly not relevant to the bill. The concerns raised by Senator Margetts at least need to be addressed. I can assure the Senate that the government is already considering a recommendation of the council of the OECD on bribery in international business transactions.

The recommendation calls on member countries to, amongst other things, consider taking a range of domestic measures relating to civil, criminal and taxation issues with a view to preventing bribery of foreign public officials in connection with international business transactions. The government responded to the recommendation by establishing an interdepartmental committee last year which is chaired by representatives from the Attorney-General's Department.

The committee has been asked to prepare a submission to the government on what Australia's response to the OECD recommendation should be. As part of the process the committee is consulting with key business and other interest groups. It is expected that the committee will report to the government later this year. I hope that assists Senator Margetts.

I will turn to a couple of points raised by Senator Baume. Senator Baume stated that large companies could be restructured to avoid the audit obligation. It is an interesting concern, particularly in the light of what Senator McGauran has just been saying about companies refusing to get bigger so that they avoid the audit obligation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Different people think different ways, Senator.

—Thank you for that very insightful assistance. I am not really fond of abuse across the chamber. The bill contains a sized test for assets and revenue which requires that they be consolidated. This is to be done in accordance with the relevant accounting standards. It therefore requires a consolidation of assets and revenue of all entities which are controlled by the company in question. The nature and scope of this accounting standard on control are properly matters for the Accounting Standards Board, which is responsible for making these standards.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume also referred to the massive lack of commercial experience in preparing this bill. The bill was prepared by a four-person task force which included a private practitioner who was experienced in commercial law. It was also discussed with the Attorney-General's private sector consultative group, which includes representatives of small and large business. In addition, the criteria are based on comparable tests used in the United Kingdom and Ontario.

Senator Spindler queried whether the abolition of various company registers would prejudice people being able to access information about companies. For Senator Spindler's edification, the information on these registers is either unnecessary or will be readily available from the ASC. Business and professional advisers are increasingly finding that the ASC is a convenient means of obtaining information about companies.

While I think it is very important that professional people have access to that information, I am sure that Senator Spindler appreciates the concern I have that ordinary citizens have access to that information. My advice is that there will be either the same or easier access to that information through the ASC. We should feel comforted to know that information will not be less accessible.

This bill actually contains significant improvements to the law on share buy-backs, company registers and proprietary companies. The changes will greatly assist Australian business, especially small business. Many of the changes, and the plain English drafting of the bill, have been welcomed by the Senate.

The delay in the introduction of the bill has been a matter of concern to the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and the government. Business and professional advisers are keenly awaiting a number of the changes to be introduced with this bill. They include: the possibility for companies to set up with one director and one member; the introduction of streamlined rules for companies to buy back their own shares; the abolition of AGMs for proprietary companies; the removal of requirements to keep various company registers; and the removal of the requirement for small proprietary companies to prepare accounts.

Already the delay in the passage has meant that most of Australia's 900,000 proprietary companies will have to lodge key financial data with the ASC for another year, which is an unnecessary and wasteful obligation. In the debate on this bill, opposition senators raised a supposedly new concern about an obligation under the bill for large proprietary companies to have their accounts audited. It is the government's view that this is an appropriate obligation in view of the economic significance of the companies. They are often major trading enterprises with significant employers and numerous trade creditors. An audit gives a level of assurance about their financial position. The ASC does have a discretion to relieve companies of this obligation in hard cases—and I will comment about that in a moment.

The concerns raised by some business organisations are nothing more than special pleading. It is not surprising that the companies affected do not want a new obligation imposed upon them; indeed, it would be surprising if they did. The question that needs to be answered is whether this obligation is in the public interest.

It is worth looking at a few facts. Companies which are caught by the new obligation are in fact substantial businesses and not by any means small. They have to satisfy at least two of three criteria: assets of at least $5 million, revenue of at least $10 million, and 50 or more employees. These figures were the subject of substantial consultation. They were first released in a proposal by the simplification task force in March 1994. They were included in a draft bill released for three months comment in July 1994. They were in the bill as introduced into parliament last December. They were examined by the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, and its report on the bill was tabled in March 1995.

The consultation process did not provide any justification for changing the figures. A range of views was expressed, with some suggestions that they were too low as well as some suggestions that they were too high. The parliamentary committee did not recommend that they be changed, although it did ask the Attorney-General to look in particular at the use of the employee criteria. This was done and the Attorney-General indicated that he did not propose to make any change at this stage, although he did give a commitment to keep them under review.

It is worth noting that the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry wrote to the parliamentary committee at the time of its review. The ACCI stated that while the figures were arbitrary they supported the bill and did not believe there was any reason to delay passage.

The position in comparable overseas jurisdictions also supports the view that the audit requirement is not unreasonable. In Ontario, a company is subject to an audit obligation if its assets are $Can2.5 million, or if its gross operating revenues are $Can5 million. In the UK, a company is subject to an audit obligation if it meets certain criteria based on operating revenue, assets and employees. The asset and revenue criteria are in fact much lower than those in the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill.

Let us look at industry claims that they are being unfairly treated. No new information has been produced. On the best information available, it has been estimated that only two per cent of companies will be subject to this obligation. That is a very small proportion of proprietary companies. Those figures have not been challenged.

A number of misleading claims have been made by the industry. It has been suggested the bill would have unintended consequences, whereas the effects of the bill are well known. The estimated cost of an average audit being $25,000 to $40,000 is massively exaggerated. It has been suggested that the ASC would not have a discretion to deal with special circumstances where an audit might not be justified. The ASC already has a wide discretion to exempt a company from accounting and auditing obligations where compliance would give rise to an unreasonable burden on the company. The issue has been raised with the ASC in the context of a new audit obligation. The ASC has indicated it would be prepared to look sympathetically at granting exemptions which did not cut across the intention of the legislation.

In applying the unreasonable burden test, the ASC has indicated that it would look at whether the public benefit in disclosure of audited accounts would be outweighed by the costs incurred. It has also been suggested, according to Senator Vanstone, that somehow the relevant business groups were misled into believing their concerns would be addressed by a government sponsored amendment. This is simply not the case.

Two meetings and several telephone discussions were held, at which concerns were discussed in detail. An undertaking was given that issues raised would be considered and reported to the Attorney-General. This undertaking was met. Furthermore, in light of the concerns raised about the ASC discretion, the chairman of the ASC was contacted to obtain clarification of their position. The view of the chairman was conveyed to the representative of the industry groups, and he indicated that this was a very positive development. In essence, nothing raised by the industry groups justifies a further review or any further delay. However, it seems that the special pleadings seems to have worked for the time being.

If the issue of the size criteria is to be referred to a committee, it would make sense for that to be the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. The committee has a statutory function to look at the operation of the Corporations Law and proposed amendments. It is familiar with this bill and the issues raised by small-large distinction. I understand the chairman of the committee has indicated that the committee would be able to look at the matter in a timely manner. I thank senators for their contribution to the debate. I hope the points of query raised during the second reading stage have been answered. I think it should be very clear that the government sees no need for this reference. If it is going to happen, we would prefer that it go to the joint committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As foreshadowed in my speech at the second reading stage, I wish to add at the end of the motion that the bill be read a second time the words `but that items 1 to 4 inclusive of schedule 4 of the bill be referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for inquiry and report on or before Monday 28 August 1995'. I understand that Senator Spindler has a concern with that. He wants it to go to another committee. I think he wants this amended to make some changes to the reporting date because he may not know what the other committee can do. I move:

PARA.TAB: At the end of motion, add "but that items 1 to 4, inclusive of Schedule 4 of the bill be referred to the Legal and Consitutional Legislation Committee for inquiry and report on or before Monday, 28 August 1995.".

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Democrats are supportive of the substance of the motion. We believe the matter needs to be looked at again. I do not think it is an answer for the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) to say that it has been through the committee and everything has been looked at. I think it is incumbent upon us to ensure that the legislation we pass is sensible. While I make no commitment on behalf of the Democrats as to the substance of what is being put forward by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, I believe that a case has been made out for that issue to be looked at again. As Senator Vanstone indicated, I have discussed it with her.

PARA.TAB: I have concerns about the bill going to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. The committee is absolutely overloaded. It is getting a number of bills referred to it right now. I think it makes more sense for that particular reference to be given to the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities because that committee has dealt with it. The secretariat of the committee is familiar with the matters that we are dealing with. I move:
Omit "Legal and Consititional Legislation Committee", substitute "Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities".

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—My party feels very strongly that this needs to be done. We do not want to hold this bill up. It is only one limited aspect of the bill that we want reviewed. It is an aspect the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has agreed needs to be held under review in the end, and we want it reviewed before the bill is passed. We feel reasonably strongly that it should go to the Senate committee, that they could do it this Friday and it could come back on Monday. I understand what Senator Spindler is after in this respect. I suggest that, since there seems to be an understanding that it has to go to one committee or another, we adjourn further discussion of this matter to a later hour this day when we can resolve the detail of it. It should take only a minute to bring it back on. We will not need advisers because in any event I suspect that it will go to a committee. Then we would get a sensible solution, rather than going for one or the other because we are here now. I do not think any work will be done between now and a later hour this day.
—I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Debate resumed from 28 November 1994, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you Mr—Madam Acting Deputy President. My apologies. There are so many men here—far too many men—and not enough women that it naturally flows from the tongue far too often to commence with the salutation, `Thank you Mr' when you really mean `Madam'.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—I agree with you, Senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to have you there. It is a pleasure too for this Racial Hatred Bill to finally come on. Some members of the government—not the least of whom is the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch)—have been trying to portray the view and create an impression in the ethnic communities around Australia that the coalition did not want to discuss this bill. There was only one occasion when we asked for this bill to be adjourned. We asked for it to be adjourned until the following week—which it was. But, sadly, it was always on the bottom of the pile—at least it never got to the top of the pile.

PARA.TAB: I am sure all senators and members have had the experience of coming into this place prepared to debate a bill and finding for one or other reason that it does not come on. That is what has happened with this piece of legislation. I am very pleased that finally the Attorney has managed to convince his colleagues of what he should have convinced them all along, and that is that this matter should be dealt with.

I would like to make it very clear from the beginning—just in case anyone was in any doubt and thought they might set the tone of this debate in another way—that this debate is not about who is more opposed to racial hatred. I do not believe even the most base personality opposite could suggest that—

TALK.START.PARA: —There are none, Senator.

—I used a relative term, Minister, `the most base'. It does not mean they are very base; it just means the most base. I do not believe even the most base personality opposite could suggest that there are people on this side who are actually in favour of racial hatred, who are in favour of people deliberately setting out to upset and demean others simply because of their race or, for that matter, because of their religion, how they look or whatever else. It just does not jell. This bill is not about who is more opposed to racial hatred. It is not a contest—a breast-beating contest—to see who can proclaim most loudly that they are opposed to something that I would expect every member of the federal parliament would be opposed to. I say, without any doubt in my mind, that there would not be a federal member of parliament who would say, or in the heart of hearts believe, that they are in favour of racial hatred.

PARA.TAB: This bill is about the best way to deal with any examples of racial hatred that we see in the community. What is to be done about it? None of us like it. What is to be done? Is there something that the Commonwealth ought to be doing? That is what this bill is about. It is equally, as I say, not about who is more welcoming of a multicultural society or who welcomes migrants more into this country. My party—contrary to what some members opposite would seek to portray in the communities—has a very proud record in this respect.

Going back to the 1960s—nearly a third of a century ago but, nonetheless, I was alive then—it was a coalition government that abolished the very abhorrent White Australia policy. That decision led to a very welcome inflow of many people from a wide range of ethnic and racial backgrounds. It was a Liberal government that established the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs and SBS TV, and introduced a very wide range of multicultural settlement services that today remain the basis of Australia's multicultural policies.

It was a coalition government that welcomed to Australia the first boat people from South East Asia in the late 1970s and the early 1980s and, as many will remember here, against the strident opposition of some of my colleagues opposite, certainly of the Labor Party of the day. So this is not a contest—and I hope it does not develop into one; it should not be—about whose party is more in favour of multiculturalism, more opposed to racial hatred. It is about the best way to deal with the ugly examples of racial hatred that we face from time to time.

We have said—and the government has yet to match this commitment—that we believe the best way to deal with these ugly incidents is an education campaign. We have been prepared to commit $10 million towards such an education campaign. We are surprised the government has not stepped in and agreed with that proposal as a sensible way to proceed. After all, in one of the other very important areas that you have an interest in, Madam Acting Deputy President, domestic violence, the value of education campaigns is clearly understood and supported on all sides. So there is no doubt about the value of an education campaign as a policy tool to implement change, to try to deal with racism when it rears its ugly head. We have been prepared to make that commitment. We look forward to the government finally admitting—hopefully sooner rather than later—that it supports such a commitment.

But the government seems hell-bent on believing that its way is the only way to proceed, and that is by way of a racial hatred bill. The bill was not available to us until just before it was to be introduced, despite the fact the government wished to run the debate in the community. But once we saw the bill we had a good look at it and we made no bones about the fact that we would oppose it. We do not see this as the appropriate way to deal with and respond to those incidents in the community, which we are all repulsed by. We believe education is the appropriate way. But if there is to be a legislative sanction to add to the armoury to oppose this sort of behaviour then this is not it. This is not the appropriate way to do it.

There are two reasons that we oppose this bill. The first, and perhaps the most central, is the proposed new section 61. That section says that a person must not, with the intention of inciting racial hatred against another person or a group of people, do an act in private if the act is firstly reasonably likely in all circumstances to incite racial hatred against other persons or a group of people and is done because of the race, colour or national or ethnic origin of the other person or of some or all of the people in the group. That criminal sanction says nothing about associating violence with hatred. It makes it a criminal sanction for you to incite hatred in another even though you are not encouraging them to act in any violent way.

You hate a particular group yourself for one of a myriad of reasons, you believe it is justified and you want to pass that on. You want others to agree with you. You are encouraging them to agree with you. You are inviting them to share your hatred. But you are not the sort of person who would go and burn down a picket fence or bash someone in the face and you do not want to encourage anyone else to do that. You want them to understand why you hate this group of people, why you feel that way. This is very much associated with feelings. You want them to feel the same way too. For that, this government will put you in gaol for up to one year. We say that is wrong; it is a limitation on freedom of speech.

We all understand that free speech is not entirely free. There are already some sanctions. So let us not pretend that by saying we are supporters of free speech we are somehow ignorant and think that speech is always completely free. We understand that there are limitations on speech. But we think you have to be very careful when you add to those limitations. This government was happy to introduce a bill to ban political advertising, which is the most useful way to share views at the time of elections about what one party or another is doing. It is an essential part of the political process. The government that proposed this bill was happy to ban that freedom of speech and put an extra limit on it because it was just damned well inconvenient. The High Court chucked out that bill and said that it was not on. You cannot limit speech in that way. It is essential to our system.

We understand that there are sometimes cases for limits to be made. Defamation laws are one example. But we say that this is not one. You should be able to, within the existing limits, say what you like. If it offends someone, but you do not incite people to violence, you should be able to say it. No law should try to engineer in your mind what you ought to think about another group, or make it a criminal sanction for you to feel a particular way, express that feeling and want others to agree with you. We say that that is wrong. It is social engineering at its worst, and it is a most unnecessary limitation on freedom of speech. For that reason, we will not support the government's composition of criminal sanctions.

The bill also has civil sanctions which we do not support for a number of reasons. The government has had its problems with civil sanctions in other bills as a consequence of the Brandy decision. The states are now moving to implement their own civil sanctions. They do not have the same separation of powers problems that we have. We think it is time to reflect on the degree to which we keep adding to that list of activities. If you undertake them, you can find yourself getting a letter saying that someone wants to drag you off to one tribunal or another. Let us not take that out of perspective. Let us not suggest that we are saying that consultative tribunals are not a useful way to resolve disputes. Take it exactly as it is. We are concerned about the rate at which we are doing that. We think we need to pause before we continue to do it.

We also think that, in any event, the drafting of that civil sanction is in itself peculiarly broad. You could find yourself dragged off to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to explain yourself. If you are a normal citizen who does not have lawyers in the family or friends who are lawyers and you get such a letter, you think, `Hell. What is happening here?' You get some legal advice. While we might understand the conciliatory nature of some of these proceedings, a lot of normal citizens are not so informed. So they get legal advice.

What about doing an act that is likely in all the circumstances to offend or insult someone. It goes on to deal with acts that humiliate or intimidate. I see that there are school children in the galleries. I remember that when I was at school people offended me every other day. I probably said things that offended others. It is still happening and it will go on happening. To suggest that, because someone says something you find offensive, you should be able to run off to the human rights commission is breathtaking. What offends one person may be water off a duck's back to another. There is no objective standard here. If it is to be reasonably likely in all the circumstances, it must relate back to that person. We are unsatisfied with the civil sanctions. We think the criminal sanction is appallingly drafted. For that reason, we have put out our own exposure draft.

Our exposure draft shows the government the fashion in which it should have proceeded. Our exposure draft creates a criminal sanction for inciting hatred, but it associates the incitement to hatred with violence. No-one likes people hating. It is just a part of life and you go through it. Every now and then, something happens and you hate it. You meet someone who you do not like. You may get to the point of hating them. Hate is not a good thing, but it is a part of life. We have to learn how to handle it.

When we get to the stage of acting or wanting to act on hate—when you punch someone in the face or incite someone else to do that or you want to burn down their house, picket fence or garden—and causing someone else physical harm to their person or their property, and you encourage others to do that, that behaviour should be the subject of a criminal sanction. The limitation is not just on expressing your view but on starting to encourage other people to do nasty things to people, such as damage their property or person. You are encouraging by your words some action to result from that.

We wholeheartedly agree that that kind of behaviour should be the subject of a criminal sanction. For our exposure draft we chose to follow very closely the legislation in New South Wales, which by all accounts has worked very well. We think that that is the appropriate criminal sanction to have: not one that bans free speech full stop but one that bans speech that incites violence against property or person. That is where to draw the line in this matter.

As I have indicated earlier, we do not agree with the civil remedies as drafted by the government. We are a bit apprehensive about them. We are pleased the states are moving to do as they choose in that respect and, for that reason, we did not choose to include in our exposure draft the civil remedies that are included in the state legislation.

There is an enormous amount of breast beating going on in this area by some of my colleagues opposite determined to show that they are opposed to racial hatred. As I said, we too are opposed to racial hatred, but we believe the way to do it is by a sensible education campaign. We have been prepared to commit $10 million towards that and we look forward to the government agreeing to match that commitment.

To the extent that a legislative sanction is required, we believe that legislative sanction should be limited to speech which encourages and incites violence. That you should not be allowed to do, but you should be allowed to make a speech which expresses your own view, repulsive as it might be—a view of hatred and encouraging others to agree with you—without going to gaol.

I wanted to end by coming to that point, highlighting that we are opposed to a straight limitation on freedom of speech. Speech which is not inciting violence, we think, you ought to be able to proceed with. That is why in our exposure draft we have chosen to have a criminal sanction which would put in goal people who incite hatred on the basis of racial grounds, and put them in the gaol for quite a bit longer than this government would. There are much tougher sanctions in our bill.

That is not the only reason I chose to end on this. Sadly, in the community there has been by accident or design—and I certainly hope it is accident—some very misleading information about the government's bill. I personally feel the Attorney would have done himself some credit if he had chosen to clear up those misunderstandings, because they are misunderstandings—as I said, created by accident or design—by people who ought to know better, who are out there bagging my party every other day on this issue and who are holding themselves out to the ethnic communities as people who are informed. I do not mind people doing that. If you think you have something to say, you reckon you know about it and you can help others by informing them, well and good; but do not do that if you either have not bothered to inform yourself or are deliberately seeking to deceive.

Many of you will have heard the name Victor Rebikoff on the radio every other day in this place and heard him getting stuck into my party for our position. Mr Rebikoff had this to say about the government's bill:

SPEECH.PARA: The real important fact of the racial hatred bill before the parliament is that the end result of criminal sanctions really only applies where racial incitement leads to bodily injury or property damage—that's the bottom line.

That is just untrue. The government's criminal sanction, the proposed new section 60, can lead you to a criminal sanction, can send you to gaol, even though you are not encouraging any physical damage to property or person.

PARA.TAB: Mr Rebikoff has simply not told the truth. Maybe he misunderstood. Maybe he was misinformed. But someone in his position should not rush out to the airwaves, purport to speak for the ethnic communities around Australia, and get it so badly wrong. Helene Teischman, who acts as the secretariat to the Ethnic Coalition of Australia, does exactly the same. In a transcript of interview, six, seven, eight, nine, 10—possibly 11—times she creates the impression that people should not worry about the government's bill; that they should go for it because it will only get at people who incite hatred that leads to violence. That is rubbish. If she did not know then, she must know now that the government's Racial Hatred Bill would put in gaol people who incite hatred even if it is not associated in any way whatsoever with violence. For people who purport to lead a community to mislead that community by accident or design is a disgrace.
The real question is the appropriate way to handle this hatred. We think it is by education and by an exposure draft that does not limit freedom of speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are those in the community who through their words and actions would do harm to others on the grounds of their race, colour or national or ethnic origins. This Racial Hatred Bill provides both criminal and civil remedies to meet this evil. It has been promised wide support, but also strong opposition, in this chamber. I hope that in the end it becomes law.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite argue that this legislation is not needed; that there are better ways of dealing with the problem it seeks to address; that it might make matters worse; that it unduly restricts the freedom of speech; and that it is too clumsy an instrument to achieve its purpose.

Parliament ought to vote down legislation which if passed would unduly constrain people from doing what they will. It ought to reject bills which if enacted would do more harm than good. It ought to avoid making laws which achieve no purpose. But, if the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth require that parliament proscribe conduct of a particular kind, it should do so.

By the end of this debate many senators will have spoken on this bill. They will have set out the arguments for and against its passing. They will have shown that we as legislators must balance valid but competing factors in reaching a right conclusion. Then will come the decision as to whether the legislation will be allowed or refused passage.

This bill ought to be passed. The arguments in favour of our doing so far outweigh those to the contrary. It is needed to reinforce Australia's integrity as a multicultural nation, to assure members of the community that they can go about their affairs confidently and freely, to rein in the rampages of hate and to show all people, whether here or overseas, the standards we aspire to live by.

Australia's destiny has made her a multicultural society. She became so when a myriad of influences from around the world entwined themselves around each other within her shores. Even were it right to do so, it is now impossible to undo this fusion. It is therefore essential for the wellbeing of each and every one who lives in this country that all its inhabitants are assured of its commitment to their true interests. When as a nation we embrace the qualities of communal cohesion, generosity, equality, justice, compassion and equity, we go a long way to ensuring this.

The legislation of a democracy such as Australia shows those values in which it places store. Australian criminal law attends to a range of wayward actions. In my judgment, ill-doing invoked by racial hatred is a greater threat to the community than many others.

It is instructive to look at what the parliaments of this country have made criminal. In Western Australia, a person `who, not being a member of either House of Parliament, unlawfully publishes any false or scandalous defamatory matter touching the conduct of any member or members of either House of Parliament as such member or members is guilty of a misdemeanour and is liable to imprisonment for 2 years and to a fine of $1,000'.

Similar laws apply in other Australian jurisdictions. In Queensland, your state, Mr Acting Deputy President Herron, which you so well represent, any person `who, without such justification or excuse as would be sufficient in the case of the defamation of a private person, publishes anything intended to be read, or any sign or visible representation, tending to expose to hatred or contempt in the estimation of the people of any Foreign State, any Prince or person exercising sovereign authority over that State, is guilty of a misdemeanour and is liable to imprisonment for two years'.

Society would have interesting values were it to punish its citizens for publishing material prejudicial to the reputation of politicians and foreign potentates but allows them to harm their compatriots for racial reasons. In New South Wales it is a crime to wilfully enter upon any part of a fountain erected in a public place. In South Australia the same is the case where a person who, without the authority of the occupier of the land on which animals are kept in the course of primary production, unfastens and leaves unfastened a gate on or leading to the land. In Victoria any person who wilfully and without lawful justification or excuse, the proof of which lies on him or her, disquiets any meeting of persons lawfully assembled for religious worship, can be gaoled for up to three months. Are these three actions more heinous than those of threatening to cause harm to a person because of his or her race, colour, or national or ethnic origin?

Turning to the civil parts of this legislation, people can be sued in the civil courts for giving negligent advice, for failing to explain fully the possible consequences of a medical procedure, for telling people to go on strike and for urging them to breach a contract of employment. Are those actions inherently more injurious to people than an abusive attack on them because of their race, colour, or national or ethnic origin?

A reading of Hansard will show many and persistent points of order taken during question time in this chamber. Senators have protested with proper indignation that they, members of their particular party or indeed other persons have been subject to oral abuse. It would be a happy event were the Senate to pass legislation which looks to the welfare of people vulnerable to verbal attacks because of their race, colour, or national or ethnic origin.

This legislation deals with big issues. Laws against racial hatred are needed to underpin a fair and benevolent society, an apt Australian identity and a proper Australian nationalism. We should curb conduct which would fracture the integrity of those things. Defining particular groups within a community and allowing one to assail another risks social disorder.

What is happening in the old Yugoslavia is a dramatic example of how this can produce national chaos. The problems of varying intensity in Burma, Fiji, Germany, Indonesia, Ireland, Israel, Russia, Sri Lanka, Turkey and the United States also illustrate the point. Were all the people in each of these countries assured a fair, respected, secure and dignified place in society, much of the tension within their respective communities would abate. Someone driven by racial malice who threatens to harm person or property can throw unwarranted strain on a multicultural society. Legislation ought make clear that such conduct is wrong. This bill does that.

The wider the range of people who feel they have a full stake in the country they live in, the more likely they are to hold together as a nation where there is peace, order and good government. This is what the founders of the Commonwealth intended and what its citizens have sought since its establishment. The greater the peace, order and good government of a country, the better for all who reside in it. In any community, the better the life of the weak, the poor, the disadvantaged, the plain and the different, the better the life of the strong, the rich, the advantaged, the glamorous and the mainstream. Where a society allows and even encourages its members to abuse their fellows on the grounds of race, it diminishes the force within it making for a worthy community. Nazi Germany is the most graphic example of this in the 20th century. What is now happening in old Yugoslavia, in Sri Lanka and Turkey gives other examples.

That freedom of speech is needed for the right operation of a liberal and democratic society has been an axiom for a long time. The High Court has recently declared it basic to proper political debate in Australia. But, in doing so, the highest judicial body in this country set limits to its range. Sir Gerard Brennan, who is now the Chief Justice of the High Court, when giving his decision in Theophanous v Herald and Weekly Times Limited, said:

SPEECH.PARA: In law there is no absolute freedom to do anything that might affect another. Laws necessarily restrict absolute freedoms in order that all may live in a society of freedom under the law, by which we mean a society in which absolute freedoms are restricted in law to the extent that is thought appropriate to our history and culture.

Australia's history and culture has made it a multicultural society which its laws are obliged to keep viable and vibrant. It needs legislation to ensure that those within its shores who might be tempted to do so are inhibited from hurting others because of their race, colour, national or ethnic origin. And words can hurt. Why should this country condone people who give expression to racial hatred, which brings both fear and harm to those who as its citizens are entitled to look to it for the protection of their wellbeing.

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will now proceed to debate matters of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is a tremendous country and we have very energetic and enterprising people. In spite of the best efforts of this government to curtail that energy and enthusiasm, there are still a lot of people in Australia who are doing tremendous work for Australia and for Australia's position in the world in an economic sense. I take the opportunity today in this debate on matters of public interest to mention a couple of the enterprises that I had the opportunity to inspect during the parliamentary recess so as to make parliament aware of the good things that are happening in our country in spite of the best efforts of the Labor Party to curtail them.

PARA.TAB: Together with my Western Australian colleague Senator John Panizza, I had the opportunity to accept an invitation from the Western Australian and Northern Territory governments to inspect the Ord River scheme and what is happening in the Kununurra area. The extension of the Ord River project is a very exciting scheme. Those of my age would remember when, many years ago, the Menzies Liberal-Country Party government set up the Ord River scheme. It was at the time, and has been subsequently, the subject of cynicism and criticism about it being enormously subsidised, but all of that is now behind the Ord River project.

In the last year, $35 million worth of agricultural exports were produced in the Ord River area and there are plans to double that production in the fairly near future. In the Ord River area, primary producers produce melons, chickpeas and all sorts of small crops. A wide variety of crops is grown in the area and, of course, producers have recently gone into a major expansion of Australia's sugar growing areas. Senator Panizza and I were conducted around the scheme by Mr Peter McCosker who is the project officer working for the Western Australian government. I also spoke with a Western Australian minister, Mr Monty House, about the plans that his government and the Northern Territory government have for this very significant area. It is a very exciting prospect. It is a project which I personally support and I would think that the coalition as a whole would be very keen to support the Western Australian and Northern Territory governments in that significant expansion.

Interestingly, I know that the two state governments have invited a number of politicians up to that area to show them over the site. I said, `Well, what do you want from us? How much money are you seeking?' They indicated that they were not seeking any money at all. They simply want the federal government and federal parliamentarians to understand what is happening and to assist them in promoting the scheme. The biggest problem being faced by the Ord project is—would you believe—the native title legislation, and that problem is not just being experienced by the project organisers.

Aboriginal groups in the area who want to take part in the expansion simply do not know what their rights are: they do not know how to go through native title legislation and they do not know what they can do and what they cannot do. It is a complete mess. If I came back from the Ord with any underlying understanding of what is needed, it is that some clarification—from the viewpoints of both the Aboriginals and the project developers—of the native title legislation is essential. The government refuses to understand it, but the problem has to be addressed before the Ord can expand.

I am pleased to see that a Queensland hi-tech company is developing the new sugar mill in the Ord. I was also very interested to hear of the plans for the sugar industry in Western Australia. I come from the lower Burdekin district in Queensland which is, without argument, one of the best sugar growing areas in the world. In my former life as a solicitor in a small country town, I became aware of how the Queensland sugar industry has been established.

It is interesting that in the west they are looking at establishing a complete industry without any government regulation and not much government involvement. It will all be done by contractors, as I understand it. They have a rather different way of distributing the proceeds of the sugar crop—that is, different from what happens in Queensland and, I assume, New South Wales. They are proposing that, out of the total proceeds from the sale of the sugar crop, there will be a certain amount set aside to cover the base costs of the sugar growers. There will also be an amount set aside for harvesting costs and an amount set aside, as I understand the proposal, for the milling costs. Once those three components are paid out so that everyone gets their base costs, the balance—the profits, so to speak—will then be distributed between the millers and the growers on the basis of a proportion of their capital investment in the industry. That is different from the Queensland industry in that the division of crop proceeds is a continuing and running sore in the Queensland industry and it has been since time immemorial. It will be interesting to see how the Western Australian system works out.

I also saw, whilst visiting the Ord, what I think might be the first privately funded hydro scheme in Australia. It is being constructed by Civil and Civic and I think Lend Lease are the financiers of it. It is a very interesting project. Private enterprise is building the hydro project and it is also providing a lot of jobs. As I understand it, they are to reticulate and sell the electricity produced at a much cheaper cost than has been provided anywhere else in Australia in the past. So exciting things are happening there. I also understand that the water distribution system in the Ord area is shortly to be privatised, with the farmers co-op taking on the distribution of water from the Ord Dam.

There were a lot of other exciting things about the Ord and the north-west that we were privileged to see. It is certainly a project that I think deserves the support of this parliament and of all parliamentarians. If the government could do its bit by clarifying the native title legislation, I think we would have a real asset to Australia's economic position in the north-west of Western Australia.

During the recess, I was also privileged, at the invitation of my colleague Mr Michael Ronaldson—the very well-regarded and, I am quite sure, long-term member for the electorate of Ballarat—to visit his area and talk to a number of small businesses in the Ballarat area. I want to highlight that there are industries around Australia which, in spite of this government's failures, are doing well through innovation, through good management and through good work practices. Everywhere I went in the recess—and I travelled quite widely—speaking to small businessmen the same thing came up time and time again: `Can you get the Labor Party to fix that unfair dismissals legislation? Can you get them to fix the industrial relations legislation? Can you get them to get off the backs of small business and to stop taxing us to death? If you do that, we don't want any assistance; we will go out and do it for Australia.'

Whilst in Ballarat, I was very pleased to be taken to see what is happening at Miric Industries in Ballarat. It is a very innovative and forward looking company that was established some time ago by Mr Milton Schultz, a very energetic man with great vision and great foresight. It is now being run by his son, Mr Rick Schultz. It involves metal pressing, wire components, and plant manufacturing for the automotive, white goods, building and electronics industries. It is a very good company that has been in business for 20 years. It has a staff of 28 and a turnover of $2 million plus.

Recently this company actually took on a new enterprise. The owner said, `Look, I don't want to be beholden to the international or multinational automotive companies all my life, I want to look at something that I can sell directly to the public.' He looked around. He had had some involvement with horseracing and he remembered that the farriers used to tell him that horseshoe nails were difficult to get, not of a good quality and expensive and supply was pretty erratic. So he decided to set up his own horseshoe nail factory within his business. As I recall what he told me—would you believe—only one other company in the world is doing this, an American company. This Australian company now exports to New Zealand, it exports to America, it has orders that it cannot fill, it is tremendously innovative and it already—it only started in January—has five additional workers employed.

Here is a company with good management. This Australian went out and thought about it, thought about the market. He now produces these horseshoe nails, as I recall, 30 per cent cheaper than the American version, and of better quality. He does this, I might say, having to pay 30 per cent more for the steel he uses than the American company.

I say this with some hesitation because no-one likes to criticise the big Australian: in this plant and a couple of others I went to during the recess, there was some criticism of BHP and the way this government organises things, that overseas countries could buy BHP steel cheaper than Australian companies. This horseshoe nail factory has to pay more for its Australian steel than its competitor in America pays. But it can still produce a better and cheaper product and is a great credit to Australian manufacturing.

The other place that I visited during the recess in my capacity as shadow minister for regional development and infrastructure was in Dubbo, at the request of my friend and colleague Mr Michael Cobb, the member for Parkes. He took me to a place called Fletcher International Exports, run by Mr Roger Fletcher and his wife. It is a tremendous plant, with over 500 people employed there. It is a mutton abattoir. They kill the sheep and export the mutton. They do not sell any of it in Australia, as I recall. All of it goes overseas. He has more markets than he can supply. He employs over 500 people and has a tremendous business.

Mr Fletcher is a very interesting person. I think a lot of parliamentarians have met him. Again, he is one of those who do not want any help from governments, except for governments to get off his back and he will do the rest. Boy, oh, boy, if you look at his factory you can just see what he could do for Australia. He has a wool scourer and does fellmongering work. I am no expert on the wool and sheep industry, and that would be fairly obvious from what I say, but looking through that plant it is just tremendous the way he has set it up, the industrial relations he and his wife have organised with the people that work for them and the tremendous output and energy in that particular factory.

He has done a lot of things. I think he was proud to tell us he has no formal education. I think he said he used to be a drover. He now runs this international company that gets huge export dollars for Australia and does things that others have thought too difficult to do in Australia in the past.

With the fellmongering, he actually spins his own wool in a way that I understand is very, very new to Australia. He laments the fact that there is little or no tanning in Australia. He was telling us that his next project will be to use the sheep hides and have them tanned to make another fabulous new export industry for Australia.

That plant is an example, as is the one I saw in Ballarat, of what Australians can do. So whilst at times we lament and despair what is happening in this country, we certainly understand that the Labor Party has no interest in and understanding of people and the innovation and energy in small business. But they are just two that I did want to talk about, and the experience in the north-west, that show that in spite of the efforts of this government there are Australians that are innovative, that have the energy, that are getting on with the job of earning big export dollars and creating real employment for Australians. If only the government could understand from that what needs to be done with small business, our country would get out of its one million unemployment problem and its balance of payments problems and we would all be a lot, lot better off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak about some issues that surround a proposal in Queensland to build a very large dam on the Dawson River near Taroom. If it is built at the particular place where at least one of the projections are for it to be built, it will be known as the Nathan dam. There is a lot of controversy surrounding this, and I do not come here today to necessarily put down what I think are the answers but certainly to raise the questions that are being raised by people in that area. The Australian Democrats have indicated for quite a long period of time their concerns about what is happening to the river systems of Australia. I noticed quite recently that the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Tim Fischer, expressed his concern about this, and I can only agree with that part of what he said which was in the media.

PARA.TAB: At the invitation of some of the people in that area, I did visit Taroom in July and spent a little over a day there. I walked down to the bottom of the Nathan Gorge to one of the proposed sites for the dam wall and visited a number of properties which would be affected if the dam was built at that site. In the evening I attended a meeting in Taroom at which there were over 40 people present. This had resulted from a very limited invitation to those people from an organisation known as LAND, Landholders Affected by Nathan dam. I understand, however, that a meeting had been held a few weeks prior to that one, convened by the United Graziers Association and the Cattlemen's Union, and that attracted over 100 people. At both meetings a lot of concern and, I think, opposition was expressed to the building of the Nathan dam on the particular site which is being proposed.

One of the concerns I have about this kind of development is the fact that it often divides people within communities, even divides communities one against the other and sometimes one group of land-holders against another group. In broad terms, I suppose, and in this instance, the people of Taroom who spoke to me are mostly graziers and agriculturalists. In some ways the dispute between them which could develop would be a dispute between their particular land use and the use of the land by, for example, rice growers further down the Dawson River and their need to irrigate their crop.

It seems to me a great tragedy that we have in Australia at times these kinds of disputes in which the very valid concerns of two groups of people seem to be unable to be reconciled, and you end up with one group of land users at loggerheads with another group of land users.
