The greater tragedy, however—and a very cynical exercise it would be—would be if government or bureaucrats sought to use the division between people as a way to push through either this development or any other development.

Some of the discussion about the particular project that I had heard earlier and prior to going to Taroom was that the land which would be inundated by siting the dam at this site was not agricultural land. I don't know how people got that information because certainly I visited and drove along river flats which were high quality black soil, suitable and being used at present for the growing of crops. These river flats would be, I understand, inundated if the particular dam was built. It seems rather short-sighted to me to project building a dam which would inundate good agricultural land so that we could thereby irrigate other agricultural land. There ought to be an alternative which would meet both needs.
The Taroom Shire Landcare Committee's submission on the impact of development options on Taroom Shire states:

SPEECH.PARA: Taroom Shire, at the head of the Valley—
that is, the Dawson Valley—
has much of the valley's best irrigable land—in fact 29,000 hectares above and below Taroom.

I do not know how much of the 29,000 hectares would be inundated, but some thousands of hectares have been mentioned. In fact, one of the figures which were quoted to me was that between 40,000 and 60,000 hectares of land could be inundated if the dam is built in the current preferred site. I find it hard to believe that the Taroom Shire, in particular, if it lost that amount of land through flooding, would gain from the proposal.

PARA.TAB: The underlying question about land use, which is raised by the dam, is that the development of a large dam on the Dawson River would open up the area for more intensive farming through irrigation. It is thought that would increase the population of the area. There is no doubt that we certainly need to return people to the inland areas of Australia, I have no argument with that, but I wonder if those results would follow from building a large dam such as that proposed. The experience around the world is that large agricultural development of this kind is increasingly being done by international agribusiness corporations rather than by family farmers. It is a matter of debate, then, as to whether this kind of agricultural development is the kind that Australia or Queensland needs.

One of the other possibilities for using the water from such a large dam is to supply new mining ventures in coal in the Wandoan area. I understand that Mount Isa Mines holds some leases over quite extensive coalfields, but there is a problem here as well. There is a debate going on, particularly in Mount Isa at the moment, about the increasing practice of mining companies, such as Mount Isa Mines, to service new mines by flying in employees from coastal cities rather than utilising local labour. This debate is certainly generating a lot of heat in Mount Isa. So one would have to wonder whether the building of a dam and supplying of water to open up mines in that area would, in fact, benefit the area locally.

Another concern which I have, of course, is the environment and there are many environmental issues raised by the building of large dams, particularly a large dam on the Dawson River at this site. The Taroom branch of the Wildlife Preservation Society has canvassed a lot of these in a submission it made to the Water Resources Commission, but just let me list them. I had never heard of bogamoss, or bogamosses, and I doubt whether many senators have either.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have.

—Senator O'Chee has. They are a mound spring that occurs in this particular area, and in other parts of Australia, but they are pretty rare. Although I had seen these in other parts of Australia, I had never heard them called bogamoss before. But that is what they are called in the Taroom area. Most of these are in the area which would be inundated if the Nathan dam was built on the projected site. So that certainly is a matter of great debate, and the debate surrounds the possibility that, associated with the bogamoss in that area, are some quite unique flora and fauna, some of which are already endangered.

PARA.TAB: There is also the question of transmission loss if water has to be transported over long distances, the problem of high chemical use in cotton growing and, apparently, an increase in seismic activity of between 5 and 10 per cent, which is associated with dams of this size. Most of the environmental problems would be minimised if any proposed water storage was confined within the present river bank levels.

The people in Taroom raised with me the fears that they have about compensation if the dam is built. It has been said to me that a number of land-holdings along the river have already been devalued because of rumours about the effect of the dam on properties. At the meeting which I attended, one person stated that she had been unable to borrow money from her bank to develop the property because it could be affected by the dam. It is valid to ask, because of the inevitable rumours which begin when such a project is on the drawing board, whether or not a process has begun which could result in increased land values for the areas to benefit from irrigation and decreased land values for the land which will be inundated.

I am also concerned about the implications of the Competition Policy Reform Bill, which we passed in this place some weeks ago. It seems to me that the debate is not just about appropriate sites for dams, water supply and end use. It is also a debate about who will ultimately control and profit from the building of a large dam and that is an even more important question. However, there are a number of alternatives and that is what impressed me. Those people I spoke to were not wanting to stop development in their area. They were not wanting simply to block the building of the dam. They understand that that country and most of Australia need more water and they were prepared to put forward a number of alternatives.

I am not sure whether these alternatives are viable but it is worth, I think, projecting that there are alternatives which ought to be looked at. These alternatives include: building a dam at the Baroondah site; building a much smaller dam in the Nathan Gorge but further downstream and including off-stream storage and weirs; or building further weirs on the Dawson River, but in sequence over a period of years so that the total cost would be incurred in manageable stages. The critical issue is that, whatever is built, it must deliver environmentally, socially and economically viable results.

Finally, let me say that one of the great concerns I have is that the water resources people, to date, have not responded to the Landholders Affected by Nathan Dam's `Response to the Dawson Valley Appraisal Study'. I believe that no further work should be done until that response is made and becomes part of the appropriate process of consultation with the people whose lives will be very deeply and significantly affected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon in the matter of public interest debate to once again express my very real concerns for the Tasmanian salmon industry and, of course, their employees. My concern is shared by the Liberal candidate for Lyons, Russell Anderson, the Liberal candidate for Franklin, Les Glover, and the Liberal candidate for Denison, Ingrid Wren.

PARA.TAB: The salmon industry in my home state is a new, developing, and exciting industry. It has substantial potential for growth. Currently, 2,000 people are employed because of the existence of this industry, often in those parts of my home state that suffer from severe unemployment because of Labor's bias against the outlying regions of this country. Economically, the industry is vital to Tasmania, producing about $100 million worth of product each year. Socially, the industry is vital with the employment that it provides, especially in the regional areas. Environmentally, it is an industry which we ought be encouraging. On every count, the aquaculture industry is one we ought be fostering and promoting.

Unfortunately, the industry is being threatened with extinction by the threat of imports from North America. The threat is not from economic competition, but from the diseases that these imports carry and will, sooner or later, infect the Tasmanian fish farms. Such an infection of the Tasmanian fish would make their economic viability untenable. In short, the industry would be destroyed. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, or AQIS, provided a draft import risk analysis in recent times. I have previously expressed my concerns about that report, both in this place and in Senate estimates committees. In advising the Senate about my previous concerns, I also want to acknowledge the concerns expressed by my Tasmanian colleagues Senator Jocelyn Newman, Senator Paul Calvert and Senator John Watson.

At great expense to it, the industry has now produced its response to the AQIS draft. It is a meaty document that runs into, I would assume, well in excess of 100 pages and has been very well prepared. It draws on a wealth of experience as set out in the page under the heading `Report Contributors'. There we have listed before us all manner of persons, with appropriate degrees and scientific qualifications that make them people well qualified to express the opinions that they have in that report. The bottom line of the report is that the risk of allowing importation of uncooked, wild-ocean caught, Pacific salmon from Canada and the United States is totally unacceptable.

There has been a furphy put around that basically the salmon growers and the industry are against the importation of these products because of competition. Most Australians, chances are, would not be aware that in fact Australia already imports some $52 million worth of salmon product each year. The salmon growers do not oppose the importation of that particular product because it is either canned or cooked and comes in a form where the risk of disease is a lot less likely than what is currently being proposed.

AQIS draft recommendations were not supported by the evidence. Indeed, where it does have a basis, it is on the basis of assumption and guesswork, hardly the stringent analysis one would expect from this government instrumentality. At this stage, I would like to quote from the report, at page 5, where the industry sets out in a summary form their concerns. The summary states:

SPEECH.PARA: As explained in this submission, our industry competes strongly in local and overseas markets. Our product is regarded as the best in the world and attracts premium prices as a result of its unparalleled quality and freedom from disease and chemical residues.

PARA.TAB: What we do fear, however, is the prospect that our competitive advantage in lucrative export markets—and therefore our economic viability—will be destroyed by the introduction of disease. Our product's reputation and the future of the industry are reliant on maintaining freedom from disease.

Should AQIS's recommendations be approved, product entering the country from Canada and the United States will be sourced from stock which contains over 20 diseases not found in Australia. Should these diseases transfer to local stocks, commercial and recreational fisheries would be irreparably damaged, and native species put under threat. ABARE has concluded that the $100 million local salmonid industry would cease to operate.

AQIS acknowledges that exotic pathogens will enter the country and that the industry would be under major threat if these pathogens were to transfer to local stocks. What is not acknowledged is the likelihood—some would argue inevitability—that transfer will occur.

Independent scientific analysis and numerous case studies highlight the likelihood and ease with which transfer can occur. By not properly evaluating the means through which disease could enter native fisheries once diseased fish enters that country AQIS is breaking with accepted international practice and putting our entire industry at risk.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, there are three basic issues. The first issue is whether exotic diseases will enter the country. AQIS and the industry agree that that will occur. The next issue is whether the disease pathogens will be transferred to local stock. That is the only place where there is disagreement between the industry and AQIS because, if transfer does occur, the industry will be devastated; that fact is acknowledged by ABARE and by the industry. The only area of disagreement between the industry and AQIS is in relation to the likelihood of the transfer of the disease pathogens into our local fish communities.

PARA.TAB: The amount of research undertaken by AQIS in this area is, unfortunately, lacking. Allow me to give an example of one of the 20 diseases, known as PKD—proliferative kidney disease. This disease has been flagged as an example of a disease which should be kept out of Tasmania. It is interesting that the AQIS report identifies that the causative agent of this disease has not been isolated; the infective dose required to infect a fish is unknown; the physical resistance of the PKD agent is not known; the parasite's stability in sea water is not known; and the presence or otherwise of suitable hosts in Australia has not been established.

With a disease-free status and premium prices being commanded as a result of that disease-free status, AQIS ought be approaching this on the basis of minimising risk. They ought minimise the risk, especially when there are substantial gaps in our collective knowledge as a scientific community in this important area and, in particular, with the disease involved. Despite the dearth of evidence, AQIS is apparently adopting a policy of `what you don't know won't hurt you'. I personally—and, I am sure, the industry in Tasmania—expect a much higher standard. Tasmanians, I am sure, expect a much higher standard of care from AQIS. The AQIS approach is apparently based on disproving risk rather than proving that there is no risk, and there is a significant difference. I recommend that approach to AQIS and its officers.

I will quote an example which is contained in this report and which makes the point very well. The aquaculture industry does not, of course, have such a great community understanding as does, for example, the beef industry, and so this report asks the readers to:

SPEECH.PARA: Consider the following scenario: it is proposed to import beef into Australia from a location that is known to have in excess of 20 cattle diseases not currently present in Australia. Many of these disease agents have the potential to wipe out the beef industry and will be present in the imported product. Some of these diseases are new, their method of transmission is unknown, the susceptibility of Australian cattle is unknown, the scientific knowledge is sketchy, and there is the possibility that the native mammal or marsupial populations could be wiped out if the diseases escaped into the environment.
Such product would be almost certain to be refused entry to Australia without processing at the source to eliminate the pathogens.
This then raises the question—why is the salmon industry being treated differently?
That scenario highlights the difficulty that the industry in my state now faces and the double standards being applied in relation to this relatively small industry by Australian standards.

PARA.TAB: To support industry's claims that they are not opposed to North American imports for economic reasons, the Tasmanian Salmonid Growers Association has very appropriately suggested a four-step program to deal with this matter and the suggestions that it makes are outlined on page 7:

SPEECH.PARA: It is therefore our strong contention that:
.In line with international practice, Canada and the United States should be required to institute processing methods which eliminate disease at source prior to export.
.Improved requirements for heat treating imported product must be implemented.
.Import regulations should be strictly enforced.
.All product shipments need to be tested by AGAL at the exporters' expense.

AQIS's justification for allowing diseased product into this country is the assertion that the many diseases will not establish themselves in Australia. However, there is no scientific evidence to support such an assertion. Whilst there is no such evidence, our waterways, employees and producers ought be protected from the certain devastation that will ruin the livelihoods of 2,000 Tasmanians if the disease does take hold in fish.

PARA.TAB: Now that the government has before it this fine report prepared by the industry in Tasmania, I trust the report will receive detailed yet speedy consideration so that the unnecessary dislocation and uncertainty being occasioned to the industry can be removed to thus allow the employees and the industry to get on with doing what they do best: providing high class, world standard, clean green product to our domestic markets and earning valuable export dollars to offset the outrageously high trade deficits we have experienced under the current Labor Government.

I plead with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) to act quickly and to act appropriately. Remember that your duty is not to AQIS or to your bureaucracy, or, might I respectfully say, to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry), but to the people who work within the industry. I also plead with the minister to remember the very real importance this industry has to the people of Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of today's matter of public importance debate to speak on this very important report of the committee on Darwin. It is a 400-page report which was tabled in the Senate at the end of June this year. The committee was established by the federal government in 1993 to look at ways of making Darwin the nation's gateway to east Asia. Chaired by Labor mate Neville Wran, the committee was given $4 million of taxpayers' money and asked to investigate strategies to develop the potential of Darwin as Australia's northern link to east Asia. But, as the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Shane Stone, told the Legislative Assembly in Darwin last week, the committee subsequently lost the plot. Instead of looking at how Darwin could service the national interest, they took, to quote Mr Stone, `the benevolent but ultimately self-defeating view that the task was to identify ways to assist Australia's poor sister northern capital'.

PARA.TAB: The report now stands as a testimony to opportunities lost for Northern Australia, for this tired and unimaginative federal Labor government and for the taxpayers of this country who invested $4 million.

The committee on Darwin was announced amid political fanfare and publicity by the then Treasurer, John Dawkins, in the 1993-94 federal budget. His vision for Darwin was reflected in his statement of 17 August 1993. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Darwin has the potential to become a major regional city, providing Australia's northern link to East Asia and acting as a catalyst and facilitator of increased trade with the region.
It is in Australia's interests that such potential is quickly realised, so that the nation can take full advantage of the emerging initiatives within the region.
This process will require the Northern Territory economy to develop and expand from one based on mining, tourism and agriculture to one with larger industrial and commercial sectors.

This in turn will provide a basis for population growth through new employment opportunities, enabling an expansion of the population of Darwin into an even more significant city over the coming decades.

In my submission to the committee, I urged that committee to think laterally about the development of the north and suggested certain joint ventures between government and the private sector. Then, through the Senate estimates committees, I continued to monitor the progress of the committee by way of questions of various departments and officers.

PARA.TAB: The final report slipped into Parliament House on 29 June this year. I say `slipped in' because, unlike the fanfare that surrounded the original Dawkins announcement, the launch of the report was so subdued that members of the public were ringing my office asking where to find copies. The federal government's reaction was particularly telling. Despite the trade with Asia rhetoric we hear from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), he managed only a brief statement in response to the report. In fact, he stopped short of committing his government to a detailed response to the report, which ought to take place in this parliament. The report was then left to the Northern Territory senator and minister, Bob Collins. He rose to his feet in question time on 29 June, made some flippant remarks, and went on to table the document in what seemed an afterthought. Trade minister, Bob McMullan, has been mute on the report in parliament.

The report itself contains 77 recommendations, estimated at $20 million over four years, and it must be said that their tone suggests political appeasement rather than political challenge. As one commentator said, the report bears the hallmarks of Treasury. The dissenting statements at the end of the report reveal frustration within the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Geoff Stewart, the founder of North Flinders Mines, wrote:
I consider that a more visionary, bold and imaginative approach towards the development of north Australia's vast trade and investment potential with East Asia is warranted.
Others, such as the Northern Territory political commentator Frank Alcorta were more blunt. Mr Alcorta said:
. . . this is a disgraceful report which may linger like a bad odour to continue poisoning perceptions about Darwin and therefore the Northern Territory.

Sure, the report talks about the Northern Territory developing niche markets in tourism, health, education, training, research and medicine, but in many cases these have already been identified and pursued by the Northern Territory government. Sure, the report talks about the railway, the important link between Alice Springs and Darwin, being a case of when, not if, but why does it shy away from land bridging? Why does the committee underestimate the domestic freight content by 22 per cent?

PARA.TAB: If there is one redeeming feature, then it rests with the 18 consultants' reports which were commissioned by the committee. They contain valuable research on subjects such as shipping, defence, long-term trends in east Asia and business leaders' perceptions of Darwin. I seek leave to incorporate a table listing these consultancies, which will be of interest to many organisations who will implement the consultants' recommendations that have been ignored by the Labor government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. For some reason, the Wran report fails to reflect the quality of those consultancies. It is also fails to reflect John Dawkins's vision for Darwin. Why did the government and the committee lose the plot? My guess is that when the sponsor, John Dawkins, left federal parliament in 1994, the political will for this committee left with him. In other words, the government had an excuse to go cold on the project. We are now left with a report worth $10,000 a page, which not only fails Darwin and the people of the Northern Territory but fails the taxpayers who invested in it.
—How many pages?

—There are 398 pages in the report. To add insult to injury, the report downplays Darwin's strategic significance, adding that the city cannot rely on its proximity to Asia and that the adverse effects of its image problems are `pervasive.' Someone should have told the 600 or so visitors who were, at the time the report was launched, on their way to Darwin from China, the Philippines, Malaysia, Macau, and Indonesia for the Northern Territory Expo Trade Show this year.
—Who was the chairman of this committee?
—Mr Wran.
—And he was talking about an image problem for Darwin?

—That is right. It is also significant that the Philippines President, Fidel Ramos, is creating history today by addressing the Northern Territory parliament. He is, in fact, the first Asian head of state to address an Australian parliament. The Philippines and the Northern Territory will also sign a special memorandum of understanding today. I remind the Senate that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has not yet visited the Northern Territory parliament. In fact, he turned up on the day of the opening an hour and a half late and did not come to the actual opening ceremony.

PARA.TAB: As senator for the Northern Territory and shadow minister for northern development, I want to put the federal Labor government on notice. Rest assured, I will not let $4 million worth of taxpayers' money gather dust in ministerial offices. I will ensure that this report stands as a testimony to Labor's neglect of the north. For too long, the north has been the subject of countless reports and inquiries; for too long we have suffered government paralysis by analysis. The federal coalition is determined to turn that situation around.

Northern Australia is currently responsible for almost 30 per cent of national exports, and there is vast potential in terms of resources, value added industry and exports of beef and other products. A federal coalition government will tap that potential and nurture economic investment, and the diversification of regional economies through a range of innovative and forward thinking policies. History will not remember the Wran report or this government kindly.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer, Minister, to your argument of convenience that Commonwealth funding of Dr Lawrence's effort to close down the Marks royal commission was contingent upon the Western Australian government not paying such costs. If that was the basis upon which you funded the Lawrence appeals, why did you not at the time of making that decision seek the financial support of the Western Australian government? Why did Mrs Lawrence's request to the Western Australian government for financial support refer only to her appearance before the commission? Haven't you, in fact, post facto invented this so-called contingent argument in an effort to disguise the improper decision of the Commonwealth cabinet in the first instance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proper course in these matters is for the person herself, in this instance Dr Lawrence, to make the application to the Western Australian government. I had assumed that that application had been made, both for the funding of her appearance before the commission and in any collateral appearances that may have been made. I assume she has had some other distractions in that respect, but that does not alter the basic matter in issue. The government is perfectly prepared—
—You made the decision without—

—No. The government simply would like to protect Commonwealth taxpayers' interests by securing the paying of this so far as the Western Australian government is concerned. Absolutely nothing hangs on this particular question. They know perfectly well we do want them to pay for it. If there has not been a formal letter to that effect from Dr Lawrence to them, that is a matter that can very easily be remedied because nothing of any substance whatsoever holds on it.

PARA.TAB: The point of the matter is simply this: there is no problem whatsoever, legally or in terms of the propriety of the matter, for the Commonwealth paying the tab for this in the event that nobody else is prepared to do so. Obviously Dr Lawrence had to be in a position of knowing with some confidence that the tab would be picked up whether or not the Western Australian government was going to act in accordance with past practice and precedent, and it was on that basis that we addressed ourselves primarily to the question of how this particular amount was going to be paid, should it become necessary to do so. The particular course that we have adopted in that respect has been to identify a particular head of Commonwealth enactment—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday you were saying it was all contingent—

—It is still contingent; we are not going to pay any money to anybody unless we have to. I cannot quite work out why you are getting so excited about this. We are not going to pay any money to anybody unless we have to. We will certainly be asking, if it has not been asked for already, the Western Australian government to pay that. That particular litigation in any event is not complete; it is only the preliminary procedural stage of it.
—Now the public is concerned you are changing your argument.

—I don't know why you are getting excited about it. There is no matter of principle in issue here. We are not going to pay taxpayers' money to anybody unless and until we have to. But in the event that we have to, we will, and, in the event that we do, we have a perfectly straightforward legal foundation on which to do so. The preferred position in this respect will be to pay the money out under the authority of paragraph 4(4)(a) of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity, since this has been a matter of some interest yesterday in the parliament and more widely, to table and seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement from the Commonwealth government of the precise basis on which we are moving so far as the payment of this money is concerned, in the event that we have to—in the event that Western Australia does not do the right thing; in the event that Western Australia does not do what New South Wales did and fund Greiner's challenge to ICAC; in the event that the Tasmanian government does not do what it did in supporting Gray's attack on the Rouse royal commission; in the event that the Western Australian government does not cough up what it is supposed to for even the ordinary witness costs as well, because it is presently resisting that—in the event of any of these contingencies, in the event that we do have to pay, this is the basis on which we will pay it.

We have set out here the basis of it. We have also attached to that a legal advice from the Solicitor-General prepared specifically for this purpose, because we are not in the business of tabling advice received in the ordinary course of events, and you can see for yourselves the perfectly clear and straightforward basis on which this has been put together. I seek leave to have the document incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: FUNDING OF DR LAWRENCE'S LEGAL COSTS IN RELATION TO THE

1.Successive Commonwealth Governments have provided financial assistance to Ministers in relation to legal proceedings. Prior to 1984 this was done on an ad hoc basis but guidelines were then put in place by the Labor Government to cover the most frequently occurring situations, ie where criminal or civil action is taken against a Minister in relation to some matter arising out of the performance of his or her ministerial duties. The Guidelines were not intended to exclude the provision of financial assistance to ministers in other situations, such as appearances before Inquiries and Royal Commissions, and do not purport to do so.

2.In relation to Dr Lawrence's involvement in the Marks Royal Commission, consistent with practice and precedent, Cabinet agreed that it would be appropriate to financially support, to the extent necessary, her appearance before the Commission and any reasonable challenge she might make to the validity of its proceedings. Such costs will only be met should the Western Australian Government refuse to meet its own obligation to fund Dr Lawrence's costs—the funding of the costs of central witnesses before royal commissions being long-established practice at both State and federal level. There has been no definitive response from the Western Australian Government to this point.

3.The Government has taken the view that the most appropriate basis on which any Commonwealth payment might be made would be under paragraph 4(4)(b) of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act 1990. Consistently with principle and past practice, the Government is not prepared to table any legal advices it may have received in the course of its consideration of this matter. However the Solicitor-General has been asked to provide a summary of his views on the relevant legal issues in order that the Government might publicly explain the basis on which it has acted. A copy of that summary is attached.

4.In relation to any payment which may be made for Dr Lawrence's legal costs, Cabinet has agreed that in accordance with long-standing and established practice, no payments would be made unless they were certified by the Australian Government Solicitor as fair and reasonable. What is `fair and reasonable' will be determined by the Australian Government Solicitor having regard to reasonable, commercial practice. The Government has made no payment so far. The Government has not undertaken to provide any financial assistance towards the legal costs of any other person who may be involved in the Commission, and all accounts will be rigorously scrutinised by the Australian Government Solicitor.
IN THE MATTER OF PAYMENT OF LEGAL EXPENSES OF THE HON DR CARMEN LAWRENCE MP IN CONNECTION WITH WESTERN AUSTRALIAN ROYAL COMMISSION

1.Bearing in mind sections 44 and 48 of the Constitution, I am asked briefly to summarise my conclusions as to the validity of the mechanisms proposed to make the payments with respect to legal expenses incurred by the Hon. Dr Carmen Lawrence, MP in connection with the current Western Australian Royal Commission into use of Executive Power (`the Marks Commission') in the event that the West Australian Government refuses to pay part or all of these expenses.

2.The Parliamentary Entitlements Act 1990, passed to clarify the law following the difficulties posed by section 48 of the Constitution exposed in Brown v West (1991) 69 CLR 195, makes specific provision in subsection 4(4) to cover payments other than mainstream salary and related benefits—

TAB.TAB: (4)Benefits under this Act do not limit:
(a)benefits under any other law; or
(b)benefits afforded by the government to a Minister for the purpose of carrying out functions as a Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: 3.Payment of legal expenses pursuant to a separate appropriation line item made in reliance on paragraph 4(4)(a) would clearly constitute a benefit `under any other law' for the purposes of that paragraph. But the reasoning in Brown v West raises the possibility that payment out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance before that `other law' appropriation was actually enacted might not be possible.

4.To avoid this difficulty, and in order to enable payment to be made out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance for legal expenses as they are incurred (with that payment subsequently confirmed by formal appropriation), reliance may reasonably be had on the alternative source of legal authority in paragraph 4(4)(b) for the payment as a benefit `afforded by the Government to a Minister for the purpose of carrying out functions as a Minister'. Given the public acknowledgement by those initiating and supporting the Marks Commission, as well as those opposing it, that the matters being inquired of are directed to the issue of Dr Lawrence's continuing fitness for public office as a Commonwealth minister, these matters are open to be regarded by Cabinet as directly relevant to her continuing to carry out her functions as a minister. This conclusion may be reinforced by particular reference to the mounted or foreshadowed legal challenges to the Commission based on Dr Lawrence's defence of the integrity of the institutions of parliamentary privilege and Cabinet confidentiality.
5.The payment could separately be supported as a benefit under paragraph 4(4)(a) if it were made under the procedures of section 34A of the Audit Act 1901.

6.I do not believe there is any difficulty arising from section 44(v) of Constitution. As the Cabinet decision neither is based upon nor gives rise to any agreement, it cannot be said that Dr Lawrence has thereby any direct or indirect pecuniary interest in any agreement with the Public Service of the Commonwealth.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Trade: Mexico

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator McMullan, the Minister for Trade. I understand that recently the minister visited Mexico to participate in the first meeting of the Australia-Mexico Joint Commission. I also understand that during that meeting, Minister, you raised the difficulties being faced by Australian exports with respect to tariffs. Could the minister advise of the outcome of his discussions in Mexico with respect to this issue?

—There are two major items of export interest to Australian industry on which, in consultation with those industries, I pressed the Mexican government for tariff reductions when I was in Mexico in July. They were two very important issues.
—Why is our market share falling in Asia? That is the big question to which we never get any answers.
—Order! Senator Kemp!

—One was with regard to wool tops, which will create a lot of jobs in Victoria, in which you would have thought some Victorian senators might be interested. The other was with regard to sugar harvesting equipment, which is very important in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: These two important value adding examples either add value to our raw materials or build on our commodity strength to sell manufactures beyond merely selling the commodities themselves. I am very pleased to inform the Senate that I have now received very encouraging advice indicating that the Mexican government just this week has taken action which, I expect, will result in the elimination of tariffs on Australian wool tops into Mexico and sugar harvesting equipment into Mexico in the very near future.

Mexico is a very important market for wool, particularly with the special access it now has through NAFTA, and it was singled out by the industry council, in discussions with Senator Collins and myself, as a priority market for the development of wool exports. Up until now we have been successfully selling a lot of wool into Mexico—but in its raw state, not processed.

The processor in Mexico is about to close. If nothing had been done, the preferential access for wool top into Mexico would have gone to Uruguay, which had a free trade agreement with Mexico in this matter. As a result of our representations, I am confident that that tariff disadvantage will now disappear, the zero tariff will benefit and there will be a major boost to our wool industry, in particular the export of higher value added wool tops rather than greasy wool. It is about a $100 million market, so it is not something to be sneezed at. It is a big priority for our processing industry and a significant success for bilateral trade activities for Australia.

Similarly, with regard to sugar harvesting equipment, there has been, as a result of NAFTA, a circumstance in which there was an advantage to United States suppliers compared with the Australian supplier. I refer in particular to Austoft of Bundaberg, but any Australian supplier would have been in the same position. They were the company which I was aware were seeking to export and which ran into difficulties compared with their American counterparts.

As a result of our representations, I am now quite confident that we will find that tariff also removed and that we will therefore be able to be a competitive supplier. It does not guarantee that we will win. We now have to have product and price, but the company is very optimistic that, if the 10 per cent differential can be taken away, it can win in the market and restore its continuing strength.

It is a significant victory for Australian manufacturing access to this important market. It also shows that in markets such as this—and we cannot sell sugar to Mexico, because it is a big producer—we do not have to stay away and say, `Shock, horror, this is a competitor.' We can go and supply our skills in manufacturing and our services in manufacturing—and the same applies in mining—and become strong suppliers in the value added manufacturing and services end of the market and create high-skill jobs for Australians in manufacturing and the provision of services. It is an indication of the success of bilateral trade strategy, building on our traditional priorities in multilateral and regional strategy. I realise the opposition continues to wish that we would fail and put out statements announcing that we have, but I regret to advise it that we have succeeded again.
