Why should she be treated differently from any other person in living history in terms of their appearance before and in relation to a royal commission? If you can answer that you will go some way towards clearing up a perception in this community that this is a witch-hunt, that you are driving it, that it is an act of vindictiveness, and that she has been targeted in the terms of reference and in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Minister, I am afraid you just have not understood the question that was put to you. The government says that it is funding this action because there are matters of Commonwealth interests at stake. In that event, why isn't the Australian Government Solicitor acting to represent the Commonwealth interest? What Dr Lawrence separately chooses to do to look after her private and personal interests is not of any interest to me. The question is: why isn't the Australian Government Solicitor handling the matter for the government's interest in this matter? I secondly ask: should you at any time wish to intimidate or impugn the integrity of the commissioner or any of the commission staff, why don't you have the guts to do it outside?

—There are two points here. If and when the Commonwealth intervenes in this matter we will be able to choose our solicitor. In line with precedent, we could go with the Commonwealth Government Solicitor or, as has happened quite frequently, we may have to brief others as well.
—Whose interest? It is the Commonwealth's interest.

—In this case, as Senator Vanstone knows quite well—and she is dissembling the truth here—Carmen Lawrence is the person who has briefed solicitors. It is her right to brief whomever she wants, and you know that.

PARA.TAB: In terms of intimidation, Senator Vanstone, you raised the question of distance. Carmen Lawrence has been attacked because she has briefed someone from Sydney. In that context, I am asking you why someone from Adelaide has been briefed to assist the commission. That is the only context in which I raise that matter. As I say, if and when the Commonwealth decides to intervene—if we do—then it is up to us to choose our solicitors and counsel. In the meantime, any person appearing before the commission has the right to brief their own solicitors, as has been consistently the right of any such person in the past. Get honest!

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Nuclear Testing in the Pacific

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner. Minister, are you aware that on Radio National this morning Mr Downer made some claims concerning your response to French nuclear tests in the Pacific. Is it true that an Australian company has made an offer to survey Mururoa Atoll for radioactive leakage free of charge and that you have declined to pass on this offer to the French government? If so, could you explain why?

—It is true that an Australian company by the name of World Geo-Science Corporation has made contact with my office with an offer to conduct flight surveys before and after a nuclear test at Mururoa, and also requested that I pass on the company's offer to the French government. The company proposed to conduct low-level flights over the test site and use its gamma rays spectrometer to detect changes to radiation levels.

PARA.TAB: While the company offered to apply its technology free of charge, it did make clear that funding would be required for the charter of a plane or a helicopter if the flights were to take place. This morning Mr Downer seemed to think that the whole venture would be free of charge and that this was a sufficient reason for him to lend his support and go running off to the French government with the idea.

Mr Downer should be aware that as part of the meeting of South Pacific environment ministers which the government convened in Brisbane last week I commissioned a report on the environmental impacts of French nuclear testing in the Pacific. I commissioned 20 Australian scientists from a wide range of disciplines to undertake the report. The report they produced, which I publicly released last week, is, I think, the most authoritative scientific assessment which has been undertaken since the Cousteau mission to Mururoa in 1987. The report concludes that the testing to date has already caused significant structural damage to Mururoa Atoll. Nothing is known about Fangataufa Atoll where some of the larger tests of more than 10 times the destructive power of Hiroshima have been carried out.

As far as radioactive contamination is concerned, the report makes very clear that the effects will be felt in the longer term. Worst case scenarios put the possibility of radioactive leakage in the range of 20 to 50 years. Best case scenarios put it at over 700 years.

It is impossible to be more precise because of the refusal of the French government to allow access to the atolls and access to the scientific data that they hold. All the scientific evidence indicates that it is highly unlikely there would be a change in radiation levels as a consequence of a single test. It is also my view that it is highly unlikely that the French government would permit the necessary low level flights over the test site.

TALK.START.PARA: —There could be extensive leakage; why not ask them?

—In the event that they did, Senator, such a survey would be unlikely to yield very useful results independent of the more comprehensive data about the impact of testing. It would be no substitute for a proper, comprehensive scientific monitoring program. The Australian scientists have set out their program in their report. This is no reflection on the technology of the company itself, but explains why I did not raise that issue with the French ambassador yesterday.

PARA.TAB: What I did raise with him was the strong and unambiguous concern of the South Pacific environment ministers that came out of the meeting last week. On behalf of the participants of that meeting I asked the French ambassador to take to the French government our strongest possible opposition to their decision and to ask them, if they continue to claim that this will have no environmental impact, why they are not doing it at home in metropolitan France and why they are not allowing access to the atolls, the data and the samples they hold. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister would also be aware of the press reports this morning concerning the Quantum report that is going to air tonight on the ABC which reportedly concludes that there is no risk of environmental damage. How do your concerns tie up with those press reports?

—I do not know where Quantum is getting its information from. What I can say is that I am getting my information from 20 eminent Australian scientists. I am happy to table their report and the declaration of the environment ministers. The reason this report was commissioned is to lay bear the scientific facts of the matter, whatever they might be. Their conclusion has formed part of my response on the environmental impact of testing.

PARA.TAB: Their report is there for all to see. I released it last week and I am happy to table it now. It is clear from that report that, on the basis of the limited amount of data available from the French government, there has been major environmental damage at Mururoa Atoll and that we can expect leakage of radioactive contaminants into the marine environment in the longer term. That is simply unacceptable as far as I am concerned, as far as the South Pacific environment ministers are concerned and as far as all Australians are concerned. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —What an answer! A cop-out!
—Why don't you listen, you moron!
—Order! Senator Kemp!
—You are hopeless.
—Order! Senator Kemp!
—You are soft on the whole issue.
—Order! Senator Kemp!
—You are not competent.
—Order! You will get no more warnings after this, Senator Kemp.
—A point of order, Mr President.
—What about Faulkner? Are you going to let him get away with that?
—Do you not think, Mr President, it would be appropriate in all the circumstances to suggest that such provocation on the part of Senator Faulkner is unhelpful?
—I heard it; I do not think it provoked it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Child Care

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Is it not true that the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 is still being dealt with by the Senate and has not yet been voted upon? Is it not also true that a large advertisement in the mainstream press entitled `The building blocks of child care', placed by your department, presumes that senators will vote in a particular way, the government's way, on this legislation? What is the cost of this advertising program? Will it be discontinued, as it should be, until after the parliament has voted on the legislation because it is obviously very misleading?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Kernot and other senators would know, the 12 hours proposals for allowing child-care assistance for occasional care users was a budget decision. It is a very fair presumption that budget decisions will be received and supported in the large part through this parliament. There are precedents, Senator, for not presuming that and I take your point.

PARA.TAB: We are very concerned, though, to make sure that as many people as possible do have access to child care, and that was the reason for the introduction of the 12 hours proposals.

ANSWER.PARA: Those proposals will, on our estimates, allow 31,000 extra families to have access to child care—that would be for both occasional use and work related use. Given that there is still a significant unmet demand for work related child care, there is a concern that we make as much effort as possible to ensure our child care does meet the needs of working families while at the same time balancing some allowance for occasional care. They are some of the reasons, not all, why we have allowed for child-care assistance for up to 12 hours for occasional care use.

PARA.TAB: As to the cost of the advertisement, Senator, I do not have any information about that. I will seek to find that out for you. In the light of the now delay of this legislation, I will certainly see what needs to follow as a result of it. As I understand it, that legislation is before the House and the decision to not proceed with it has not actually happened. As I understand it, there is a reference to the community affairs standing committee at this stage for Friday. But, Senator, I will certainly see what further information I can find for you about the cost and the second part of your question.

TALK.START.PARA: —After recent years it would be a surprise to hear you say that you would presume that all budget legislation would go through. I did not ask you to defend the proposal; I asked: how can you honestly place this advertisement now when it is clearly misleading? Your department would have known two months ago the date of the referral to the committee for this Friday. So obviously it has been placed in the interim.
—Along with the information about the costs, I will see what further information I can find for you on that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Automotive Industry

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook. Since the last parliamentary session, several significant investment decisions have been announced in the automotive industry. Holden Engine Company, Ford Australia and Venture Corporation have all made significant investment decisions which have highlighted the resurgence of the automotive industry in Australia. On the federal government side the concept car project has been launched, the 1994 state of the automotive industry report has been released and Senator Cook has led a delegation of Australian component producers to Asia on the back of the settlement of the US-Japan auto dispute. Can the minister inform the Senate more fully of those developments?

—This is good news for Australia and for the Australian economy because the investment we have attracted in the automotive sector, totalling over the last year or so in excess of $US2 billion, is a clear vote of confidence by international corporations in the strength of the Australian economy and the ability of Australians in the Australian automotive industry to be world competitive. Certainly, we ought to pay tribute to the way in which this industry has restructured itself to achieve that goal.

PARA.TAB: On top of those investments as well, a number of major international companies—BMW, Mercedes Benz and Honda—and other companies too have decided to source major component suppliers for their cars on international production lines from Australia. So there is further a knock-on effect of the new competitiveness that this industry enjoys.

The latest announcement, however, on investment came last Thursday—an announcement of $200 million for 1995 to 1997, reaching nearly half a billion dollars over the next five years to upgrade Holden's Engine Co. plant and to expand its capacity to export car engines from Australia. I must congratulate the Managing Director of the Holden's Engine Co., Mr Peter Thomas, and his work force. We worked with them over the last nine months in order to help them attract this investment. They won this investment in the General Motors Corporation against strong competition from other affiliates of that corporation.

Holden's Engine Co. is the largest automotive export earner in Australia. This investment projects that it will increase its exports to $750 million a year and that, with the expansion that is anticipated, it could make a $170 million annual contribution to the trade account. On top of that, Ford Australia has announced a billion dollar investment in upgrading its plant in Australia for the next generation Ford Falcon. We have worked closely with the Ford Motor Co. starting July last year in Detroit and at international board level, working our way through, including during a visit to Australia by Mr Wayne Booker, the executive vice-president for international automotive operations at Ford worldwide. They have voted confidently in Australia's capacity to be a supplier in this market with a billion dollar investment. In attracting this billion dollar investment, the Prime Minister played, I believe, quite a decisive role.

The investment commitment will give a strong boost also to local component part suppliers. The Ford Motor Co. is the biggest market for Australian owned component part suppliers, and we estimate that, since they take 27 per cent from Australia, the investment will be worth $4 billion to the component part sector alone. On top of that, an American corporation has located itself in Australia and invested $165 million in Australia to use its Australian production facilities as an export base for Asia and, in particular, for India and for the immediate ASEAN area. They see that Australia is a very competitive site for this investment and the best place to locate major investment for their corporation in this part of the world.

We have locked Australia into the global strategies of the major car producers in the world, and we have done so through policies under this government—the export facilitation scheme being one of them—and our ability to find ways of improving the micro economy and of improving workplace efficiency in this industry. These are major investments for Australia. We have set ourselves up for a world site for international automotive production, and it is good news for the Australian economy. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Ministerial Responsibility

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it the view of Mr Keating that any minister caught lying to the Australian public should resign or be sacked from the government?

—It is a totally hypothetical question. It is one that always has to be answered in the context of a particular situation. The truth of the matter is that, if it is the case that Senator Alston is referring to matters of current controversy, there has not yet been an opportunity for Dr Lawrence to state her case to the royal commission. There has not yet been a full opportunity for her alternative voice to be heard in that particular forum. Until her voice is heard, I think fair play demands that no sleazy assumptions of that kind continue to be made.
—On a point of order: Senator Evans has obviously misheard the question. I did not mention Dr Lawrence. I asked—
—No, you little petunia!

—Just a minute. I asked it as a matter of principle. You blokes may not have principles, and we can establish that separately, but I am simply asking you as a matter of principle: if ministers are caught lying, should they have to resign or be sacked? It is a simple question, unrelated to Dr Lawrence. It could apply to anyone else in your frontbench. Try to answer that, will you.

—On the point of order: I do remind the senator that it was a hypothetical question and, as such, it could have been ruled out of order. I have allowed the question. I ask the minister to continue his reply.

—Obviously, these situations depend on all the circumstances. They are matters for political judgment by the parliament, which has its remedies in terms of no confidence motions. It's a matter for the executive government of the day to make a judgment. Everything will depend upon the circumstances. Misstatements are made all the time. Sometimes they are made deliberately; sometimes they are made inadvertently; and sometimes they are made through sheer absence of a recollection of the circumstances. Thirty-five minutes ago Senator Hill lied in this place. He got up—I was going to correct this after question time but let me take the opportunity now—and premised a question, among other things—
—Order! I think you should withdraw that remark or rephrase it.
—I don't know whether it was deliberate, I don't know whether it was inadvertent; but he told a monstrous untruth—a manifest fabrication, a big fat porky.
—I ask you to withdraw what you originally said.

—The word `lie' has been used by Senator Alston. I am using the same word. If it is appropriate to withdraw it, I do so. I make the point that what I am told is an untruth was put to me across this table 35 minutes ago when Senator Hill got up and asked a question of me—
—I take a point of order.
—Wipe that smirk off your face!

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Kemp

TALK.START.PARA: —Come off it. The question is a very clear question. It concerns the government's standards. The question is:

INTERJECT.PARA: Is it the view of Mr Keating that any minister caught lying to the Australian public should resign or be sacked from the government?
It is a question of the government's standards. Could Senator Evans address his answer to that question and tell us what the standards of the Keating government are?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point of order.

—The standards that should be applied are the same standards that should now be applied, for example, to Senator Hill because he got up and asked a question of me which was premised upon, among other things, the very explicit assertion that neither the Commonwealth, Dr Lawrence nor her advisers had applied to the Western Australian government. I am advised that on 4 August an application was made by Dr Lawrence's advisers to the Western Australian government for funding support both for the challenges to the validity of the commission and for—

—Mr President, this has to be the most flagrant breach of the standing orders that you have been confronted with. Here is a minister who is asked a simple question of principle, and you let him go on and talk about Dr Lawrence and Senator Hill. How could that possibly have anything to do with my question?
—In the robust cut and thrust of this place I think that is a bit rich, frankly. There is no point of order.

—What I am saying is that a manifest untruth, on the advice to me, was told to me, to the parliament and to the Australian public just 35 minutes ago. I don't know whether that was deliberate; I don't know whether it was inadvertent; I don't know whether the sources in the Western Australian government who gave him copies of private correspondence from Carmen Lawrence—
—They are your documents. You tabled them, you dill. They are yours.
—I don't know what your sources are but your sources made you sufficiently confident to assert in this place that no such application had been made. You got it wrong and you ought to apologise.

—On a supplementary question: this is fascinating. Is this the position we have now reached that when you, Senator Evans, are asked to state a position of principle in relation to ethics and integrity the best you can do is turn it into something about misstatements which, of course, is fundamentally different from lying; and then try to change the subject to Senator Hill? Does this mean that, in the lead-up to the next election, we are going to hear repeats of l-a-w law tax cuts, Bob Carr on tolls and Wayne Goss on the privatisation of hospitals; and that all these are going to be simply the price you have to pay to get a Labor government? Is it your position that you are so morally bankrupt you don't even have a statement of principle in relation to whether lying is acceptable for a minister?
—I call the Minister, but I am not sure what the question was.

—The government's position is that these matters are matters for proper determination through the political process in the parliament and through the executive government, when all the facts and all the recollections are on the table and when it is possible to make a judgment about that. The government makes the point that these are not matters for royal commissions. Royal commissions are for determining matters of criminality, matters of financial impropriety, matters of maladministration, matters of abuse of power, matters of public policy and matters of national security—
—You will not say that liars are unacceptable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections on both sides. It is impossible to be heard.
—Royal commissions are not to be used for the purpose of sleazy political witch-hunts. That is all you are about in this case. You ought to be collectively ashamed of yourselves.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Philippines

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht. As patron of the Philippines-Australia Association of Tasmania, I have been taking a keen interest in the current visit by President Ramos. I note that the president has been accompanied by a large business delegation seeking inwards investment by Australian companies, including targeting large-scale infrastructure projects. In light of the minister's construction responsibilities, I ask: what support is the government making available to Australian construction companies to gain entry to the Philippine market?

—I thank Senator Denman for her question and, as she mentioned in her question, for her interest particularly with Australian-Filipino relations. I, like many members of this chamber, was very pleased to attend the state dinner for President Ramos yesterday evening in the Great Hall, which was a great occasion. Both leaders, the Prime Minister and the President, indicated the need to extend and build economic ties between our countries. Our Prime Minister indicated that there are plenty of opportunities still to extend those ties between Australia and the Philippines.

PARA.TAB: In particular, as minister for construction I have told the parliament before that, from the Working Nation statement of last year, we have established the Asian infrastructure consortia program—a program aimed at encouraging Australian construction companies to get together in one consortium and bid for major projects in infrastructure in the Asian region. That program is now working well; Australian construction companies have come to the fore; we have made a number of financial contributions to fund those consortiums; and it is a $12 million program over four years.

I am pleased, because of the President's visit to Australia, to now announce that we have approved a grant to the John Holland group from Australia in a bid for a $230 million project for the development and construction of a water supply facility in the south metro area of Manila. If the bid is successful—and I have been advised that we have a very good chance of success—the Australian content of that $230 million project will be $60 million. The project will supply water to over one million domestic consumers and over 8,000 commercial and industrial consumers at a rate of 600 million litres per day and, ultimately, at a capacity of 1,200 million litres per day.

This is a build, operate and transfer project—the first of its kind in Manila—for the development and provision of water for that city. It is part of a number of important projects that have already taken place in the construction industry in the Philippines in which our companies have been involved; such projects including railway upgrades, coastal lighthouses, small hydro plants, and port and grain terminals. They have all been very successful.

This project is one where we are now seeing the success of the Asian infrastructure consortia program. I am sure that all members in the Senate would congratulate the Australian companies for forming the consortium around the John Holland group and look forward to more success in the future.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In a grubby attempt to discredit the former Western Australian state minister Keith Wilson's view of the Easton petition, Brian Howe claimed on radio that Mr Wilson had `a very idiosyncratic personality'; was `a very difficult character to deal with'; was `very unpredictable'; was `someone whose motives were always somewhat unclear'; was `a very, very hard politician to read'; and was `a loose cannon'. Now that the current WA Labor leader, Jim McGinty, agrees with Mr Wilson, as do present or former Labor members and ministers—Pam Beggs; David Smith; Graham Edwards; Geoff Gallop; John Kobelke; Eric Ripper; Judyth Watson; and Ian Taylor, a former deputy leader—does the government believe that they are all difficult, unpredictable, idiosyncratic, loose cannons, whose motives are unclear and difficult to read, or is Dr Lawrence the only one with the memory? And is that why you can justify spending $10,000 a day on Dr Lawrence's defence? (Time expired)

—The whole point about this particular royal commission and what makes it such a bizarre excursion is that it is not an investigation into criminality, maladministration, abuse of power, financial misuse or any one of those other things which are objectively ascertainable. It is an investigation into the condition of people's memories about events which occurred about three years ago, memories unsupported by contemporaneous documentary evidence. And how you or anyone else can feel comfortable reaching conclusions based on that kind of evidence of recollections unsupported by contemporaneous written records I do not know. I do not know how you can lie straight in bed feeling confident about any conclusion that you might reach on that, let alone anyone else who is in the business of being judgmental about it. It is particularly dangerous to do that.

PARA.TAB: The bottom line is not whether certain events or discussions took place, because obviously these events did take place. Obviously there were discussions. The big matter in issue is when those discussions took place. Did they take place before or after the petition was tabled? The truth of the matter is, as every single one of us in this place knows, human memory is notoriously fallible on matters of this kind. Of course that is the case, and that is exactly the point that Brian Howe, Mr Howe, was making about Mr Wilson. Some people's memory, of course, is more notoriously fallible than others. It may be that a particular judgment in that respect can be made with particular confidence about particular individuals. But the truth of the matter is that that is the nature of the issue here.

The bottom line in all of this is not to establish at the end of the day even the cause of the poor woman's suicide. It is not to establish whether anyone engaged in criminal activity. It is not to establish whether there was any maladministration. It is not to establish whether there was any lack of probity in a financial transaction. It is not to address a national security matter. It is simply to address a political imperative as experienced by Mr Court—the political imperative of diverting attention from the huge and obvious political difficulties he and the Western Australia government are in as a result of the adventures of Noel Crichton-Browne. That is the reason for this adventure. Everyone in the country knows that is the reason for this adventure. It is perfectly appropriate to cast doubt upon the testimony of those who purport to recollect just as much as it is about those who do not recollect these events. Nobody can be confident about this sort of matter. The whole thing is a political ramp. Again, you ought to be collectively ashamed of yourselves for supporting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I prefix it by saying I am not being judgmental at all; I am simply saying that there are eight former ministers and now three former staff members all with one view, and Dr Lawrence with another view. My question is: is that why you are spending $10,000 a day on defending Dr Lawrence with taxpayers' money? Will you now apologise to Mr Wilson for the attack on his integrity, given that there are eight former ministers and three staff members who agree with his version and not Dr Lawrence's?

—The reason the Western Australian government is spending millions of dollars of taxpayers' money in this respect is not to establish any matter that is a proper matter for a royal commission; it is to advance a political cause in the sleaziest way imaginable. The reason why the Commonwealth government stands ready if it becomes necessary to do so to support Dr Lawrence in the payment of her financial costs is that to do so is to enable her to carry on her functions as a minister, which are under challenge as a result of those advancing this cause. The object of the exercise from start to finish has been to discredit Dr Lawrence and try to establish her unfitness to hold that particular office. The object has been to put at risk her capacity to carry on her functions as a minister. That is why, quite apart from other reasons of common decency, which are conspicuously lacking on the other side, the Commonwealth does stand ready to pay her costs in this matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: China: Women's Conference

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services and it relates to next week's Beijing women's conference. Why was AusAID's Dr Ware appointed as a delegate to that conference after that official, on 23 June at estimates, refused to accept as coercive the official Shanghai policy to impose a fine of three times the family annual income payable over six years where a woman refused to have her second pregnancy aborted? Would you not agree that this official policy is coercive? What action is the Australian delegation going to take, when in Beijing, to protest the gross violations of human rights, including widespread coerced abortions and sterilisation in the name of the PRC's one child family policy?

—I do not know by what criteria Dr Ware was appointed. I will certainly see if there is anything about that which I can find out for Senator Harradine. Dr Ware is a person with considerable experience and a contribution to make. As to the question about the—
—Welcome back, Noel.
—Hang in there, Noel.
—Thanks, fellas.

—I am sorry, Senator Harradine. As to the questions of China's policy and coercive abortions, this government has made comments. I certainly remember an answer from Senator Gareth Evans. I would be entirely in support of the view that it is, on the face of it, not a policy that I would want to support at all. But it is a matter of ongoing concern and consideration about how best to deal with it. It is certainly very much a matter for the Chinese government. As to what the Australian delegation is proposing to do about it, I will take that on notice and find out for you.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ADF: In-Vitro Fertilisation

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that it was originally proposed this financial year to budget $1 million from the defence budget for in-vitro fertilisation procedures for members of the ADF, a proposal which was later abandoned? Were the origins of this proposal to be found in the fact that, since the ADF provides full health cover for its members, the advice they received was that in-vitro fertilisation must be provided to comply with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act and associated acts?

—I will check the details of that. I can say to Senator MacGibbon that no such proposal has ever come across my desk. In a portfolio of this size, it is always possible that something of this nature may have. But I would be surprised if it has and it has not come over my desk. I will check the details and let you know.

PARA.TAB: You raise a broader question of how often quasi-judicial bodies try to impose `community standards' on the Defence Force without looking at the impact on the Defence Force. That is something that I have constantly under review. In some other cases, those decisions can have a very adverse effect on the Defence Force. But the issue you raise has never come to my attention. That is not to say that you are badly informed or otherwise. I am surprised that it has not, if there is any substance to it. I will check it and get back to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the minister's answer, I ask a supplementary question. How much longer will the government tolerate the inapplicability of some sections of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act and associated acts to the Australian Defence Force? Will it amend the act to exclude the ADF from its provisions where reasonable grounds exist for its exclusion?

—The senator has hit the nail right on the head when he says `reasonable grounds'. As much as possible, the ADF itself wants to reflect community standards and attitudes on a variety of social issues. There are, however, some justifiable exceptions in the unique nature of what a defence force does. Where that does conflict with existing legislation or there is an inappropriate provision for exemption for the Defence Force, I am happy to take those issues before cabinet and seek an exemption.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Rural Women

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Bob Collins. The first national rural women's forum was held in Canberra in early to mid-June this year and has certainly been described as a milestone in the history of rural women. Can the minister advise if the government is moving to implement any of the recommendations flowing from the forum?
—I am well aware of the forum and its findings and, indeed, my department was a co-sponsor of the forum. I met yesterday with Dr Margaret Alston, the forum convener. Related, Richard?
—It does not ring a bell.

—No? I met with her yesterday to formally receive the forum's report and recommendations. Firstly, let me say that I do strongly support the recent moves by rural women to organise and involve themselves in the full range of rural issues. I see this involvement as being critically important to developing effective rural policy and viable rural communities.

PARA.TAB: I frequently raise with industry groups the need for both industry and government to correct the gender imbalance which is so glaringly obvious in the primary and resource industries in Australia. My department has developed a comprehensive strategy for achieving gender balance on portfolio bodies by the year 2000, and I have written to all major industry groups to request their assistance, where appropriate, in meeting this target. Of course, in my portfolio—and it is unique—we have a huge expanse of selection committees that do the job of putting up names for these bodies. The representation on those selection committees comes from industry, not from the government.

A rural women's unit has been established in my department and Helen Board has been appointed as the national rural women's coordinator. This unit will be invaluable in our efforts to identify and address the needs of rural women relevant to my portfolio. Indeed, I was very pleased to see that a number of the recommendations from the forum recognised the role of the unit and its importance in assisting rural women to achieve their aims.

Work has already commenced in several other areas covered by forum recommendations. For example, ABARE has already commenced research on the contribution of women to the rural sector. The rural women's unit is discussing the possibility of establishing a national rural women's network with the states and members of the various state networks. Child care in rural Australia is also an issue that I have personally been closely involved with.

A number of programs already emphasise rural women and family issues. The rural partnership program, which I launched last week in Perth, is an excellent example of that. I am strongly encouraging the involvement of women in the community planning and development that will be supported under this program. However, a number of the forum recommendations—and I pointed this out to Dr Alston yesterday—are outside the scope of my portfolio. They are aimed at other federal portfolios, the state governments and the rural communities themselves. I will be working with my colleagues to see how we can best address them.

The forum's findings demonstrate yet again that rural women are concerned with a whole range of issues that affect them, their families, their communities and the farm. I am pleased to say that action is already in train to analyse and, where appropriate, address the recommendations that have been made.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Sales Tax: Motor Vehicles

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook. Is the minister aware that, in a recent survey of New South Wales car dealers, 79 per cent blamed the federal Labor government's increase in the sales tax on cars for the slump in demand for new vehicles? Does he care that new car sales fell by 28 per cent in July? Is he concerned that 27 per cent of New South Wales dealers will reduce their staff numbers over the next 12 months because of the slump in demand? Given that the car sales tax increase to 22 per cent is a blatant breach of Mr Keating's 1992 promise that the tax would be permanently lowered to 15 per cent, why should any car dealer or car industry employees, let alone car buyers, believe anything Mr Keating says before the next federal election?

—When people want to make a point, they actually ought to be very careful about how they statistically present that point. It is a well-known fact. If you want to go back through history and look at the July sales of motor vehicles in Australia, you will find that inevitably they are lower than the June sales. The reason they are lower is because people clear their stock in June for the end-of-year clearance. Anyone in Australia who watches television or reads a newspaper would see all the bargains in the end-of-year clearance in June. There is a big bulge in selling in June and a consequent drop-off in July. That is the way the market works.

PARA.TAB: So when you quote to me, Senator Minchin, a reduction in sales for July over June of 28 per cent, you do not surprise me. But does that mean that the motor vehicle industry in Australia is in bad repair? There has been a lot higher demand in this country for motor vehicles over the last 12 months when compared with about five years ago. There is an upward growth in demand for motor vehicles.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot compare that with the recession.

—The economy is stronger, consumer demand is higher, more people are buying motor vehicles and there is a tendency for more people to replace their old car or their second-hand car by buying a new car. They are worthwhile changes in the economy which reflect our ability to actually manage this economy and to ensure that there is a degree of consumer confidence as well.

PARA.TAB: In an earlier answer in question time, I talked about $2 billion-plus investment by the major motor vehicle companies and major component parts supply companies in Australia. That $2 billion did not come here because people think that this is a poor market, it did not come here because people think that we do not produce a quality product, and it did not come here because people thought there was no opportunity in this market. It came here for all the reasons that this is a good market; there is opportunity, there is confidence, and we are a good export base to the region.

The other part of this question is about the reduction we made in the One Nation statement to the tax on motor vehicle sales. We reduced the impost on wholesale sales tax on motor cars. We did it as a counter-cyclical measure; we did it to stimulate the economy; we did it directly in recognition of the lobbying of the motor vehicle industry to encourage an uptake of motor vehicles, to keep production volumes up and to maintain their competitiveness. We did it then for those reasons. Now that the economy is back into strong and sustainable growth, it is an appropriate time to return the tax to its original level, and that is what we have done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to the Minister for Human Services and Health.

SPEECH.PARA: I think question time today demonstrated why a Senate inquiry into the government's decision to fund the efforts to bring down the Marks royal commission in Western Australia is warranted. In question time I asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question regarding what appears to have been an afterthought, that is, that they would seek the Western Australian government to pay for the costs of Supreme Court action and attempted High Court action to end that royal commission. That appeared to be presented yesterday as an argument of convenience on the basis that that did not accord with the documentation that had been previously made public and tabled by the government in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: On 20 June, the Attorney-General put out a press release in which he said, the way I read it, that the government would support Mrs Lawrence in her efforts to close down the commission. The government also said that, `The Western Australian government, having pulled this stunt, has a responsibility to accede to a request from Dr Lawrence to meet her costs in this action'. That was clearly referring to a previous letter written by Dr Lawrence to the Western Australian government, and tabled in the Senate by the minister representing the Attorney-General, in which Mrs Lawrence sought support for her appearance before the royal commission, with no mention whatsoever of the cost related to her attempts to close down the commission.

On that basis, at the time that the government decided to fund the action, to fund Lawrence in her efforts to bring the royal commission to a close in order that she would not have to appear before it, there was no intention whatsoever on the government's part to seek that the Western Australian government pay for that; it was done in order that they might support their minister and to save her embarrassment, and it was to be done at the expense of the Australian taxpayer, a decision—

TALK.START.PARA: —When were those royal commissions supposed to commence?
—Before then. He has already said that here. Read your Attorney-General's press release.
—Show it to me.

—Leave it there for a minute. That is the basis of the argument of convenience that the minister tried to put in the Senate yesterday—to suggest that all along it had been the government's intention to first seek the Western Australian government to pay for this. That was not its intention at all. It was a convenient afterthought.

PARA.TAB: We could get to the real truth of the matter—and all the truth—if the government had put on the table the documents that the Senate had sought by order, but the government refused to do. Now we will seek them through a further process of a Senate committee inquiry, provided the minority parties are prepared to support us in our efforts to find the truth in this matter.

The second issue that ought to be explored by that inquiry is this obscure argument of the government as to its basis, its entitlement, to be funding Dr Lawrence in this matter. In the documents incorporated by Senator Evans in question time today its argument appears to rely on section 4(4) of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act. That does not provide any basis for payment at all. Subsection 4(4)(b) states:

SPEECH.PARA: (4)Benefits under this Act do not limit:

PARA.TAB: (b)benefits afforded by the government to a Minister for the purpose of carrying out functions as a Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: No-one could suggest that that subsection provides the power that empowers the government. But even if the government was right—and it is an obscure interpretation, if I might say so, at best—it is still in trouble because there is no way that it could suggest that these payments to Dr Lawrence to close down the royal commission can be `benefits paid by the government to the minister for the purpose of carrying out her functions as a minister'. There is no way in which you could argue that her efforts to close down the royal commission can in any way further her responsibility as a Commonwealth health minister. Even if the interpretation that is being sought to be applied was correct, the government certainly falls at that hurdle.

PARA.TAB: The correct and most appropriate body to explore the detail of not only the legal questions involved but also the motivation of the government is the Senate committee process. That is why we are seeking to set up this inquiry.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the two matters raised by Senator Hill, let me say this: the suggestion that this is simply some kind of afterthought—the business of the Commonwealth not wanting to pay anything that it did not have to—is simply not so. The government's intention has never been to pay for anything we did not have to. In fact, it would be irresponsible of us if we were to make such a decision.

PARA.TAB: What we did decide to do right from the very outset was to stand behind Dr Lawrence to cover any costs that were incurred over and above that which she was able to recover from the Western Australian government, in the event that the Western Australian government backslid on its responsibilities and did not fully support her, both in terms of any proceedings before the commission itself and in terms of any collateral challenge to the validity of the commission.

If Senator Hill is to be believed, the Attorney-General said on 20 June—I do not have the text in front of me; Senator Hill was not kind enough to remind me of it—that the government will support Dr Lawrence's efforts and that the Western Australian government has been requested to accede to her request to support her. But that is expressed, in general terms—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read her letter?
—Sorry?
—It refers to the request she has already made. The request she made related to her appearance before the commission.

—That cannot possibly be right because the particular action before the Supreme Court was not commenced until nine days after this particular press statement was issued. The action taken in the Supreme Court was commenced on 29 June. You are talking about an exchange which occurred on 20 June. Until then there was nothing to request of the Western Australian government because it was just purely proceeding in general terms. The more specific request came along later, as you would expect. It came along, in fact, on 4 August, when a very detailed, I am advised, seven-page application was made—not just a two-paragraph letter from Dr Lawrence—by her legal advisers arguing the case for indemnity, both for all proceedings before the commission and for a fully detailed account of all the proceedings that went on before the Supreme Court.

PARA.TAB: In any event, there is no question but that the Commonwealth has never been prepared to sign blank cheques on this particular matter. We are only going to cover the costs of anything, as I said, that is not otherwise covered for Dr Lawrence.

As to the second business from Senator Hill, the truth of the matter is again extremely straightforward: 4(4)(b) of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act is the general cover for payments of the kind that are proposed to be made in this instance, just as the act as a whole provides cover in all its various different provisions for all the various different classes of payment, regular and ad hoc, that might be made from time to time to parliamentarians and ministers. There needs to be statutory cover for this because the case of Brown v. West a year or so before this act was passed made clear that unless there was statutory support for any payments made, there may be some problems with section 48 of the constitution.

Of course it is the case that there has to be further explicit action taken to support a particular appropriation, and the point about 4(4)(b) is only that it provides the general legal authority for a payment of this kind to be made. Any particular dollars that have been made obviously have to be supported through the normal appropriation system. The difference is that with 4(4)(b) you can support, on the legal advice available to us, an advance payment under the Advance to the Minister for Finance. There may be a trouble under any other head of power, certainly as articulated in this act, in doing that, in making a payment under the advance, unless you rely on 4(4)(b).

We can rely specifically on 4(4)(b) because what is clearly involved here is Dr Lawrence's capacity to continue carrying out her functions as a minister. I will read into the record again the relevant advice from the Solicitor-General, who makes the point clear:

SPEECH.PARA: Given the public acknowledgment by those initiating and supporting the Marks Commission, as well as those opposing it, that the matters being inquired of are directed to the issue of Dr Lawrence's continuing fitness for public office as a Commonwealth minister, these matters are open to be regarded by Cabinet as directly relevant to her continuing to carry out her functions as a minister. This conclusion may be reinforced by particular reference to the mounted or foreshadowed legal challenges to the Commission based on Dr Lawrence's defence of the integrity of the institutions of parliamentary privilege and Cabinet confidentiality.

There in a nutshell is the basis of that particular argument. There is no doubt about the legality of this payment, if it has to be made. There is no doubt about the propriety of it. The only matter of issue so far as propriety is concerned here is the propriety of a witch-hunt being mounted at massive cost to the taxpayers by the Western Australian government in utterly unprecedented circumstances. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to address this matter and comment particularly on the stunt that has been pulled by the government and Dr Lawrence in the application for funding, or putting the onus on the Western Australian government. They were put in place by the Lawrence government and when this petition was tabled she was operating under those guidelines with the full knowledge of what those guidelines contained.

That is a very important point to remember when we are debating this particular issue. This is particularly so when there is an attempt to denigrate people, which is what this exercise was all about. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a discussion taking place in the chamber at the present time about the meaning of those rules and regulations which determine when it is appropriate or otherwise for government to pay the costs of the legal proceedings of a minister. In looking at those rules and regulations it is appropriate to keep in mind what the moral rights of the situation may be.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane has spoken about a petition—an inaccurate petition—and he has also spoken about the very fearful consequences that followed on from that petition. That is not the issue that is before the royal commission in Western Australia. The thrust of the issue before the royal commission in Western Australia is the credibility of a minister who is now a serving minister in the federal government. That credibility is being tested by calling a series of witnesses to give an account of the tabling of a petition some years ago.

The credibility of the minister has been attacked on a classic forensic tactic: that is, get a person to make a statement about an alleged state of fact and then get other people to contradict that alleged state of fact and to say, `You have said this. They have said that. We prefer the evidence of those others. Your credibility is therefore to be criticised.'

That is what this royal commission is all about. It is an evidentiary exercise that is designed to test the credibility of a minister that is presently serving in this government. The purpose of attacking her credibility is not to rectify what happened two or three years ago. The purpose of attacking her credibility is to make her a less efficient minister in this government and perhaps make her fall as a minister from this government. This exercise is about the capacity of Dr Lawrence to serve as a minister in this government. This exercise is designed to get rid of her or make her less effective by impugning her credibility.

I have not been through the information on all the royal commissions that have taken place here and overseas. I would be surprised if there has ever been a royal commission whose exclusive task was to test the credibility of a particular person in the community. I am willing to be corrected on that; I would be glad if those following me in this debate could point me to other such exercises. This minister has been put in the position of having to finance her defence in this unique exercise of having an evidentiary and forensic instrument used against her to impugn her credibility—that is, a particular type of examination where people make a statement and then get somebody else to make a statement to contradict that statement. I am interested to see whether anybody can point me to where that has happened before.

I believe that if a person is subject to a unique exercise like this and is required to spend thousands of dollars defending a position that nobody else has had to defend, and when the person's integrity is impugned for the sake of impugning the credibility and effectiveness of a government, then in those circumstances, and as a matter of principle, it is proper and moral that the government under attack should expend money in order to defend that attack. (Time expired)

INTERJECT.PARA: NEWS RELEASE
ATTORNEY-GENERAL
THE HON. MICHAEL LAVARCH MP
MARKS ROYAL COMMISSION

The Western Australian Government's establishment of the Marks Royal Commission is nothing more than a political attack on Dr Carmen Lawrence and a transparent attempt to cast doubt on her fitness to be a senior Minister of the Commonwealth Government.
The subject matter of the Royal Commission raises no suggestion of illegality, corruption, maladministration or public policy failure which are the proper subjects of a
Royal Commission.
It is also clear that if Dr Lawrence was not a senior Federal Labor Minister, there would be no Royal Commission.
The Royal Commission is being asked to inquire into actions that have taken place in the Western Australian Parliament. That Parliament has already inquired into and reported on these events.

The Western Australian Government's actions attack the fundamental principles of Parliamentary privilege and representative democracy by asserting executive authority over actions inherent in the performance of the duties of a Member of Parliament.

To defend these important principles, as well as one of its Ministers, as Commonwealth Attorney-General I will seek to intervene in action announced today by Dr Lawrence asking the Western Australian Supreme Court to determine the legality of the Royal Commission.
The decision to establish the Royal Commission challenges the independence and effectiveness of Parliament. It goes beyond the normal cut and thrust of politics.
The Western Australian Government having pulled this stunt, has a responsibility to accede to a request from Dr Lawrence to meet her costs in this action.

If the Western Australian Government refuses to meet its obligations, the Commonwealth will provide appropriate financial support to ensure Dr Lawrence is able to protect her rights as well as acting on its own behalf to protect the rights of all Parliaments.
NEWS RELEASE
ATTORNEY-GENERAL
THE HON. MICHAEL LAVARCH MP
OPPOSITION HYPOCRISY ON MARKS ROYAL COMMISSION
Responsibility for the expenditure of public funds associated with the Marks Royal Commission rests squarely with the Court Government in Western Australia.
It was the Court Government which called the Royal Commission in the face of warnings from its own Deputy Premier, Hendy Cowan, in the Perth Sunday Times that:
The National Party does not believe taxpayers should pay for what is essentially an inquiry to achieve a political outcome.
The Federal Opposition's use of the guidelines for ministerial legal costs in this matter is a red herring.

Prior to 1983, there were no guidelines. The guidelines now apply only to ministers defending legal proceedings. They do not apply to inquiries or to court action initiated by ministers. These continue to be assessed on a case by case basis.
The establishment of the Marks Royal Commission is clearly aimed at casting doubt on the fitness of Dr Carmen Lawrence to be a Commonwealth Minister.

The calling of the inquiry is also an attack on the fundamental principles of Parliamentary privilege and representative democracy, in that it asserts executive authority over actions inherent in the performance of the duties of a Member of Parliament.

The Western Australian Government, having called the Royal Commission, has a responsibility to meet her costs including the seeking of a determination in the courts on the legality of the Royal Commission.
If it fails to do so, the Commonwealth has a duty to ensure Dr Lawrence is able to seek a determination on its legality as well as to put its own views before the courts.
For the Federal Opposition to attack the Commonwealth's support of Dr Lawrence is the ultimate in hypocrisy.

They have cheered on the Court Government's blatant abuse of taxpayer funds in pursuing political agendas, first in the futile challenge to the native title legislation which it admits cost at least $4 million, and this inquiry conservatively costed at $1.4 million.
The real cost of these two stunts may well exceed the Court Government's entire $7.36 million legal aid budget for ordinary Western Australians this financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw attention to one particular paragraph which I did not have an opportunity to see until Senator Hill thrust it across the table at me when I was on my feet just a few minutes ago. The relevant paragraph reads:

ANSWER.PARA: The Western Australian Government, having pulled this stunt, has a responsibility to accede to a request from Dr Lawrence to meet her costs in this action.

It will be appreciated that the language of that sentence is quite capable of referring to a request that might be made in the future as well as to any request that has already been made in the past. It is self-evident on its terms; it is self-evident from the context. Senator Hill sought to make much—

TALK.START.PARA: —The word `may' meant something different to you yesterday.

—The word `may' does not actually appear in the sentence which I have just quoted, Senator Baume. Senator Hill made much of the fact that Dr Lawrence's earlier request to the Western Australian government did not refer to support for collateral actions, only to support for her legal costs.
—Senator Evans, you are straying somewhat outside the bounds of section 191. It does not provide for further debate on the matter.

—I am adding to my answer by putting down on the record, drawing attention to a particular clause and making clear that that is perfectly consistent with what I said, that Dr Lawrence may have made an earlier application, but she also made a later one.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Kemp

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have section 191 here and it says:

INTERJECT.PARA: A Senator who has spoken to a question may again be heard, to explain some material part of the Senator's speech which has been misquoted or misunderstood, but shall not introduce any new matter . . .

Senator Evans is not doing that. What he is doing is trying to carry the debate further. If he wishes to proceed in this manner it seems to me that you, Madam Deputy President, should either bring him to order and sit him down or let the debate continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the Clerk that I was not relying on that standing order; I was relying on a different standing order which entitles me at any time to add to an answer previously given.
—Make up your mind. You ought to be a High Court judge.

—I was acting on what I thought was good advice from you. That was very silly of me to act on your advice. I am just adding to an answer. I am trying to do it quickly and succinctly. All I want to do is two things: one, to put on the record the text of those two press releases from Mr Lavarch on 20 and 21 June respectively, coming, as they did, just a few days after the cabinet decision which was made on 8 June and which made it clear that this is not a recent invention.

PARA.TAB: The second thing I want to do—and I was in the process of doing this when I was rudely interrupted—was draw attention to that particular sentence in the press release of 20 June which makes it clear that Mr Lavarch was saying that the Western Australian government has a responsibility to accede to a request from Dr Lawrence to meet her costs in this action. I also want to make the point, which I can do in a couple of sentences, that that language is perfectly capable of being applied to a request that might be made in the future as well as to any request that was made in the past.

There was a request made earlier by Dr Lawrence, I think it was on 18 May—the letter that Senator Hill was quoting—which did refer only to the representation before the inquiry itself and might be read as not extending to support for the collateral proceedings. However, a subsequent application was made on 8 August, as I said earlier in the answer, which makes it very clear indeed that Dr Lawrence's request was for support for her collateral action as well as for the actual appearance before the inquiry itself. I think it is important that the record be clear on these matters. I am not seeking to debate it any further but simply seeking to clarify a matter that might otherwise cause some confusion. I am indebted to you, Madam Deputy President.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provisions of section 81 of the Reserve Bank Act 1959, I present the report of the Reserve Bank of Australia Board on the operations of the bank, together with financial statements and the report of the Auditor-General for the financial year 1994-95.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Reserve Bank of Australia is usually cautious in what it says in these reports. Certainly it does not seek to alienate itself from the general economic position taken by the government and does not seek to embarrass the government. Nonetheless, this report reveals real concerns about the inflationary threat facing Australia and, by clear inference, the government's handling of our present economy. I can demonstrate that in a few moments by reading some sections of the report.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that the government has mishandled the economic recovery to the stage now where the Reserve Bank is pointing to inflationary risks facing the economy. It makes the point at one stage that one of the problems facing Australia is the massive current account deficit. The fact is that, under this government, this nation not only is massively indebted—it has the worst balance of payments situation, I think, of all the Western developed countries—but also is going into debt at the rate of something like $2 billion a month because of an incompetent government economic policy. The government is not bringing about the basic changes required in Australia to stop us going into debt. This has some disastrous consequences, and the bank points them out. For example, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: While . . . yields rose in most countries during 1994, the rise in Australia was relatively large by international standards, suggesting some Australia-specific concerns to the markets—
and this is the key point—
It was no coincidence that countries with poor long-term records on inflation, or with large fiscal or current account deficits, tended to record the largest increases in bond yields.

We score on every ground. We have an appalling long-term inflation record under this government—sure, they got it down by having a massive recession. We are under inflationary risk at the moment; we have had huge deficits; and now we have got a massive current account deficit, which keeps getting worse and worse despite the fact that we have gone through a recession which should have held up or reversed the level of internal demand that would have brought about those sorts of imports or would have caused this sort of crisis.

PARA.TAB: Here we have a situation where the government's basic policy failure makes us one of the worst in the world and having a specific problem that, as the Reserve Bank says, other countries do not have. What is the situation facing Australia? According to the Reserve Bank:

SPEECH.PARA: With business costs—labour, raw materials, intermediate inputs, and imported products—all rising faster, it would be surprising if prices to the consumer, measured in underlying terms, did not also pick up more quickly over the coming year.

That's a great forecast, a great prospect we have—rising prices coming on top of the big increases in KST, that is Keating's sales tax, we got on 1 July, bringing about more than a 50 per cent increase in the sales tax bill Australians have to pay. There has been a 46 per cent increase since the last election in the level of sales tax that has to be paid on motor vehicles. That means that every motor vehicle owner in Australia faces a massive increase in price, probably between $1,000 and $3,000, when they replace their motor vehicles, because of this government's increased tax. As the Reserve Bank says:
These pressures could be heightened by the impact of indirect tax measures—

by this government. But this is the government that said at the last election that consumption taxes were a disgrace and that you should not have them. It won the last election by attacking consumption taxes. Yet here the Reserve Bank says that these inflationary pressures could be heightened by the impact of indirect tax measures. Whose are they? They are Paul Keating's. They are KST—the Keating sales tax. It is the sales tax you have when you are not having a consumption tax, apparently. It just happens to be worse.

PARA.TAB: There have been huge rises in petrol tax, a 46 per cent increase since the last election and in Keating's sales tax a 50 per cent increase. These and all those other little Keating taxes, these consumption taxes you are not supposed to have according to Keating, now account for something like $30,000 million a year. The GST that Keating said you should not have would have cost something like $20,000 million. It is unbelievable—50 per cent more than the GST would have been. On top of that, there has been a 50 per cent increase in KST, Keating sales tax, collections over the short period of less than two and a half years since the March 1993 election in which the Labor government lied its way back into power. The Reserve Bank goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: Long-term security yields, although now well below their recent peaks, still appear to anticipate inflation rates above recent outcomes . . . From this perspective, the main concerns for policy in 1994-95 were twofold. One was to avoid the cyclical pick-up in labour costs gathering too much momentum and prejudicing our long-term inflation performance. A second concern was that a lower exchange rate, if sustained, could exacerbate domestic inflationary pressures, adding to the difficulty of recovering the situation—
the situation brought about by this government's incompetent economic policies. The Reserve Bank then says:

Both these concerns remain at the present time . . . The round of cost increases, presently going through the economy, however, is likely to push underlying inflation above 3 per cent over the year ahead. For that to be temporary, there can be no further pick-up in the growth of labour and staff costs, and the more subdued growth path now being followed will need to be reflected in some moderation in wage and salary claims over the coming year . . . The recent low levels of the exchange rate, were they to continue, would clearly be unhelpful from an inflation perspective. The prospect of domestic price and cost pressures easing as the economy slows helps to make that situation tolerable for a time, as does the partial recovery in the exchange rate during July. Even so, movements in cost pressures, and in the exchange rate, will obviously warrant careful monitoring over the year ahead.
That is Reserve Bankese for saying that we are seriously at risk and that we have to watch this very closely. We are by no means out of the woods.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister gave a totally false impression to the president of the Philippines last night that the Australian economy is wonderful and that everything is perfect.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't say that.

—He said how magnificent it is that we are leading in growth and all these wonderful things. He did not mention the magic figures. The particular magic figure he did not mention was the disastrous balance of payments figure making us the worst in the world.

PARA.TAB: The Reserve Bank is telling us about our problems and warning us about what will happen. There is no doubt that the Reserve Bank's comment that we can expect at best a rate of growth of around three per cent or so is not enough to reduce unemployment in the future, on the government's own indication and statements. Whatever the government does, it has now painted itself into an economic corner that worries the Reserve Bank. It ought to worry the rest of Australia. It does not worry this government because, frankly, this government apparently does not care about people who are suffering as a result of these economic policies and who are having to suffer higher real interest rates than they ought to because of this government's economic policies. It is not useful to say that the foreign exchange balance does not matter. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should this country condone people who give expression to racial hatred which brings fear and does harm to those who, as citizens, are entitled to look to it for the protection of their wellbeing? People in a good society are entitled to freedom of speech. They are also entitled to freedom from fear. Those who promote one freedom as absolute, make the other empty. The true concept of citizenship embraces freedom of expression. It also encompasses freedom from harassment, including racial harassment. Harassment is prone to be directed against the most vulnerable in society and it is only right and equitable that their interests be looked to.

PARA.TAB: The states of New South Wales and Western Australia have seen the need for legislation to curb racial hatred within their borders. Sections 20C and 20D of the anti-discrimination act of New South Wales and part XI of the criminal code of Western Australia provide imprisonment and fines for people engaged in conduct comparable to that dealt with in the bill now under debate.

This bill curtails freedom of speech, and for this it has been much criticised. That criticism is made by people who accept without demur one or more of the many laws which limit what we may say and how we may do so. To set out limits to the content and manner of what people can legally say in public is in keeping with the true principle of free speech. People who go beyond those limits are met with both criminal and civil sanctions throughout the federation.

There are penal laws in Australia against sedition, against conspiracy, against revealing information gained as a public servant, against perjury, against libel and against using insulting words or singing obscene songs within the hearing of people in a public place. Civil action can be brought against a person who induces a breach of agreement, who advocates a secondary boycott, who reveals a trade secret of his or her employer, who as a doctor or lawyer gives negligent advice, and who verbally breaches copyright.
There is speech which can do great harm and should be proscribed. In his letter, St James said:

SPEECH.PARA: So also the tongue is a small thing. But what huge damage can it do. A great forest can be set on fire by one tiny spark. And the tongue is a flame of fire. It is full of evil. It poisons every part of the body. The tongue is set on fire by hell itself. It can turn our whole lives into a blazing flame of doom and ruin.
Adolf Hitler knew the power of speech and put it to horrible effect. He set down his thoughts on the matter in his preface to Mein Kampf as follows:
I know that fewer people are won over by the written than the spoken word, and that the growth of every great Movement on earth is due to great speakers and not to great writers.
Certainly Hitler could say what he wanted and how he wanted while ruling Germany.

PARA.TAB: Laws in the states and territories already proscribe crimes with the elements of those dealt with in this bill other than the racial one. Some people, including those of good will, have proposed that the evil the bill seeks to counter be met not by establishing new offences, but by increasing the penalties available for those now existing when committed for racial reasons. This is not good enough.

Australia needs legislation in place by which its population can readily identify that conduct and language seen as unacceptable in a multicultural society. When so equipped, it will be better able to meet those problems engendered by a person who moves against others because of their race, colour, nationality or ethnic origin.

Racial jibes having troubled its playing fields recently, the Australian Football League would now be in a better position to deal with the resultant crisis had it had clear and established rules in place to apply to the matter. Had they been in place, the league's reputation for racial rectitude would now be less vulnerable and Aboriginal players' chances of avoiding abuse on the field because of their colour would improve.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you say about the past? What about that?

—I am glad to say that the AFL, a most honourable organisation, has now moved to bring in regulations—and, in fact, has brought in rules—to stop that. In this debate there is a danger that those immune to the injury racial hatred can beget will give too little weight to the harm it inflicts on those who are not. There is a risk that people of good will, anxious to preserve the best of society and, in particular, its commitment to free speech, will prejudice the welfare of men, women and children cruelly and unjustly attacked because of their race, colour, nationality or ethnic origin. It is right for senators to keep this risk in mind when dealing with this bill.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza made a comment on 31 May in this chamber which brought home to me the truth of what I am saying. For example, my family has an Australian background and has been here for some generations. None of its members has suffered from racial discrimination. It is comfortable living in the mainstream which desists from attacking itself. To come to the point, Senator Panizza made an eloquent and, I found, moving plea on behalf of all ethnic groups when he asked that we as a nation should empathise with all people no matter what their background, and understand that some, even today, must suffer wounds inflicted by racism. The relatives of Eddie Mabo are a recent dramatic example of people made to bear the burden of racism as practised by an ugly element within our community.

As in my own case, most of the legislators in this parliament are in the Australian mainstream. In assessing the need for this bill, we are duty bound to give proper weight to the problems people amongst us face because of their race, colour, or national or ethnic origin. For example, with what moral force can a white Australian admonish a black one who has been racially abused on the football field to leave the injustice so inflicted inside the fence? Michael Long, universally acknowledged as a great and brilliant footballer, has in recent times made public the racism directed against him. Many decent men and women thought that he ought bear the slurs cast upon him as part of the give and take of sporting life. He disagreed, and more and more people are turning to his point of view. As I said before, it is good to see that the Australian Football League has now moved to put to rights the sorts of problems that Michael Long raised.

This debate is likely to introduce interpretations of the bill's language which go well beyond its normal and natural meaning.
