Hypothetical facts will be advanced to show how the legislation will damage the wellbeing of Australians. But these arguments do not go to the fundamental purpose of this bill. This bill makes criminal certain types of threats. It provides civil remedies for people who suffer damage because of certain racial acts. It provides neither criminal nor civil remedies against people who engage in discussions, debates, arguments, lectures, conversations, plays, comments, asides or jokes. It is directed against threats and public conduct intended to incite racial hatred or likely to offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate. Those are the matters about which we are now in debate.

This is legislation aimed at checking the outrage of racial hatred; at giving people who have suffered through its perpetration some means of redress; at giving those vulnerable to ethnic prejudice even more reason than at present to trust in Australia's care for them. It is needed to underpin the very structure of our community, which is now one made out of many varying cultures and races. People from time to time in Australian history have been placed outside the mainstream and have found themselves cruelly used by the mainstream.

The Aborigines have been the major and most persistent sufferers, but Australian citizens born in Italy were imprisoned during the Second World War. People whose background was German suffered sorely in this country during the first half of the present century. During the conflict in the Gulf at the start of this decade, members of the Middle Eastern communities living here were subject to both crude and subtle abuse. Most recently, those with a French connection have experienced bitter times in Australia. These are but graphic illustrations of forces ever present in this nation. Australia must be seen to curb those forces for the sake of all who live within her boundaries. Each and every resident of this great and good nation is entitled to feel an equal and secure part of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Racial Hatred Bill 1994. The debate on this bill has produced some strange, though mostly temporary, alliances. The extreme and openly racist right has been joined by people with a genuine but mistaken belief that the legislation will limit free speech to the extent of curtailing genuine debate on matters of public interest.

PARA.TAB: Such people concerned about our democratic system have been joined at the margin by advocates of civil rights who take the extreme libertarian view that any restriction on the freedom of expression is bad and must be resisted at any cost. On the other hand, many who have managed to avoid the harshness of Europe's history, and who have not lost a generation in the devastation of the Second World War or in the Nazi holocaust, tend to view the world from a naively benign perspective. They object to criminal sanctions even when these are less stringent than the penalties in some states prohibiting threats without racial connotations.

In some ways, it is a debate juxtaposing individual rights and the collective good. This debate has come to the fore as we move into decades of increasing globalisation, in turn diminishing the capacity of nation states to shape the destiny of their communities. In this climate, it is imperative that the community, however defined, sets up clear guidelines and standards for human behaviour separate from the all-pervasive individualistic competition model. We must seek to establish some balancing standards of collective behaviour based on cooperation and tolerance.

The Racial Hatred Bill is a response to the recommendations of the national inquiry into racist violence, the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and the Law Reform Commission's report on multiculturalism and the law.

Australia is a largely harmonious society. However, racially motivated violence and offensive behaviour do occur. This was documented by the national inquiry into racist violence by Irene Moss and Ron Castan, which lists and describes 1,447 cases of racist violence and intimidation. Irene Moss, the Race Discrimination Commissioner, found only 25 cases where a satisfactory result had been obtained by subsequent informal mediation.

In addition, there is a large body of evidence collected by ethnic communities of such incidents. Equally disturbing is the emergence of National Action and other extremist groups adept at utilising any evidence of social dislocation such as unemployment amongst the young and the rising level of poverty in rural areas.

Let me turn to the legislation. The government's bill amends the Crimes Act 1914 to create offences based on racial hatred. These include: prohibitions of threats to cause physical harm because of race, colour or national or ethnic origin; threats to property because of race, colour or national or ethnic origin and in some cases religion; and incitement of racial hatred because of the race, colour or national or ethnic origin of a person or a group of persons.

The bill also amends the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 to outlaw and provide complaints procedures for: offensive, insulting, humiliating or intimidating behaviour on the basis of race, colour or national or ethnic origin; and failure to prevent an employee or agent from similar conduct.

To some extent, the crimes are already covered to varying degrees by statutory offences in state legislation, but this bill fills in gaps, consolidates the law and adds the racial focus. The amendments to the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 are analogous to provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. One of the provisions which has raised some concern is the declaration that the act of being offensive and insulting should be unlawful. However, it matches the terminology of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and the most common means of resolving disputes under this section is through conciliation.

Let me come back to the issue of free speech. We rightly treasure free speech as one of the essential safeguards of our democratic system and an important element of the right to have a voice in government decisions. In the political arena, the High Court has recognised this right in the political advertising and Theophanous cases.

The principle of free speech is now an implied constitutional right and an essential element of our democratic society. We are rightly jealous of it and must protect it against governments, powerful interests and indeed anyone who would wish to silence critics and the voices of those who have opposing views. If public debate is to fulfil its essential function in a pluralist society, this freedom of expression must also be preserved for those who hold views which we find abhorrent.

In the racial vilification debate, this essentially correct argument, however, has been used like a club as an absolute, self-evident truth and a more than sufficient reason to reject the bill. However, it is clearly a case of one public policy principle—namely, free speech—being circumscribed to achieve other competing public policy objectives which are judged important enough to limit the freedom of expression. Examples are the laws relating to defamation, copyright, obscenity, sedition, contempt of court and incitement to violence.

The question arises whether the need to protect people from insults, harassment and worse because of their present or former nationality, creed, skin colour or religion is such a competing policy objective. Surely it is the mark of any civilised society to offer protection to the potential victims rather than to the perpetrators of racist hate propaganda.

Many other countries in Europe, New Zealand and some states in the United States, as well as New South Wales and Western Australia, have taken that step. It is of particular importance in Australia with people from over 140 countries living in relative harmony, even if that is challenged occasionally by rivalries originating in the old world.

British historian Sir Alan Bullock, while displaying his Eurocentric mindset by ignoring the unresolved and traumatic relationship with the prior owners of the continent, said, on his recent visit, that Australia's most significant postwar achievement was the successful creation of a multicultural society which could serve as an example to the rest of the world. It is an achievement worth protecting also in John Rawls's terms, who measures the level of a society's social justice by the degree to which that society protects its weakest members.

The bill is tightly drawn to confine the limits to free speech to intentional and public threats of personal violence or property damage and public incitement to racial hatred which is intentional and likely to succeed. The answer to critics of these provisions must surely be that it is difficult to see why we should safeguard the rights of potential perpetrators of such acts rather than the right of potential victims to be protected against such attacks.

The protection against public statements reasonably likely to offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate another person is, as I have said before, in similar terms to the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act and is carefully hedged to protect public debate and artistic expression. Statements which offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate another person are not criminal offences. However, any person aggrieved by such a statement may lodge a complaint with the Human Rights Commission. The commission will hear both sides and will determine any action which needs to be taken.

Free speech advocates conveniently overlook the exemptions in this bill, for a complaint will not succeed if the statements were made: reasonably and in good faith; in the performance, exhibition or distribution of an artistic work; in making a statement, publishing something, discussing or debating for any genuine academic, artistic or scientific purpose or `any other genuine purpose in the public interest'; in the course of publishing a fair and accurate report of any event or matter of public interest; or in making a fair comment on any event if the comment is an expression of a genuine belief by the person making the comment. It seems that those who delight in racist jokes or jeers on radio, in films and in the theatre will still be able to do so if this bill is passed.

Some of the most muddled thinking has centred on the criminal sanctions which apply to threats of violence, property damage and incitement to racial hatred. Little account has been taken of the fact that the two and one year prison terms respectively are the upper limit of the punishment a court could determine—and, obviously, it would only apply these terms in the most extreme cases. In its discretion the court could use a shorter term, a fine, community service or no punishment at all. People who object to the possibility of a prison term for racially motivated threats should also be made aware that the terms for, say, threats to damage property, where those threats are not racially motivated, are five years in Victoria and New South Wales and seven years in Queensland.

We should ask the question which has been asked by many a critic: will the legislation stop racist attitudes or behaviour? No, of course not. It would be foolhardy to expect this. If passed, the race hatred legislation will be first of all a statement by the Australian parliament that there is some behaviour which is not acceptable in our community. Such standard setting is important as part of the glue which our diverse community needs to achieve the security and social cohesion which is the basis of tolerance.

More specifically, it is protection from racially motivated harassment that no member of our society should be denied. This became a real issue for Australian Moslems during the Gulf War debate, for Jewish people when synagogues were daubed with swastikas by neo-nazi hoodlums, and continues to simmer in the relations between white people and Aborigines.

The tension between the Macedonian and Greek communities was fanned, to their great discredit, by Australian politicians intent on catching votes. This serves as a useful reminder that such tensions are not limited to contact between minorities and mainstream society.The violence which accompanied the Greek-Macedonian conflict sent a shock wave through the ethnic community as people realised how high the stakes were and how easy it was to damage the fragile consensus of coexistence. That experience caused some small ethnic communities to worry that the race hatred legislation could be used against them by opponents who were stronger financially and politically.

All ethnic communities, I believe, need to be reassured that parliament will provide laws strong enough to ensure equality before the law and that the system will apply them in a way which protects the weak and contains the strong. The rule of law, more than any other single factor, differentiates Australia from some of the governments migrants have fled.

There are those who argue that racists will be driven underground, that we will give them a public profile and turn them into martyrs, or that they are not a big enough problem to worry about. Driving racists underground is better than allowing them to act out their prejudices through violent behaviour. We should remember that in this context words can lead to action—violent action.

Giving them a public profile will not turn them into martyrs unless the community is sympathetic to their actions—and this is where `standard setting' comes in. None of the extremists convicted of violent crimes in Australia so far in recent years have become `martyrs'.

Those who recommend that we should disregard the sporadic outbursts of National Action and other extremist groups as insignificant might recall that in the 1920s many in Germany dismissed the loutish ramblings of Hitler and his cohorts until it was too late. They would have done better to challenge them earlier and more decisively.

I am not suggesting that Australia is in any danger of sliding into totalitarianism. The national fabric is too strong with many built-in safeguards supported by affluence for most, a relaxed and independent approach to life and irreverent rejection of any form of authority.

What is at stake is the make-up of Australia's substantive character as a community and the direction we chart for the next generation which currently has almost as high a proportion of unemployed people as the one provided by the Weimar Republic as a breeding ground for extremist `solutions' in Germany. Passing a law such as the Racial Hatred Bill is a definitive expression of the national will and as such an essential reinforcement for the educational efforts which must be undertaken at all levels of our communal life to contain racism.

The less than $2.5 million foreshadowed in the minister's explanatory memorandum is hopelessly inadequate. So would be yet another series of pamphlets exhorting people to banish racist thoughts and avoid racist actions. Australians are generally decent and tolerant. What is required is a campaign which reinforces these positive attitudes, identifies unintentional racism and exposes the degrading and ultimately dangerous aspects of racism in all its forms. It is part of that desirable national mindset to legislate against the most virulent expressions and to provide a process for examination and conciliation for behaviour which is less destructive but still harmful.

It is important when we talk about education not to limit it to seminars or to pamphlets. I wonder whether that is what people mean when they say, `Let's forget about this bill. Let's instead concentrate on education.' Let us examine what we mean by education.

It seems that as a nation it is part of the educative process for this parliament to set standards that will be debated in the community, accepted in the community, followed by the community or broken by the community. That is part of the educative process. It is part of the educative process to deal with such standards, to react to them and, ultimately, to live them by doing. We will not achieve it by seminars and by silly pamphlets.

It is one of my regrets that the government's efforts in preparing this bill and in getting it passed were not accompanied by a clear exposition of what the government meant by an educative process to be funded by less than $2.5 million. I would have thought that we could have expended some time and some energy to develop such a program because it should run together with this bill and as part of this bill.
This race hatred bill is an essential building block in the process of shaping a truly mature national identity and the Australian Democrats will support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it absolutely clear from the outset that I believe that all political parties and independents represented in this parliament are totally opposed to racism in whatever form it rears its odious head. There can surely be no doubt about that. At the same time, however, there is no doubt that in its handling of the Racial Hatred Bill 1994 the government has turned it into a political stunt for cynical political purposes designed to divide the coalition. It has failed miserably to achieve this.

PARA.TAB: In its cheap attempt, however, it has put at risk the fabric of our community by encouraging intolerance and confrontation between different sections of the Australian community. Certainly so far as my party, the Liberal Party, is concerned and our coalition partner, the National Party, our proud record on our unequivocal rejection of all forms of racism speaks for itself and is exceeded by no other political party.

It was the Menzies coalition government of the 1950s and 1960s that actively encouraged and welcomed to Australia millions of migrants from the nations of western, eastern, northern and southern Europe, and many other nations as well. It was also the Menzies government that initiated the Colombo Plan under which more than one million young people from the nations of Asia came to Australia to study.

It was the coalition government of Prime Minister Harold Holt in 1966 that effectively abolished the obnoxious White Australia Policy which had been progressively weakened by the preceding Menzies government, and introduced a non-discriminatory policy based on an inclusive and totally anti-racist philosophy. It was also the Holt coalition government in 1967 that brought forward the referendum, which was carried overwhelmingly, to recognise Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders as Australians equal with all other Australians. It was that government which appointed the first ever minister for Aboriginal affairs.

It was the Gorton and McMahon coalition governments of the late 1960s and the early 1970s that extended the implementation of these policies and philosophies still further. It was the coalition government under Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser—a government in which, I remind the Senate, the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, was a leading figure—that welcomed to Australia the first boat people from war-torn Indochina, despite some strident opposition from our political opponents and from the trade union movement, and notably the then ACTU leader Bob Hawke.

I mention these facts at the outset of my remarks because they can easily be forgotten and lost forever in the re-writing of history that has been a hallmark of the Whitlam Labor government from 1972 to 1975 and the Hawke and Keating governments of the last 12 years. Many—perhaps most—of the new arrivals to Australia over the past 12 years would not know these facts. It is important that they do, because the record shows beyond all doubt the coalition's consistent and strong support for non-discrimination in our tolerant multicultural society and our fierce opposition to any form of racism wherever and whenever it has been manifest.

Australia is blessed with less racism than virtually any other country on earth. That is a great tribute to all we Australians from whatever background we may come. At the same time, however, it is undeniable that some racism does exist here. We should not deny that because it is a fact. It is unrealistic to think that we can eliminate racist actions entirely. No nation throughout history has achieved that utopian situation.

The realistic question is: how can we as a society reduce racism to the minimal extent possible, and what should be the role of government in seeking to achieve this? That brings me to the Keating government's Racial Hatred Bill 1994. The coalition has consistently believed and argued that the basic cause of racism is ignorance and that education to shape community attitudes is the only approach that will produce long-term, lasting results. That is because education attacks the causes of racism rather than the symptoms.

The government, on the other hand, believes that priority should be given to coercive legislation and to the introduction of criminal and civil sanctions to apply to thoughts and words that might incite racial vilification or hatred, or that might be judged to insult or humiliate or offend persons on racial grounds. In other words, the government's strategy is to give priority to attacking the symptoms of racist attitudes rather than the causes.

The coalition believes that this approach by the government is very deeply flawed. In other countries where a similar approach has been adopted—notably in the United States and in Britain—the results have been spectacular failures.

The coalition, of course, accepts the need for criminal sanctions where threatened or actual damage to persons or property are involved. This should be the case whether the reason for the threat or the damage is racially motivated, or for any other reason. Such actions are already criminal offences under the common law and the statute law of all states and territories. Indeed, one of the ironies of the government's Racial Hatred Bill is that penalties proposed for these offences are less than those now prevailing under existing law.

As Senator Vanstone intimated in her remarks, the coalition could live with the proposed new sections 58 and 59 of the Crimes Act contained in the government's bill, although we regard them as inferior to the alternative proposals contained in the coalition's exposure draft which has been widely circulated throughout the community in recent months, and to which Senator Vanstone referred. It is to proposed section 60 of the Crimes Act, and proposed part IIA of the Racial Discrimination Act, that the coalition has fundamental objections. We will vote against the bill if these elements remain.

Both these elements seek to punish people for what they say rather than what they do. They punish words, not deeds. As such they pose great danger to one of the fundamental cores, the fundamental underpinning, of our tolerant and civilised democratic society, namely freedom of speech.

It is true that freedom of speech in our society is not absolute. Under our rule of law there are laws relating to defamation, sedition and the like. No-one questions the need for these laws. They are vital parts of the legal institutional basis of our society. But any encroachment on the basic democratic right of freedom of speech must only be permitted if there is a clearly demonstrated need—a need so great that it threatens the very fabric of our society. That need has not been demonstrated.

The logic that has been advanced in support of the bill seems extraordinarily convoluted, to say the least. One of the main arguments put forward is that because we have proven ourselves to be one of the most tolerant and successful multicultural nations on earth—without the need for draconian legislation of the type now proposed—we need the legislation to ensure that we remain tolerant and non-racist. Such logic surely defies rational explanation.

People reject strongly the notion that they can be gaoled for expressing their opinion. Millions of people chose to come to Australia to live precisely to escape from this very concept. As the Chief Justice of the High Court, Mason CJ, said in Cunliffe v the Commonwealth in 1994:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a law which targets information or ideas, or which prohibits or regulates the content of communication . . . would require compelling justification to sustain its validity.

Clauses similar to those proposed by the government for insertion as part IIA of the Racial Hatred Bill were also included in the original racial discrimination bill when it was first introduced in 1973 and finally passed by the parliament in 1975. The coalition opposed these clauses then, and they were deleted from the bill. In debating the matter on behalf of the coalition at that time, the then shadow Attorney-General, the late Senator Ivor Greenwood, said inter alia:

If we are to endeavour to shut out by prohibition ideas which will stand on their intrinsic value or will fall on their lack of value, I think we are well on the way to controlling thought processes. We will not succeed: no country has ever succeeded in doing that. But we certainly could not claim to be the liberal society which I think we have cause to claim we are at present.
He further said in that debate:
I cannot believe that one improves human relations by preventing some people from saying what they want to say.

It is regrettable that the government did not see fit to consult at all with the coalition in the preparation of this bill, despite the long time taken within Labor's own ranks with the bill's gestation.

PARA.TAB: This bill was promised by the government, during the March 1993 election campaign, as one that would be introduced shortly after the election. The fact is that it was not introduced until 18 months after the election. The reason for that is clear: the government encountered serious difficulties within its own ranks. It was widely reported that the bill only narrowly received cabinet approval, and I have not seen that report refuted. Nor did the bill have an easy passage through the Labor caucus. Caucus chairman, Jim Snow, broke ranks and went public saying that he opposed the bill because Australia is a tolerant society—and becoming more tolerant—and that `if you don't need legislation then its better not to have it.'

Government minister, Gary Johns, opposed it for similar reasons. So did the Labor member for Kalgoorlie, Graeme Campbell. Even more significant, perhaps, was the opposition from former senior ministers in the Hawke and Keating governments and former senators John Button and Peter Walsh. Former Leader of the Government in the Senate, John Button, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I worry about the need for it, and whether, in fact, it may not be counterproductive. The most worrying thing about racial vilification (legislation) is the arguments of those in favour of it.

Former finance minister Peter Walsh went further. He wrote, before the bill was introduced, `The whole idea should be thrown out.' But of course the Racial Hatred Bill has many other critics. Indeed, I can think of few bills that have attracted as widespread criticism as this bill. One respected commentator, Mr B.A. Santamaria, has even been moved to describe it as `one of the worst pieces of legislation ever put up in this country.'

PARA.TAB: The government should not be surprised that the bill has attracted the strong criticism it has. In the course of its consultative process during the preparation of the bill, the Attorney-General's Department received no less that 646 submissions. Interestingly, and revealingly, the department omitted to consult with several major community organisations. Of the 646 submissions, 563 were opposed to racial vilification legislation. Only 83—that is, less than 15 per cent—were in support of the legislation. Of the 563 opposed, the three largest reasons given, according to the Attorney-General's Department, were that `it restricts freedom of speech'—209 submissions; `too often well intentioned legislation causes as much mischief and division as it does good, it promotes racism'—47 submissions; and it is `undemocratic, un-Australian'—42 submissions.

Of the 83 in support, the only two reasons that attracted double figures were that `the legislation can stop racism, religious bigotry, which is the cause of most problems'—47 submissions; and it `protects against jokes at the expense of some members of the community'—12 submissions. It is highly questionable whether the bill would do either of these things.

The bill has met with a very mixed response from people and organisations of non-English speaking background. It was these very people and organisations primarily that the bill presumably was designed to protect from racist comments and actions.

It would be true to say that the Jewish community generally—but not unanimously by any means—supports the bill. The same could be said of the Chinese community. As well, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia publicly supports the bill, despite some apparent ignorance about its content, even if privately there are differing views amongst its members. The coalition fully respects these sincerely held views by supporters of the bill. We understand the feelings behind them, even if we do not agree with the proposed solutions.

The coalition has not determined its position on the Racial Hatred Bill in a vacuum nor, as I have made clear, has it reached this position hastily. The Liberal and National parties have consulted widely with Australians of non-English speaking background since the bill has been introduced. We have also noted carefully the published views expressed by many of these people, including in relation to the bill's predecessor. Let me quote just a few of these views.

Arabs have been identified as one of the four most vilified groups in Australia yet the Australian Arab Association has written, `We strenuously oppose this bill.' It gives detailed reasons for that. The Australian Arabic Council, although less condemnatory of the bill than the Australian Arab Association, also stresses the value of education over legislation. The council writes:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe only (multipronged education strategies) seriously address the roots of racism and ignorance, whereas legislation addresses the symptoms.
The council adds:

In the end, the bill becomes a token gesture, or what some proponents of the bill would call an educational tool. The most vilified groups prefer more substantial educational measures which permeate the most powerful institutions responsible for spreading misinformation which then creates fertile ground for racism.
The Australian Lebanese Association has expressed major concerns about the bill. It says:
The sledgehammer of legislation will not do much in helping to eradicate racial hatred.
The Islamic Society of Victoria says:

The proposed legislation has a false sense of security and may prove problematic . . . In some cases it may backfire . . . An argument may be put that some protection (such as this proposed bill) is better than nothing. The fact remains (however) that a bad law is not worth having at all . . .

Victoria's only Islamic community worker, Abdullah Ayan, believes existing laws are sufficient, and that institutional prejudices are `far more insidious' than `overt racism by fringe groups'. He adds:
Quite frankly, for these (racist) attitudes to be aired is very healthy because you can respond to them. If you shut them up and lock them up I don't think that does anything.

A similar attitude underlies the personal opinion of the coordinator of the Hellenic Council of New South Wales, Mr Costas Vertzayas. He says, `Free speech is above and beyond and over every other consideration.' He believes the existing laws give sufficient recourse without infringing on free speech.

PARA.TAB: The Macedonian Community Council of Melbourne and Victoria considers that the government's bill `encourages stronger ethnic communities to take action to prevent weaker communities from legitimate free speech'. Leaders of the Vietnamese and Cambodian communities, including the President of the Vietnamese Community Association of Australia and the President of the Federation of Vietnamese Women's Associations in Australia, are on record opposing the government's bill.

Other organisations that have advised the coalition of their opposition to the government's bill include the Association of German Speaking Communities, the Baltic nations communities, the Council of Hungarian Associations, the Federation of Ukrainian Associations, the United Kingdom Settlers Association, the Australian Romanian Association, the Czechoslovakian Association and many others.

It is also important to note that the man many regard as the father of multiculturalism in Australia, Professor Jerzy Zubrzycki, is on the public record as saying that it is counterproductive to legislate against racial vilification, that you cannot legislate against deeply ingrained attitudes, and that education is the only real route to go. The coalition shares this view. We believe that multiculturalism can only flourish where basic rights and liberties, and, in particular, freedom of speech are enshrined. To have otherwise is ultimately to undermine multiculturalism.

In addition to the criticisms voiced by representatives of Australians of overseas origin, grave concerns have also been expressed by many other leading figures and respected commentators in the Australian community. Time does not permit me going into them in detail. I hope to do that in the committee stage.

I have today deliberately quoted extensively the views of many Australians to reflect their feelings about the Racial Hatred Bill. I have done so because I want to make it absolutely clear that the Liberal and National parties' opposition to this bill is shared by wide sections of the Australian community, including in particular many of those persons the bill ostensibly is designed to protect.

I conclude by repeating what I said at the outset of my remarks today. The Liberal-National coalition yields to no person, to no organisation, in the intensity of our abhorrence of any form of racism, any racist actions or attitudes in our tolerant, multicultural society. We all have a responsibility, a fundamental duty to one another, to do all we can to stamp out racism wherever it may appear, in ways consistent with the maintenance, preservation, and strengthening of the basic values and institutions that are the cornerstone of making our society and our way of life the envy of virtually all other peoples and all other nations on earth.

The government's Racial Hatred Bill contains the seeds of undermining these values and institutions. It is accepted without exception that the only viable long-term effective approach to the attack on racism is through education. That is why the coalition has pledged itself in government to an extensive $10 million, two-year multipronged education campaign, the full details and content of which will be finalised after extensive consultations with ethnic communities, educators and other appropriate persons. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed a great honour to follow the speech delivered by my friend and colleague Senator Short on the Racial Hatred Bill. It goes to the heart of many of these matters, but I wish to lay before the Senate today a personal view of racism and how to fight it.

PARA.TAB: My starting point is a speech that was delivered by a black man on a sweltering summer's day in Washington DC in the 1960s, a man called Martin Luther King, who gave a speech which went down in history, a speech in which he said, `I have a dream.' He went on to outline that dream in terms that one day a man would be judged not by the colour of his skin but by the quality of his character. They are mighty words. He said something else, which is also important. He ended his speech with the words `Let freedom ring'.

For Martin Luther King, racial equality was a necessary condition to achieve a greater purpose, and the greater purpose was to deliver true freedom to the people of the United States of America. We should think not just of the words `I have a dream'; we should think too of the words `Let freedom ring'. We should ask ourselves, `Is it the appropriate way in this country, at the end of this century, to achieve racial harmony by constraining freedom under the tyranny of unnecessary law?', and that is the question at issue here today.

For me, I say unequivocally that attempting to force people into racial harmony will never achieve the purpose that it sets out to attain. It runs the grave risk that, instead of uniting people, legislation such as that which is before the Senate today will divide them.

Why does legislation divide people in this fashion? Legislation such as this divides people because it encourages them to think of themselves in particular terms. It encourages people to define themselves and to define others by virtue of their race, their distinguishing characteristics, instead of defining themselves and others by their nationality and equality before the law—things which, in our constitutional system, are not distinguishing characteristics but unifying characteristics.

The great strength of our country is this: that I was born in this country in 1965 before the Holt coalition government abolished the White Australia Policy, that my grandfather moved my family to this country permanently in the 1930s, and yet I can stand here the equal of any honourable senator in this place and as a representative of my state, irrespective of racial origin. That is the strength of this nation. That is the great quality which we must preserve, and all of that has been achieved without this legislation.

If Australia was a racist country, if Queensland was a racist state, then I would not be standing before honourable senators here today. I am living proof that this country is one of the most tolerant nations on earth, and I give this warning: we meddle with that basic tolerance at our peril.

Now let me address some of the detailed issues raised by this bill so that not just those in this Senate chamber here today but those listening and those who will subsequently read this Hansard will understand clearly why I join my coalition colleagues proudly in opposition to the thrust of the provisions of this bill.

Let us turn first of all to the criminal sanctions because I believe it is a grave threat to society that people are allowed to make racist threats against other people's property or against their person. I believe that is a danger to the whole harmonious base of this nation, but it is such a grave threat that this government only accords it in this legislation a maximum 12-month gaol penalty. Senator Spindler, who spoke before me, pointed out that to make the same threat in the state of Queensland, my home state, without having to prove a racist cause, can earn somebody a maximum seven-year gaol penalty.

So much for the seriousness with which this government views that punitive crime, and it is an absurdity to say that a gaol sentence for racist threats against property, which is one-seventh the gaol sentence for threats against property without a racist motivation, is proof of this government's intent to stamp out racism. What it is, is proof that this government decided it would embark upon this course of legislation to try to score votes, but it could not even unify its own people behind some decent penalty system. There are many better ways in which to deal with the issue.

A racist threat against a person, or a racist threat against a person's property, is quite rightly a greater wrong than a simple threat without that motivation. A threat which involves race is an aggravating factor and in my mind ought to be treated at sentence as an aggravating factor. But you do not create some sort of second-class crime to deal with issues of race and say that it is proof that the government is intent on stamping out racism.

One of the great problems as far as I am concerned with this legislation is the attitude of paternalism that says certain people are almost like endangered species—they need to be locked up in special legislation. Well, I find that offensive. I find it offensive that I might be categorised as somebody who needs special legislation, and for the benefit of honourable senators on the other side, I can assure them that I am not an endangered species, but what I can assure them is that the underlying philosophy of this legislation, which is the underlying philosophy of the politically correct, is an endangered philosophical species, an endangered philosophical concept.

Is it not interesting that elsewhere around the world where political correctness bloomed into the social and political landscape some time before it reached our shores, people are already saying it is time to eradicate and eliminate political correctness and instead move onto a different vista, a vista which encompasses a society that can look at itself and its neighbours without having to have legislation to tell it how to think. You see, I believe that the true mark of maturity in a society is when the society itself is willing to accept different members with different qualities and characteristics and accept that they are equal without having been told to think that they are equal.

You cannot tell people what they must and must not think, and harder still is the concept of telling people what they must and must not feel because I think sometimes people feel things without even thinking them. You will never stamp that out with legislation. You will never end these things by saying, `We're going to pass a law.' Senator Spindler, whom I know to be for very honest reasons a solid proponent of this legislation, himself admitted today that this legislation will not stamp out racism. My grave concern is that this legislation, instead of narrowing the gap between Australians of different ethnic backgrounds, widens the gap because it encourages people to look on others as different instead of looking on them as equal Australians.

I know this from my own experience. One of my very good friends is Basil Tambanis, who I think is half Greek and half Yugoslav. He and I rib each other mercilessly, but at the end of the day we have in common one thing: that we accept each other into something which is uniquely Australian. We accept each other into the bond of mateship. As an Australian, nothing can be higher, nothing can be more privileged than to share mateship with a fellow Australian, and we can achieve this without legislation telling us that that is how we have to think or how we have to feel, but it does require a maturity of character to judge people by their behaviour, by their values, by their principles and by their fundamental worth rather than judging them on whether they should be accorded particular consideration because of the colour of their skin. That is the flaw of this legislation.

I find it extraordinary that this legislation is going to create a situation where people can take other people to court because they are offended by something they happen to say. I was brought up to believe that one of the reasons we fought the Second World War was to fight Nazism and tyranny, and Nazism and tyranny were based in part on telling people how to think. I remember being in primary school and being told that there were people who said of others that they disagreed with what others had to say but that they would fight and die to defend their right to say it. Yet here we have legislation which, instead of defending the right of people to say things, allows people to take others to court because they do not like what somebody has said. It is a big bad world outside these doors, and it is not always fair and it is not always kind, but the measure of a man or a woman's character, the quality of them themselves, is their ability to tolerate that with which they do not agree because they recognise that tolerance builds a stronger community.

This legislation says to Australians outside who have struggled for decade after decade after decade to achieve that tolerance that it was all in vain because we can sort it out by taking people to court. I think that is sad. If the aim of the government is to create a more harmonious, more tolerant society, we do not make people more tolerant of others by suing them. We make people more tolerant by making peace.

In Brisbane last year an advertising firm inadvertently upset the Chinese community with a notice they distributed about where they were moving to and why. Passions got very heated, and people were ringing up the advertising company threatening to cut people's tongues out. The sensible people in the Chinese community and the sensible people in the advertising company said, `There is a better way to sort this out.' They sat around the table together and all the differences were fixed up. But if this legislation had been in place, instead of sitting around the table and talking, they would have been sitting across a table and litigating, and that is not the way in which we strengthen the fundamental democratic institutions of this nation, nor is it the manner in which we should improve racial cooperation, one group with another.

Here is the government bringing this legislation forward when this Labor government is perhaps the most arrogant, discriminatory political party in the history of this nation. I started this speech by saying that I was born in 1965, the time of the White Australia Policy. It was not the coalition that created the White Australia Policy. It was not the coalition that refined the White Australia Policy year after year, act of parliament after act of parliament. The political heirs of the group who brought the White Australia Policy to these shores sit not here amongst the coalition but on the other side of the chamber in the Australian Labor Party. This is part of their attempt to whitewash their shameful part in Australia's history. To my fellow ethnic Chinese, to my friends who are Greek and Italian, Macedonian, Irish, whatever they may be—

TALK.START.PARA: —German.

—German as well, Senator Abetz. I say that it is time this nation lifted its sights instead of lowering them and looked for what can be achieved together instead of what will result when we divide ourselves apart.

PARA.TAB: And so I look again to the words of Martin Luther King Jr. I look again to words like:
I had a dream that one day on the red hills of Georgia the sons of former slaves and the sons of former slave owners will be able to sit down together at the table of brotherhood.

SPEECH.PARA: And I know that is possible here. That is possible here in this country only if we let freedom ring, if we let this nation lift its sights and not lower them and if we together, undistinguished by the divisions created by this legislation, recognise and achieve a common destiny as Australians equal and undivided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some 20 years ago, the Racial Discrimination Act encapsulated our community's recognition of the need to protect the vulnerable from racially motivated discrimination. We acknowledged in the clearest possible terms that racism is intolerable. It degrades, discriminates and threatens. At its worst, it injures and kills. Its foundation is a belief in inequality as the natural order of things and the exclusion and alienation of certain groups from society, its services and its benefits. Racism devalues the equality, worth and dignity of every person. It is essentially antidemocratic.

PARA.TAB: Individual acts of racism range from the unpleasant through to active denial of rights and violence. Many of these acts are not illegal, nor should they be, however abhorrent. However, the Racial Discrimination Act and now the Racial Hatred Bill identify the point at which citizens' rights to live free from intimidation, harassment, discrimination and violence override the individual's rights to engage in extreme racist acts.

My personal abhorrence of racism grew out of my experiences as a child living in Fiji. I witnessed racist behaviour, discrimination and prejudice towards Fijian and Indian people; and it angered me. These views were reinforced when I briefly visited South Africa and experienced apartheid first hand. Seeing people being told which public toilet or park bench they could use, based on the colour of their skin, left a disturbing and deep impression upon me. Like most Australians, I have grown comfortable with the perception of Australians as fair minded and egalitarian, and

SPEECH.PARA: celebrated the multicultural diversity of our nation. It is predominantly only our treatment of Aboriginal Australians that disturbs that self-image. We too often turn a blind eye to the racism that exists within our society.

PARA.TAB: Inquiries have consistently concluded that Aboriginal and ethnic Australians experience discrimination, threats and actual physical violence as part of their everyday life in this country. In considering this bill, senators must be mindful that, as predominantly white middle class Anglo-Saxon males, we have a different perspective from that of the victims of racist behaviour. How many of us have been subjected to abuse in the streets, damage to our home or businesses, or campaigns exhorting our banishment or murder simply because of our race, colour or national or ethnic origin? The victims of extreme racism look to the federal parliament for leadership and action that will assist them to live as freely from this sort of behaviour as you or I. I believe the parliament has an obligation to provide that protection.

The Racial Hatred Bill fills the gap in uncoordinated state and federal law and seeks to protect our citizens from harassment, threats and the incitement of racial hatred, which leads inevitably to violence. It incorporates a substantial public input into the government's 1992 bill and overcomes problems identified with the New South Wales legislation. It adds to the Racial Discrimination Act by further defining what kinds of extreme public racist conduct are not acceptable to our community. It does this in two ways. Firstly, it creates three criminal offences by amending the Crimes Act. Secondly, it establishes a civil prohibition against racial harassment.

The first two criminal offences prohibit threats against people and property because of race, colour or national or ethnic origin. However, criminality now attracts where the basis of the threat is race, colour or national or ethnic origin. Perhaps even more significantly, it affords protection where there is no single person threatened, but a group of people identifiable by their race. Incitement law currently requires one person to convince another to commit a specific crime. If a murder should follow a racist leader exhorting followers, say, to get Asians, the leader would not be criminally culpable. Likewise, defamation laws protect individuals, but not groups, from defamatory lies.

The third offence dealing with incitement of racial hatred has generated the most vigorous community debate, primarily because of its perceived impact on free speech. This provision prohibits public acts done with the intention of inciting, and which are likely to incite, racial hatred. It seeks to properly protect our citizens and society from the undeniable harm that is done when people set out publicly and intentionally to persuade others that a certain group is deserving of hatred, harassment, discrimination, threats and violence. It targets intentional, extreme public acts which are likely to cause harm or hatred.

The government expects that the criminal provisions contained in this bill will rarely be used. They deal only with extreme racist behaviour. As with all Commonwealth human rights legislation, the major emphasis is on conciliation of complaints by way of amendments to the Racial Discrimination Act which provide for a civil prohibition against racial harassment. These provisions enable a victim to complain to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission about public behaviour that is reasonably likely to offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate an individual or group on the basis of their race, colour or national or ethnic origin. Broad exemptions to these provisions ensure that ideas and discussions can flow freely and without restriction in matters of public interest. Debate in good faith about sensitive issues will not be stifled.

The bill's civil provisions reflect the successful formula used to deal with sexual harassment in the 1983 Sex Discrimination Act. At that time the parliament recognised that harassment, as a particularly damaging form of discrimination, required specific legislative provisions. No-one has yet explained to me why the parliament should protect people from sexual harassment but not racial harassment. As with domestic violence and sexual assault law, this bill recognises that existing general criminal law is inadequate to deal with this important issue.

This package of criminal and civil provisions provides a comprehensive foundation to deal with extreme racism within the community. Like the Racial Discrimination Act this bill does not seek to eliminate racism, nor could it. A law alone cannot change what people think. What the law can change, however, is public behaviour, behaviour which is well along the continuum towards actual violence, which causes a person to suffer discrimination and harms our society as a whole.

There is overwhelming international and local evidence of growing racial intolerance and of the need for appropriate and measured legislative responses. Neo-Nazi activity is rising in affluent western Europe. What is perhaps more frightening is the political success of unabashedly racist movements such as Le Pen's National Front in France, the fascists in Italy, the Liberal Democrats in Russia and the British National Party.

The growth of the Australian Neo-Nazi movement has seen violent racist demonstrations against Asians and Jewish peoples and held in a number of our state capitals. In my own state of Western Australia, the Australian Nationalist Movement waged a war of bombing and terror against our local Asian communities. Three major Australian reports on racism starkly document incidents of racial harassment and violence in our society. The Australian Law Reform Commission report into multiculturalism and the law, the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and the 1992 national inquiry into racist violence all found abundant examples of racially motivated private property damage, destruction of religious or cultural symbols, physical and verbal assaults, and public harassment and humiliation. The desecration of Eddie Mabo's grave and Jewish graves and the exposure of the Loyal Guardians reinforce those studies.

Extreme racism is not confined to fringe groups or to the ill-educated. Surveys of university students show that racism is alive and well among our educated elite. It pervades our sporting codes and racial bullying and violence have recently been reported at one of Perth's most exclusive private schools. Thousands of racially motivated acts of violence and harassment occur every year in Australia. Racism is not under control but, rather, it is on the increase.

The United Nations has recognised its responsibility to respond to the growth in racism by declaring 1995 the Year of Tolerance. It has urged information, legislation and education to combat the resurgence of racism and intolerance. Australia has yet to fulfil its obligations contingent upon its international treaty obligations. Both the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights commit Australia to action beyond that already contained in the Racial Discrimination Act.

While it is currently popular to deride international treaty obligations, I believe it is important that we honour those commitments made on behalf of Australia. Passage of this bill would rectify that inadequacy in relation to racial hostility and racial violence. There are those who argue that this legislation is not necessary or that in enacting the bill we will be paying too high a price. Central to the arguments of those opposing the bill is the proposition that it would impose an intolerable restriction on free speech. Free speech is a fundamental tenet of democracy. Any proposed restriction on it draws appropriately vigorous debate in our community. But free speech has never been unfettered or absolute. As Lionel Murphy declared:

SPEECH.PARA: Free speech is only what is left after due weight has been accorded to the laws relating to defamation, blasphemy, copyright, sedition, obscenity, use of insulting words, official secrecy, contempt of court and Parliament, incitement and censorship.

No-one in this debate is suggesting any repeal of these speech crimes. We accept restrictions on free speech because of the potentially harmful link between words and actions. We accept restrictions on free speech where the proximity of the words to harm or damage is such that victims are entitled to expect protection. We balance the rights of the speaker and the rights of the victim. In the recent political advertising decision, two High Court justices noted the restrictions on free speech are justified only if they do not exceed:

. . . what is reasonably necessary for the preservation of an orderly and democratic society, or for the protection or vindication of the legitimate claims of individuals to live peacefully and with dignity in such a society.

This, in my view, is such a case! Public speech with the intent of inciting racial hatred is not just an expression of opinion or ideas. It is dangerous conduct that is designed to intimidate, frighten, harass and discriminate. It creates the environment in which more active and extreme forms of racism thrive. It undermines the very cohesion and tolerance we rely on as a largely successful multicultural society. It potentially escalates violence in that all members of a group identifying with a victim share the sense of injustice, fear and possible desire for revenge.

PARA.TAB: To protect this form of speech over the right to live free from fear, harassment, discrimination and violence, I believe misunderstands the whole doctrine of free speech. Surely the intentional promotion of racial hatred is as damaging to society as a misleading prospectus or video pirating.

Could extreme racism be tackled without restricting free speech, the government would have done so. However, without words, racism cannot exist; without words, racist ideas and objectives cannot be formulated; and, without words, ideology condoning discrimination and violence against certain groups cannot gain supporters and activists. That being the case, the point along the continuum at which that speech becomes sufficiently damaging and harmful to warrant civil or criminal action must be determined. This bill establishes that point on the continuum and strikes the appropriate balance between the right to free speech and the right to be protected from racial hatred and its consequences.

Some opponents of the bill, and in particular those who oppose the criminal provisions, argue that an education campaign be pursued as the sole alternative strategy. That education confronts racist attitudes is self-evident, and I am the first to support the extension of education programs that promote tolerance. However, those who support education without legislative backing give insufficient weight to law as the ultimate educative tool. Legislation is a powerful statement of public policy and defines community values that have evolved through public debate and discussion.

In this case, we are declaring as a community that behaviour promoting or causing racial hatred, harassment or violence will not be tolerated. The legislative expression of these values influences behaviour and, in time, attitudes. Like Senator O'Chee, I turn to the words of Martin Luther King but I think this quote is slightly more pertinent. Mr King said:

SPEECH.PARA: Morality cannot be legislated, but behaviour can be regulated. Judicial decrees may not change the heart, but they restrain the heartless.

Mr King also points out that most citizens are deterred from acting unlawfully unless there is some pressing reason to do otherwise. Of course, attitudes are affected by legislation. The Sex Discrimination Act is a good example of federal legislation affecting community attitudes. Whilst the SDA could never have eliminated sexism, I challenge anyone to suggest that it has not been a significant force in the considerable changes that have occurred in our society's attitude toward women and their role in it.

PARA.TAB: This bill gives force and framework to the education process regarding racial hatred in Australia. However, it does not represent a particularly radical legislative measure. The New South Wales Greiner government introduced the first Australian racial hatred legislation six years ago, with the unanimous support of that state parliament. Together with the ACT, Queensland and WA, all now have some form of criminal racial hatred laws. With the exception of WA, all of these jurisdictions also have civil provisions. This bill complements and adds to the relevant state laws.

Numerous countries have banned racial hatred and violence for many years. These laws have sustained through conservative periods of rule in Canada, New Zealand, Germany, Great Britain and some states in the United States of America. Despite protestations to the contrary, there is no evidence of a proliferation of free speech martyrs in any of these jurisdictions. Neither has there been any reports or evidence of laws being used as a weapon in inter-ethnic conflict. In three years of debate, no such examples have been proffered. Not one of the extreme racists currently in gaol in Australia, like Jack Van Tongeren, have become any class of martyr in our society.

I do not know quite what to make of the attitudes of the opposition parties. The history of their about-turns and contradictions on this issue is too complicated to recount. In March coalition inaction had become so embarrassing that John Fahey told ABC radio that Liberal turmoil over the bill reflected the party's deeper divisions. Never a truer word was said.

Senator Vanstone earlier today made a valiant attempt to put a constructive face on this Liberal Party turmoil. But, on every piece of social legislation debated in this parliament—be it native title law or this Racial Hatred Bill—the deep divisions between the liberals and the conservatives that constitute the Liberal Party have been exposed. It is ironic that Liberals in this place are always demanding government members withdraw words used in debate that they find unacceptable. They are sensitive to verbal abuse. Why will they not recognise the sensitivity of those subjected to far more hurtful and far more dangerous language?

Ultimately, I do not think those opposite are serious about confronting racial hatred. Even Senator Vanstone, who has unsuccessfully sought to reconcile the extreme views that exist within the coalition, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe, if you want to express those deep seated feelings, even if it is hatred, and you want to encourage others to agree with you, you should be allowed to.
Clearly, we are in fundamental disagreement.

PARA.TAB: I want to address a couple of remarks about the position of the Greens. I understand the strong views Senator Chamarette has about imprisonment as a solution for inappropriate behaviour and have some sympathy for her view. To her I would make three points. Firstly, imprisonment is the punishment of last resort and the bill incorporates many other more effective and less severe means of punishment. Secondly, the success or otherwise of rehabilitating aberrant behaviour is only one consideration in our criminal justice system. Equally important is the protection of individuals and the community and the deterrent function of the law. If you accept the link between racial hatred and violence, you must accept that, in extreme cases, the victims need protection from perpetrators. Thirdly, the overwhelming focus of the bill is in the civil sanctions, which I believe the Greens support.

My support for this bill is not motivated by any attempt to be more self-righteous than the opposition, nor by a pitch for the so-called ethnic vote. But it is true that I have listened to those subject to racist attacks in our community. Ethnic Australia has strongly supported the government bill as the appropriate response to this growing problem. They do so because the government consulted fully with ethnic and racial groups and listened to what they had to say in drafting this bill.

The importance of the victims' perspective was vividly reinforced for me at a meeting of the Chung Wah Young Professionals Group in Perth, which I attended—together with Daryl Williams, the member for Tangney—to debate this bill. A distressing number of group members related their personal experiences of racist behaviour. For them, racism and incitement to racial hatred were not nebulous concepts but painful, frightening and degrading personal experiences which are all too common.

Dr Eric Tan, a highly respected Western Australian and leader of the local Chinese community, offered compelling evidence of what will continue to be the case should this parliament forgo its responsibilities and fail to legislate in this matter. Dr Tan led the Chinese community during the years when the Australian Nationalist Movement terrorised the local Asian community in Perth. Dr Tan expressed his frustration at being unable to get the police to take seriously the threats and expressions of racial hatred espoused by that repugnant group. The police were unable to intervene in the ANM's activities.

The Chinese community felt isolated and abandoned as these racists spread their hate throughout Perth. Only when the ANM had progressed to firebombing of Asian restaurants and murder, thus committing offences against the then WA Criminal Code, were authorities able to effectively deal with the organisation. If this legislation had been in place, effective action could have been taken before the ANM progressed along that path to violence and murder.

That debate, the comments from the audience, and discussion with people afterwards, strongly reinforced my support for this legislation. All the education programs money can buy would not have protected those citizens from the ANM; nor would any amount of counselling have deterred the ANM from their destructive path.

I strongly urge all senators to support this important legislation. What better, more effective means do we as a parliament have to communicate our abhorrence of racism in all its forms. What stronger message can we send to the community that extreme racist behaviour is intolerable. This bill offers the parliament the chance to play the greatest educative role that it can possibly play in the ongoing battle against racism.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill is appropriately entitled the Racial Hatred Bill because, if enacted, it will unwittingly assist those few in the community who believe that they are better or superior because of the colour of their skin or their cultural background. The true value of our fellow human beings is to be determined by their personality, their morality, their integrity—in other words, their character and not the colour of their skin or their cultural background. I stand here along with my Liberal colleagues implacably opposed to the peddlers of racial hatred. My own party, when it was formed some 50 years ago, had as one of its 17 founding principles as set out in We Believe the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe in religious and racial tolerance among our citizens.

That was the Liberal stance 50 years ago. It remains the stance today. Labor has—as did Senator Chris Evans in his contribution that has just gone before—sought to rewrite history by portraying the Labor Party as the party of promoting tolerance. History will tell us otherwise. Let me give a few examples. A former Labor Premier of New South Wales, a man the Prime Minister idolises, Jack Lang, was a well-known anti-semite and supporter of the White Australia policy. A former leader of Senator Evans's party, Arthur Calwell, had a number of things to say, for example:
Japanese women should not be allowed to pollute our shores.
That was leader of the Australian Labor Party. In 1972 he said:

If Australians are ever foolish enough to open their gates in a significant way to people other than Europeans, they will soon find themselves fighting desperately to stop the nation being flooded by hordes of non-integratables.
Just before he died in 1973 Arthur Calwell said:
No red-blooded Australian wants to see a chocolate coloured Australia in the 1980s.

What a proud tradition the Australian Labor Party has! But that deals with a past generation of Labor Party politicians. What about the present generation? Nobody encapsulates that better than the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who said in his maiden speech on 17 March 1970:
It is time we considered the enormous cost of bringing migrants to this country. . . After all, the best migrant is the infant Australian.

How is that supposed to make people like Senator McKiernan, Senator Spindler and me feel? What sort of attitude does that develop amongst the Australian born to migrants? I ask the rhetorical question: what sentiment does that develop towards migrants such as the Prime Minister's own wife? The callousness and harshness of the Prime Minister's comments will never be undone without a full recantation by the Prime Minister. His arrogance will unfortunately deny him this honourable course. If we need another classic example of Labor's attitude we need look no further than the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), who undoubtedly is off to address another League of Rights meeting shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I am very concerned about those remarks attributed to the Prime Minister, including understanding what is in his mind and callous attitudes, et cetera. I draw the attention of Senator Abetz to the comments made by his colleague Senator Vanstone, who said that this debate was not about who would re-establish the high moral ground. So it would be of enormous assistance if he respected the Prime Minister's and other people's views and got on with his comments.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Minister, there is no point of order. As you well know, it is a debating point the senator is making. I ask you not to take frivolous points of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a shameful waste of my time. We on this side have tried to give everybody their full 20 minutes. As soon as you start scoring points off members of the Labor Party they change the rules. The minister clearly did not listen to her own Labor backbencher. Senator Evans tried to get stuck into our side of politics on this matter. All I was doing was quoting verbatim what was said by Labor members past and present.

PARA.TAB: In contradistinction, the Liberal Party has a proud record in the area of racial tolerance. We believe that the way to deal with people's prejudice and ignorance is through education. It is ignorance that provides fertile ground for racism. As Mr Wakim, Secretary of the Australian Arabic Council, told the legal and constitutional legislation committee dealing with the Racial Hatred Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: The thrust of what we really want to inject into this discourse is not so much about the legislation, but to try and have a look at the roots of the problem rather than the symptoms, and have a look at how we can redress the ignorance that is a fertile ground for the racism in the first place, and we can redress the gap between the victim and the law, rather than the gap within the law.

That is why the coalition has proposed a $10 million fund for a multipronged education package. Because of my ongoing interest in this area I asked during estimates hearings what amount of money the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission had spent on public awareness programs in trying to fight manifestations of racism. The answer for the year 1993-94 was the princely sum of $123,000—the government is spending a lot more money on the defence of Dr Carmen Lawrence—hardly the sort of financial allocation one would expect from a government allegedly genuinely committed to the elimination of racial hatred.

PARA.TAB: I hope that my contribution to this point has set out in no uncertain terms the coalition's commitment to genuine racial tolerance and opposition to those who preach their poison of racial hatred and also our rejection of Labor's duplicity on this issue.

I turn to the specifics of the bill. The bill proposes the establishment of three new crimes. Firstly, there is the prohibition of threats to cause physical harm because of race, colour, national or ethnic origin; secondly, prohibition of threats to property because of race, colour, national or ethnic origin; and, thirdly, prohibition of incitement of racial hatred because of race, colour, national or ethnic origin. The head of power for the establishment of these new crimes is the external affairs power.

Criminal law has traditionally been the province of the states. The activities proposed to be outlawed by the first two crimes are already crimes in every state and territory of the Commonwealth and, might I add, they do it a lot better. During hearings by the legal and constitutional affairs committee I asked the following question in relation to the first two crimes:

SPEECH.PARA: Do you accept that all types of behaviour, irrespective of motivation, are already covered by criminal law in every single state and territory of the Commonwealth?
Mrs Jackson, Deputy Government Counsel, Civil Law, Attorney-Generals' Department, responded:
Yes, that is true.

Let me repeat the point that the proposed legislation will mean that there will be a lesser penalty if the crime is committed and prosecuted pursuant to these proposed new sections of the Crimes Act than if they were prosecuted under existing state legislation. Mr Pearce, of the Civil Liberties Council, told the committee:

But let me make this point about it . . . under section 198 of the Crimes Act in Victoria, for example, for the threat to damage property the penalty is 10 years. Under this legislation it is two years. Under this legislation you get time off for being a racist.

Clearly, the educational value of such an anomaly is in direct contrast to what the bill seeks to effect. This indicates that the legislation has not been thought out in the manner that it should have been. In fact, what has occurred is that under close scrutiny this legislation is now embarrassing Labor. It is noteworthy that Mr Pearce is from the Victorian Council of Civil Liberties, hardly an organisation committed to the promotion of racist ideals.

PARA.TAB: I am very strongly of the view that the way to deal with racists who commit crimes is to treat them as the common criminals they are. As Ms Wallace, also from the Council of Civil Liberties, said very succinctly:

SPEECH.PARA: Some 30 years ago, we had chronic domestic violence. We still do, but we have decided in the interim that defining domestic violence as violence, and prosecuting the people who perpetrate the violence on members of their family, that has made the difference. Not treating them as having a particular kind of violence, but treating them as ordinary perpetrators.
She went on:

And if there are levels of racial ignorance, you have a fertile ground for the growth of racism. We must address community ignorance about race, and about victims, and we must do it with a budget and with a knowledge that a budget has to be commensurate with the difficulty of the task in front of us.
We have committed $10 million to that fund.

PARA.TAB: In creating a separate crime, we run the risk of making political martyrs out of common criminals. Let us never forget that the extremists from all types of causes will go to gaol to make a statement. In my home state of Tasmania, the Greens are very well known for doing exactly that. I have no doubt that racists will also try the same tactic, especially in relation to proposed section 60, which deals with the third crime that is to be created. From that section, I believe that political martyrs may be born if prosecutions are raised. This provision will turn the expression of a view into a crime even if no threat or act of violence is perpetrated.
I join with John Stuart Mill when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We can never be sure that the opinion we endeavour to stifle is a false opinion, and if we were sure, stifling it would be an evil still.

The worldwide experience of this type of legislation has shown it to be a dismal failure, commencing in a country where, if it had been effective, one of the greatest tragedies ever inflicted upon humankind by humankind should have been avoided. I refer to the holocaust. Mr Borovoy says at page 50 of his book entitled When freedoms collide: the case for our civil liberties, which was published in 1988, the following:

Remarkably, pre-Hitler Germany had laws very much like the Canadian anti-hate law. Moreover, those laws were enforced with some vigour. During the 15 years before Hitler came to power, there were more than 200 prosecutions based on anti-semitic speech.
He goes on:

As subsequent history so painfully testifies, this type of legislation proved ineffectual on the one occasion when there was a real argument for it. Indeed, there is some indication that the Nazis of pre-Hitler Germany shrewdly exploited the criminal trials, in order to increase the size of their constituency. They used the trials as platforms to propagate their message.
Now, 60 years later, with the aid of mass communication, the platforms provided by such trials to propagate racist messages would be all the greater.

PARA.TAB: Let me add as an aside that this book by Mr Borovoy draws on journals such as Jewish Social Studies and Contemporary Jewish Record, the latter of which details that Joseph Goebbels was sentenced twice—once to three weeks and once to six weeks in prison—for insulting a Jewish deputy police commissioner of Berlin. The rest is, of course, a very shameful chapter of human history.

A very interesting article in the Australian Journal of Human Rights written by Anne Twomey is entitled `Laws against incitement to racial hatred in the United Kingdom'. At page 235, she makes the following observation:

SPEECH.PARA: Every time there is a review of these laws, the allegation is made that they are not achieving their functions, and should be amended. Although the problems are easy to identify, the solutions have been elusive and the Westminster Parliament is still struggling to find the best approach.
She concludes at page 248 with this further observation:
