Experience in the United Kingdom has again shown that many of the most notorious racists are capable of avoiding conviction under such legislation, and that it is often members of minority groups who do not have the same access to legal advice who are caught by the legislation.

If the aim of racial vilification legislation is to set out community standards of behaviour, then it may well achieve this objective. However, one might wonder whether there are other less coercive means of achieving the same results.
I endorse Anne Twomey's perceptive observations.

PARA.TAB: This legislation has unfortunately drawn division within the ethnic communities and has also been misunderstood by the very top people in the ethnic communities. For those who might be interested, on 17 February 1995, at page 289 of the Hansard, Mr Rebikoff, the president of FECCA, the Federation of Ethnic Community Councils of Australia, said this to the committee:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . We are talking about a sanction being imposed in the most extreme situation. We are not talking about this legislation reverting to the immediate course of criminal sanction. We are saying that you go through the conciliation process first, depending on the seriousness of that offence.
His legal adviser, Mr Lacey, then interrupted him. The Hansard shows that he says this:
Not quite. They are two entirely separate sanctions.

The unfortunate thing is that Mr Rebikoff had gone right around Australia promoting this legislation on the misunderstanding of how it would work. Of course he was getting support for it, but unfortunately he failed to understand it.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe that Mr Rebikoff did that with any malintention. But the simple fact is that he was wrong and he sold it incorrectly. Now that the ethnic communities understand the difficulties with the legislation, they have written to people such as Senator Short, whom I congratulate for giving a most excellent address and for his detailed consultation with the various ethnic communities in this country.

If we turn to the civil sanctions that this bill provides, it is noteworthy that Mr Peter Bailey, in his evidence to our committee, suggested that proposed section 60 ought to be removed from the criminal area and put into the civil area to overcome a whole host of problems, including the constitutionality of it, given the inherent right to freedom of speech discovered by the High Court in recent times. Mr Bailey's evidence was based on his background as a former human rights commissioner.
The opposition criticism of the civil sanctions is based on its broad framework. The legislation deals with such terms as `offend' and `insult'. Mr Pearce said:

SPEECH.PARA: Dealing first of all with the civil side, essentially the effect of that legislation will be to protect people from hurt feelings. The legislation is designed specifically, and in terms, to protect people from offence and insults.

No other legislation or principle of law that we are aware of in this country, has that effect. No other legislation or principle of the law that we are aware of seeks to protect people from hurt feelings. We say the government has no role as the guardian of hurt feelings.

We say that no case has been made out to give the government that role, and we say further that no case has been made out to why hurt feelings from racial abuse, as opposed to any of the many other forms of abuse to which people are subjected on a daily basis, ought to be singled out for special protection.

It is very easy to foresee a situation where people can be offended, insulted or humiliated on the basis of the colour of their hair or their lack of hair; their size, be it height, such as tall or short, or their width, be they thin or not so slim; if they wear glasses; or whether they have a large nose or chin; or on the clothes they wear. The range of possibilities is quite endless. I support the view of the Victorian Council for Civil Liberties in relation to this legislation going way over the top. The implications have not been thought out in a mature and sustained manner. With the current minister, we would not expect it to be considered in such a manner.

PARA.TAB: The legislation does provide defences if it is done in `good faith' or on a `scientific', `artistic' or `reasonable public interest' basis. If we are to have tribunals in this country that are to determine whether something said was in the proper pursuit of `scientific views' or `artistic performances', we are really getting into the realm of the `thought police' state. The idea that a tribunal might determine that somebody's experimentation or views will be classified as scientific but others not flies in the face of those fundamental freedoms of academic freedom and freedom of speech which we in the Liberal Party so strongly embrace.

I can foresee a situation where, given an unfortunate social climate within this country, a defence might be established on the basis of a `scientific pursuit'—indeed, that was Hitler's defence, was it not—or that a certain performance is `artistic', albeit that it is absolutely and utterly crass. To have those sorts of defences indicates how this legislation impinges on fundamental freedoms.
Unfortunately, because of the interruptions of Senator Crowley during my speech, I will undoubtedly run out of time. I seek leave to incorporate the remaining part of my speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: If those fundamental freedoms are impinged upon, we do not want the "thought police state" to develop even further where government, through its appointed people in the Human Rights Committee, will determine whether something is scientific or artistic. Clearly, this legislation goes too far and ought be condemned.

This legislation is far too broad, because the law tries to make unlawful practices which are merely socially unacceptable. Uncertainty of meaning means uncertainty in the law. And a fundamental for the rule of law to function effectively, is that there be certainty.

This legislation does not provide that type of certainty. Indeed, the only certainty it provides is, that it will be a bonanza for my profession, but on its way it will create heartache and hurt to countless people who will be inappropriately taken through the processes of this legislation.
Mr President, I look forward to dealing with the bill in more detail in the Committee stages.
Let me conclude by adopting Mr Bartlett's view, who so cogently summarised the defects of this legislation, when he said at page 345 of the Hansard:

"I would say that in my view the bill will do nothing to reduce or stop racial hatred. It seeks to take the easy approach of hitting any offender with a big stick, rather than the more difficult task of further encouraging multiculturalism through education and assimilation.
The process of multiculturalism and assimilation is continuing in this country, and it would not be encouraged by harsh, criminal and civil remedies."

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal Sen B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Racial Hatred Bill. This bill is another step forward in this government's commitment to protect all Australians from racism and to eliminate the fear and hatred that racism generates. Australia has a long and successful history of multiculturalism. Millions of migrants have settled in Australia to enjoy our high standard of living and our democratic system. Many settled in Australia precisely to escape racism and other tensions in their country of birth. The ethnic cleansing in the former Yugoslavia and Somalia and the second-class status of some indigenous people in their homelands are examples of the racism that many migrants travel to Australia to escape.

PARA.TAB: The Labor government and the Labor Party are committed to protecting all Australians from ethnically based violence that afflicts so many other nations. We on this side of the house have a fundamental belief that all Australians, irrespective of ethnicity, colour or nationality, have the right to fair treatment. This right necessarily entails freedom from racism and, more particularly, threats of violence based on racism.

Australians are already protected from racial discrimination in employment, accommodation and access to services, under the Racial Discrimination Act. The Racial Hatred Bill is designed to meet an entirely different need. Essentially, this bill has arisen out of a commitment to fighting the causes of extreme racist behaviour in Australia in order to guarantee that all Australians can live free from fear of racist agitation or abuse. I am happy to say that this commitment is supported by the overwhelming majority of senators and members in the parliament.

Obviously, the question of racial hatred laws is a difficult one. The government has to strike a balance between the right to free speech and the right of all Australians to live free from threats of racist violence or hatred. The balance between these two rights is the central component of the provisions of this bill. Put simply, the bill provides for separate civil and criminal remedies for offences motivated by racism. It amends the Racial Discrimination Act to allow individuals or groups who have been victims of racist or discriminative behaviour which is reasonably likely to offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate to pursue civil actions against the perpetrators.

It also amends the Crimes Act to make a criminal offence of threatening violence against a person or group on the basis of race, or publicly inciting others to racial hatred or contempt. These carry a maximum sentence of two years and one year's imprisonment respectively. Threats to property based on racism are also punishable by one year's imprisonment. I would stress that the terms of imprisonment are the maximum sentences and that other penalties are available of a lesser type—penalties such as fines, bonds and community service.

Firstly, I will deal with the civil offences. This first provision which allows civil proceedings against perpetrators of racist behaviour will close a gap in the existing racial discrimination law. This gap was identified by the National Inquiry into Racist Violence and the royal commission into black deaths in custody. Legal redress will be made available to individuals or groups who are victims of a public act that—to quote the bill—is likely to `offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate' on the basis of race.

This civil remedy is very similar to remedies available in the existing sexual harassment legislation, which has already been passed by the parliament and is well endorsed and supported by the Australian community at large. It allows a civil action to be taken by persons or groups who are victimised, intimidated or harassed without actually being physically assaulted.

There is some argument put forward that this legislation will have the effect of unjustifiably restricting private expressions of opinion or that it will be used to protect against offended sensibilities. This is not the case. The bill will only operate where the conduct complained of will adversely affect the quality of life and wellbeing of the groups affected.

There is a clear distinction here between simply entertaining a racist attitude and inflicting hurt and suffering on another on the basis of their race. It is my view, and that of other Labor senators, that the right to free speech is not harmed by this limitation to prevent intimidation of other Australians on racist grounds. I will now proceed to deal with the criminal offences set out in the bill.

The second set of provisions in this bill is the criminal sanctions, which make it a crime to threaten racist violence against people or property or to incite others to racial hatred. It is these provisions which have come under the most public attack from coalition members and senators.

The 1992 report of the National Inquiry into Racist Violence found that, whilst state and territory criminal law punishes the perpetrators of violent racism, it does not adequately deal with conduct that leads to this violence. The report documented 60 incidents of incitement to racial violence which were not subject to existing criminal sanction. The legislation makes it a crime to threaten to cause physical harm because of race, colour or national or ethnic origin, punishable by two years imprisonment. It also provides a maximum penalty of one year's imprisonment for threats to property on the same basis, as well as a one year penalty for intentional incitement of others to do so.

These provisions explicitly exclude acts carried out in private provided that they are not communicated to the public or done in, or within view of, a public place. Reactionary groups in Australia, as well as some members of the National Party, have been claiming that this legislation would detrimentally infringe upon the private actions of individuals and that the government is legislating to prevent people thinking particular thoughts or reading particular literature in their own homes. This is obviously incorrect and is based on an intentional misunderstanding of the bill.

This section of the bill is very narrowly focused. It does not prevent the public expression of racist views per se, nor does it prevent organisations from circulating racist material, except where it amounts to inciting racial hatred. The only activity that is restricted as being criminal by the bill is the public expression of violent threats and the incitement to racial hatred. Simply using particular words will not be subject to criminal action.

The Racial Hatred Bill has been subject to extensive public comment and scrutiny over the past few months. The principles of this bill reflect a wide canvassing of public opinion and have received widespread support from many new Australians and their respective representative groups. These include the Executive Council of Australian Jewry, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils, the Ethnic Coalition, the Australian Chinese Community Association of New South Wales, the Northern Metropolitan Migrant Resources Centre of New South Wales and the National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Services Secretariat.

Arguments raised against its implementation have included that it limits free speech and artistic expression, that it is unnecessary and that technical difficulties arise from the Brandy case. I will address a number of these concerns. The principal argument raised against this provision has been the right to free speech. It is claimed by various groups that the right to free speech includes the right to encourage others to commit racist violence or to threaten individuals or groups with racist violence. This is, frankly, ridiculous.

Few Australians would argue the right to free speech should be absolute. We all accept there must be laws limiting free speech on issues which are likely to cause harm to the fabric of our society and innocent members of the community. Current laws preventing the dissemination of child pornography or libellous allegations are a case in point. These laws recognise the need to legislate where free expression can cause serious damage to members of the community.

The right to freedom of speech does not arise in Australia from a bill of rights or any particular legislation. It is based on implied rights associated with the Commonwealth constitution and our common law tradition which were articulated in the recent High Court decisions of Australian Capital Television Pty Ltd v. The Commonwealth, and Nationwide News Pty Ltd v. Wills and subsequently reaffirmed in the cases of Theophanous v. Herald and Weekly Times and Stephens v. Western Australian Newspaper Ltd, which specifically related to the laws of defamation.

In the High Court's twin judgments of Australian Capital Television v. The Commonwealth, and Nationwide News Pty Ltd v. Wills, a majority of the court recognised a constitutional implication of freedom of political discussion. This derives from the principle of representative democracy which forms part of the Commonwealth constitution. Mr Justice Brennan described this right as `inherent in the idea of representative democracy' and went on to conclude:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . where a representative democracy is constitutionally entrenched, it carries with it those legal incidents which are essential to the effective makings of that form of government. Once it is recognised that a representative democracy is constitutionally prescribed, the freedom of discussion which is essential to sustain it is as firmly entrenched in the Constitution as a system of government which the Constitution expressly ordains.

In recognising the right of freedom of speech, the High Court also recognised that it was and should be limited in the interests of the common good. In fact, an extract from those cases was referred to in Senator Cooney's address. In order to determine when such a situation may arise, the court prescribed that a balancing process must be undertaken.

PARA.TAB: In this bill, the right to free speech has been balanced against the right to live free from fear of violence and harassment. It places no new limits on public debate of ideas or artistic expression, nor does it affect private conversations. Nothing that is said or done in good faith in the course of any public or private debate will be affected by this bill.

Similar legislation has been in force in New South Wales for the past five years and there is no evidence to suggest that New South Wales has become the police state that some would fear with the passing of this legislation. It could, in fact, be argued that the boundaries of this bill could be considerably widened without inhibiting free speech.

The bill before us does not affect the public expression of racist views, as long as these views do not incite racial hatred or violently threaten groups or individuals. It is my belief, however, that the public expression of non-violent racist views is also deeply offensive to most Australians. Nonetheless, the only avenue of expression that is curtailed by this bill is the expression of extreme threats of violence on racial grounds, and the public incitement to others to commit such acts of racist violence. Given this very narrow focus, there can be no genuine argument that free speech is in fact restricted.

Mr Fischer in the other chamber argued that this type of legislation was unnecessary because of Australia's record of racial harmony. It is true that in the large majority of cases different ethnic groups in Australia live in harmony, but there are exceptions to this rule and there is still a need for the protection that this bill affords. Page 299 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's Report of national inquiry into racist violence 1991 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The evidence presented to the inquiry indicated that some people are deliberately inciting racial hostility and, particularly in the case of racist graffiti and poster campaigns, getting away with it.

The truth of this observation was highlighted recently when the ACT opposition leader had cause to lodge a racial vilification complaint based on unsolicited mail from the Citizens Electoral Council. This mail links Aboriginal land claims with terrorism and claims that the emergence of an `Aboriginal identity will lead to a terrorist upsurge, precisely as they created the Shining Path of Peru'. Further, Mr Fischer has claimed that this legislation is a waste of time and that the government should deal with more important matters. In fact, he said:
This bill quite simply should not be before this House—not tonight, not tomorrow, not in the future—in this form or in any form . . .
The widespread support for this bill indicates that his opinion is not widely shared.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators have also raised the possibility that the application of this bill would limit artistic expression. Indeed, this has been a major focus of the opposition's attack on the bill, although it is not a view that I have heard expressed within the wider community. Artistic expression is specifically exempt from the effect of the bill. It would have to be a rather strange form of art that would seriously incite racist violence, in any case, which should put this fear to rest.

The opposition has claimed that the bill will prevent comedians from telling racist jokes. Senator Abetz, in particular, claimed that shows like Wogarama would be affected by the passage of this bill. This claim is completely incorrect and based on a misunderstanding of the nature of the legislation. The Wogarama comedians base many of their jokes and parodies on stereotypes of a particular ethnic community. They do not incite their audience to commit racial violence against that community. They do not encourage their audience to develop an attitude of hatred, contempt or severe ridicule of that community.

Senators Ellison and Abetz claimed before the Senate legal and constitutional committee that the existing law covers any criminal case that might be brought under the provisions of the Racial Hatred Bill and that, therefore, this bill is redundant. While I would agree that there may be some situations where the existing law currently applies, it does not cover all situations, particularly those relating to incitement to racial hatred. It is my view that there is an important educative and deterrent role in having this legislation enacted. This legislation sends a clear and direct message to those individuals and groups in our society that do encourage acts of violent racism that this government is serious in seeing these activities stopped.

Racism must be fought at the grassroots levels through educational campaigns and by publicity—and the government has indicated its support for this option as well. By openly confronting and dispelling racist claims, this bill is also playing its part. The opposition has belatedly indicated support for anti-racist education programs, and I welcome that. But legislation also plays its part and it indicates the strength of the government's commitment. If the laws that arise from this Racial Hatred Bill are never utilised, they will still have helped to spread the message that public, verbally violent racism will be strongly opposed by this government.

Our reputation as a multicultural nation that will not tolerate racism and racist violence is a very proud one. Extreme racism and racist violence are infrequent and, despite the great diversity of the Australian population, we have an excellent record in maintaining racial harmony.

This bill is not designed to engineer an end to all racist attitudes. No piece of legislation will—not in itself. But the opinions that are expressed in this bill target particular behaviour which threatens racist violence against the person, group or property and it provides a means of redress to those who have become victims of such violent acts. For this reason, this bill must receive the support of the Senate, and I commend it to senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might preface my remarks by recounting to the Senate an experience I had today when I was walking around the perimeter of this building. It was in one of the four corners of the perimeter of Parliament House that I came across a monument which had been erected by the Returned Services League in 1988 when this building was constructed. The monument was dedicated to all those who had fallen in previous wars on behalf of Australia in its defence.

PARA.TAB: There was in a bronze cast the hat of a sailor and the hat of a soldier. The inscription said, `Look around. This is what they believed in.' Indeed, I did that. I saw Parliament House; I saw the nation's capital; I saw law and order prevailing; I saw freedom in existence; and I saw this very building which houses the institution of democracy as we know it.

It was with this in mind that I approached today's debate on the Racial Hatred Bill dealing with racism in the community. Australia is indeed a free society. I believe it to be one of the freest societies in the world today. I also believe that Australia is free of a good many evils that exist overseas—evils such as political and religious intolerance and widespread racism. That does not mean, however, that we are not vigilant against those problems, against those cancers in a society. But let us approach this debate on the rational foundation that we are starting from a position where we have a society which is in fairly good shape.

When we look at legislation of this sort we then ask ourselves: does it transgress unduly on individual freedoms? Does it transgress on individual rights? Does it tip the scale towards one side of the argument at the expense of the other? No-one from the coalition side and, in fact, I believe quite frankly none of the 76 senators who sit in this place would condone in any way racist behaviour. It is my opinion that all 76 of us would wholeheartedly condemn racism in any shape or form. Having said that, we then have to look at this bill and see whether it does the job that it sets out to do and determine whether we are giving up those principles which I mentioned at the outset for a bill which is unworkable or does not achieve the intention of the legislatures.

The bill itself was first brought in in December 1992. It was not proceeded with due to the election in 1993 and so it now comes before the Senate some two years later. The bill is divided into two parts: part 2 deals with criminal offences; and part 3 deals with civil matters. Indeed, proposed sections 57, 58 and 60 deal with the criminal aspects, and I will come to those shortly. Recently, the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee looked at this bill and took a good deal of evidence on the various points of view on the bill.

I might add at the outset that one of the aspects that the bill looks at is acts done by reason of the race, colour or national or ethnic origin of a person. What came up before the committee was that in the United Kingdom employment and industrial tribunals had concluded that Moslems did not fall within the category of an `ethnic group'. So at the outset one has to ask whether that has been sufficiently defined—whether we have used the correct words in relation to the term `ethnic origin', because there is some precedent, I would suggest, in the United Kingdom that that does not go far enough.

Indeed, there was evidence from Mr Neave, the Deputy Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department, that it may well be difficult to define the term `ethnic origin' in the bill in a manner that does not inadvertently exclude other groups. So I just signal that at the outset as a possible problem.

As far as freedom of speech went, the committee also received evidence from witnesses that the bill may well breach the implied constitutional guarantee of freedom of political discussion. Mr Peter Bailey, a Visiting Fellow at the Faculty of Law at the Australian National University and former Deputy Chairman of the Human Rights Commission, referred to the following statement by Professor Eric Barendt which was quoted by three of the justices who formed part of the majority in the High Court case of Theophanous. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: `Political speech' refers to all speech relevant to the development of public opinion on the whole range of issues which an intelligent citizen should think about.
Mr Bailey then commented:

It seems to me that, if that is the broadly accepted definition by the High Court of political speech, it is difficult to think of much in the way of speech in a public space—which is what this legislation is about—that is not going to be deemed political . . . .

That being the case, the legislation has to get through the gateway put by the High Court, which broadly is that the means adopted are reasonably and appropriately adapted to achieve the desired end . . . . I think that is correct and I think that, given the multiplicity of reports that have come out on racial vilification, the High Court would be unlikely to say that you cannot have some kind of restrictions. The question is whether this legislation goes too far down the line of restriction . . .

Mr Bailey suggested that the removal of the proposed criminal offence of inciting racial hatred from the Crimes Act 1914, and its reformulation as a civil provision concerning racial harassment under the Racial Discrimination Act, would more appropriately meet the evil that is sought to be remedied, and therefore be more likely to withstand constitutional challenge.

PARA.TAB: What he was saying, in a nutshell, was that by the incorporation of these criminal sanctions you could well be running foul of recent decisions of the High Court. And at the end of the day if this bill is rendered unconstitutional, then you are definitely not serving the ends that the legislatures intended.

I mentioned earlier that the bill provided for three criminal offences. Briefly, they are as follows: proposed section 58 provides that it is an offence to threaten to cause physical harm to a person or group because of their race, colour, or national or ethnic origin. The maximum penalty is imprisonment for two years.
Proposed section 59 provides that it is an offence to threaten to destroy or damage property because of the race of any other person or group. The maximum penalty is imprisonment for one year.

Proposed section 60 provides that it is a criminal offence to do an act, otherwise than in private, which is intended to incite racial hatred against any other person or group, and is reasonably likely to incite racial hatred. The act must be done because of the race of the other person or members of the group. The maximum penalty is imprisonment for one year.

The creation of these separate criminal offences for racially motivated crime has two major drawbacks. Firstly, an incalcitrant racist, I would suggest, would wish for nothing more than to be sentenced for racial beliefs or what he or she might perceive to be political beliefs. Recently we have seen extremists of various persuasions prefer gaol rather than comply with bail conditions to give publicity to their cause and thereby take a `moral stand'.

In Western Australia members of the Australian Nationalist Movement were gaoled for very lengthy periods of imprisonment pursuant to various sections of the criminal code in that state. That branded the members of that movement as common criminals—nothing more, nothing less. It did not allow Jack Van Tongeren, the leader, or his band to label themselves victims, martyrs or proponents of some political cause. But it simply labelled them as common criminals, and they were sentenced pursuant to the criminal provisions of the criminal code.

Indeed, the committee heard evidence that it is already an offence in all the states and territories of Australia to threaten to injure people or damage their property, regardless of motivation. It was also raised in evidence that the difficulty in proving the additional element that the substantial reason for the doing of the impugned act is the race of a person, could well lead to the acquittal of the accused person. It would be easier, I would suggest, to simply charge the person under the state or territory legislation without having that extra element to prove. Indeed, a number of witnesses pointed to that evidentiary problem.

If I was representing a person who was charged with a racially motivated crime, I would much prefer to defend that charge under this bill than any provision of a state or territory, because the prosecution would have that added onus of proving that the act was racially motivated. But, of course, if it is a simple act of threatening to do something or damaging property, then you do not have to prove that at all. So, again, I would point that out as another flaw in this bill to those people who think that this provides the remedy for any ills that they perceive in society in this regard.

The committee had brought to its attention that one way of alleviating this problem of racist motivation might be in the sentencing process. That is, where you do find that the act is racially motivated, you could well then provide for an increased penalty. But you do not have that as part of the element of the offence.

If the court finds that damage was done, there is a conviction, and subsequently in the sentencing process, if the offence was racially motivated, there will be an increased penalty. The penalties for state offences are much more than those provided for by this bill. Mr Pearce from the Victoria Civil Liberties Council stated:

SPEECH.PARA: But let me make this point about it. Under Section 198 of the Crimes Act in Victoria for example, for the threat to damage property the penalty is 10 years. Under this legislation I think it is two years. Under this legislation you get time off for being a racist.

In this case we are looking at a flawed response to the problems that concern people. There is ample provision in the states and territories for any offence of this kind. It has been demonstrated in Western Australia. In his evidence Mr Pearce makes it abundantly clear. I therefore put it to the Senate that proposed sections 58 and 59 are superfluous and go no further in addressing any question of racism in our community.

PARA.TAB: I believe that proposed section 60 offends the principle of freedom of speech perhaps more so than the other two sections. This section needs to be examined more closely. Many columnists—in particular Sir Maurice Byers QC, the former Solicitor-General—were quoted as expressing reservations about this aspect of the legislation.

Section 60 will only make incitement to racial hatred a criminal offence if done `otherwise than in private.' This would allow the insidious activity of inciting racial hatred in private but not publicly. One wonders where the rationale for that distinction lies. Clearly the legislation must be aimed at the outworking of racial hatred once instilled as opposed to the thought process pure and simple. Racial hatred will not manifest itself in a different form if the incitement was in private as opposed to public. Mr Bailey stated to the committee that section 60 ought to become part of the civil aspect of this legislation. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . But for my own experience of working with the Racial Discrimination Act in the 1980s, quite a lot are amenable to some kind of discussion and talk if you can approach them, not saying, `You are going to be put before the police and the Crimes Act,' but saying, `This kind of thing is not appropriate.' You can explain it to them, you can have a conciliation, and you can often bring about what we are really trying to achieve, which is the community that is comfortable with itself more than often results from criminal proceedings.

He went on to state that his first problem in relation to section 60 concerned criminal proof beyond a reasonable doubt as opposed to the balance of probabilities. As regards proving these offences, he said:
It has been found difficult in New Zealand, in France, in the United Kingdom, in the United States and in Canada.

I believe that worldwide experience in this regard cannot be ignored. The phrase `otherwise than in private' is a difficult one to define and lawyers would have a bonanza in litigating that particular point. Mr Bartlett, a partner in the legal firm Minter Ellison, stated:

I would say that in my view the Bill will do nothing to reduce or stop racial hatred. It seeks to take the easy approach of hitting any offender with a big stick, rather than the more difficult task of further encouraging multiculturalism through education and assimilation.

That is really what the coalition is about: education, encouraging coexistence and not using the big stick to bludgeon people. Criminal sanction is not only superfluous in this manner but it will not result in any educative process.

PARA.TAB: I now turn to the civil aspects of the bill. The Racial Hatred Bill 1994 has directed civil sanctions at acts which are likely to `stir up hatred, serious contempt or severe ridicule against a person or a group.' The proposed section 18C of the Racial Hatred Bill 1994 is directed at acts which are reasonable likely to `offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate.' The committee received evidence of concern that the term `offend' was seen to be too broad. Mr Pearce of the Victorian Civil Liberties Council said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Dealing first of all with the civil side, essentially the effect of that legislation will be to protect people from hurt feelings. The legislation is designed specifically and in terms to protect people from offence and insults. No other legislation or principle of law that we are aware of in this country has that effect.

There are exceptions, of course, to the application of section 18C and they deal with acts which are done reasonably and in good faith, in the course of an artistic performance, a statement, publication, discussion or debate held for any genuine academic, artistic or scientific purpose. Those acts can be exempted.

PARA.TAB: That in itself begs litigation. I put to the Senate that such definition would not advance in any way any anti-racist behaviour and will only be food for more litigation. There is another aspect which deals with the civil sanction applied to employers. A vicarious liability is imposed on employers in relation to racist acts committed by employees. I submit that there is a great problem with this aspect.

At the end of the day, when we look at this bill we see that it is flawed. It will not do what people will say it will do. It will not achieve the intentions that the government has set out to implement. I believe that education is the way to solve this problem, not criminal sanctions and not definitions contained in provisions which deal with civil sanctions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been waiting a long time to speak on the Racial Hatred Bill 1994. I have been waiting not only during the time that the government has wasted in bringing the bill to this chamber; I have probably waited something like 50 years to speak on a bill like this one. I am probably one of three senators in this chamber who have had experiences like these all our lives. I claim to speak with authority. I will name the other two senators whom I think will be most interested in this bill. They are the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), who introduced the bill, and my colleague Senator Abetz who spoke some minutes ago.

PARA.TAB: As I said, this bill has been a long time in gestation. I believe it is a bill that should never have been conceived and it would have been far better off if it had been stillborn. But then, of course, I would not have had an opportunity to speak about some of the things that I have known of all my life.

The bill has been conceived by political correctness parties around Australia who are hell-bent on creating another bureaucracy to interfere with the rights of all Australians. This bill has been written to interfere with freedom of expression by all Australians in their every day interaction with each other. It is a bill that would have been better not to have come here.

I believe that this bill is totally unnecessary. Some speakers have already said that Australia is the most racially tolerant country that they have ever known. I agree with them. We do not have to travel overseas to see racial intolerance. We simply have to watch the media every day to see what is going in the former Yugoslav republic. There are racial problems in the United States, in the United Kingdom—although they seem to have died out—certainly in Ireland and in many other places. Australia does not have this problem. For those reasons I believe that this is a totally unnecessary bill.

I get back to the point that I started with, which is that I am one who should be supporting a bill like this for reasons that I will come to later. I can tell you from the word go that I am not a supporter of the bill. I totally reject the bill. I go back to what Senator Vanstone said when she started her contribution to this debate. Let us get it straight that we on this side of chamber—and I particularly—do not want to see racial vilification in Australia, but this bill is not the way to go. I let the people who are racing to get one more racial tolerance bill know that I will not have a bar of racial vilification whatsoever even though I totally oppose this bill.

I can speak with authority on this subject as I grew up and went to school as the child of parents who migrated from Italy. I can remember the racial taunts, name calling and discrimination by teachers in school and in sport. I remember that as if it were yesterday. That was a shock to me when I started school at a late age. I did not have a grasp of the English language at the time. I soon learnt the fast way what I was being told.

I spent my early childhood years with Italians mainly and some people from the former Republic of Yugoslavia. Those sorts of things did not happen with the young people and children whom I associated with. When I started school I certainly learnt what racism was all about.

As a young adult, I considered that things would change and that people would learn to accept others, especially in the school system. I thought that teachers might change as time went on; but they did not, it got worse. There was more abuse and discrimination in sport. Later on when I went into business the same thing happened. Probably the worst thing I could do as a young adult was to form a romantic association with an Australian. I can tell you that that was an experience in terms of race, religion and whatever. They were not very good times whatsoever.

Postwar migration led Australia to recognise that there are people around the world who have different ideas. I suppose we could have excused this verbal racial abuse because of the war and the fact that different countries were on different sides. My father spent time in the Italian army. After the massive migration program of the 1950s and 1960s, Australians started to change their attitudes because new Australians were around. In my younger days at school and soon after, I thought the only way of dealing with those sorts of racial taunts was not to have laws but a bunch of fives. Sometimes you were outnumbered very badly. Those sorts of things went on.

In sport there were all sorts of discrimination and abuse. After dealing with all of those things which I and my brothers have experienced, I will not have anything to do with this sort of legislation. I think a good person to quote is B.A. Santamaria. I do not think he is unknown to a lot of people in this place. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps one who was born in Australia, but both of whose parents were Italian and who therefore knows what ethnic slurs actually mean, need not apologise for dealing with the "anti-racism" mania now sweeping both the media and the sporting world.

He went on in that article to make various points about football and so on. I believe it is a very good article. The minister has seen a copy of the article. I seek leave to have the article incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Extract
The Australian, 20 May 1995
A slur on good sense
B.A. Santamaria

Perhaps one who was born in Australia, but both of whose parents were Italian and who therefore knows what ethnic slurs actually mean, need not apologise for dealing with the "anti-racialism" mania now sweeping both the media and the sporting world. He would like a dollar for every occasion, during his youth when he and other members of his family were insulted as "dagos". One of the fundamental truths which ethnic slurs taught him then was that while they were ill-bred, offensive and personally hurtful, it was necessary to keep a sense of proportion.

In a world full of the seemingly unavoidable suffering of hunger, disease and war, racial slurs remained offensive and hurtful but, measured on the barometer of suffering, they were relatively unimportant. If he was big enough, the victim would dish out a "backhander" to his verbal assailant; but the idea of passing a law to stop him, or hounding the assailant out of any position he might hold in public life for using offensive language would have been regarded as tripe. It remains tripe, and is not elevated from that category by the artificially hyped-up reaction of the media.

It was not very nice that Collingwood ruckman Damien Monkhurst should call Essendon's Aboriginal star, Michael Long, a "black b. . . " when the latter sprawled all over his Collingwood opponent as he lay on the ground. Nor was it very nice for semi-drunken spectators to use similar expletives from over the fence. But have any of the journalists who have gone into a pious frenzy over the Monkhurst-Long incident ever gone to a football match? What kind of language do they think is normally used between players, occasionally between players and umpires, let alone by some of the spectators and not only in the "outer".
If the world were a different place, none of this language would ever be used by any one of them. But it isn't a different place.

If Michael Long had had an Italian name and Monkhurst had called him a "wog", would we have had the columns of hypocritical breast-beating which has been served up because Michael Long, one of the most brilliant, effervescent and effective players in the AFL, is an Aborigine? If he had had an Irish name, and had been called a "Catholic b. . . " would the media have gone into such paroxysms of indignation?

Similarly with Arthur Tunstall and his rather crude joke, which, incidentally, was not told publicly at a meeting as original misreported, but around the lunch table. Watching the ABC's Andrew Olle trying to bully some sporting official or other into undertaking to drive Tunstall out of his official sporting position to pay the penalty of his plebeian humour inevitably turns one mind to the ABC itself.

Was it not the ABC which cheerfully offended thousands of viewers by giving an hour of prime viewing time to the Gay Mardi Gras, thus celebrating a way of life which—whatever its attractions to some—is a major source of AIDS infection? That and the accompanying insults to the Pope and to the religious beliefs of a large part of the community are apparently not as offensive as Arthur Tunstall's "joke". Nobody in the ABC has lost his or her job for these grossly offensive programs and this abysmal waste of taxpayers' money. Only Arthur Tunstall was to lose his.

The prominence given, in particular by television cameras, to Aboriginal athletes officially representing Australia running around, not with Australian but with Aboriginal flags wrapped around their shoulders, is nothing but short-term stupidity. Haven't they understood what is in store for NZ as a result of Maori separatism? Don't they understand that if you further confuse an already confused generation brought up with little history, steeped in the prevailing climate of moral and cultural relativism, with the indispensable symbolism of a single national flag routinely ridiculed, you are creating long-term problems which history may never give you the time to resolve?
The nonsensical exaggeration associated with this campaign has reached its climax with the federal Racial Vilification Bill, presented to Parliament by the Keating Government.

On May 9 this year The Australian carried an article strongly supporting the Bill, contributed by a Mary Kalantsis, professor of education at James Cook University and Bill Cope, director of the Centre for Workplace Communication and Culture, at Sydney's University of Technology.

To the objection that the Federal Racial Vilification Bill would be used to curtail freedom of speech, the two academics answered by pointing to the administration of the Greiner legislation in NSW: "In the five years of operation of the Greiner legislation there is no evidence that one skerrick of speech was restricted. There have been 448 complaints: 80 in 1993-94. Only three have been recommended for prosecution and even then the prosecution did not proceed. Most cases were investigated and conciliated by the Anti-Discrimination Board."

What does this prove, except that an expensive and unnecessary bureaucratic machinery is devoted to providing a "remedy" for a problem which does not exist? Out of 448 complaints, not a single prosecution! To say nothing of the days of taxpayer-funded time wasted on "conciliation".

It is unnecessary to appeal to the Australian people to regain a sense of proportion: the majority have it anyway. The politically correct—whether in the ABC, the commercial media, and/or university departments—who have made an industry out of allegations of racism, have merely substituted a threadbare ideology for commonsense. Not for the first or last time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read an article on Senator Bolkus's background, but, unfortunately, I have not got it with me. Incidentally, his father and my father may have come out on the same migrant ship—we are still trying to work that out. They both finished up at Port Pirie. Senator Bolkus pointed out how he had been racially slurred at school and faced all sorts of discrimination when he was part of an all Greek football club in Adelaide. He said that it spurred them and, in his words, `they finished up belting the shit out of every team.'

PARA.TAB: I thought that his ideas may have been like mine. He has gone through all that. He has succeeded. He has been elected to parliament and is a minister in a government that we could do without. He overcame all the problems without those sorts of laws. I thought he might have had the same idea as I have, but, unfortunately, he does not. He can do what he wants to do.

I believe that this bill is legislative overkill. It is a bill to regulate exactly how we speak and more so how we think. It consists of changes to the Crimes Act and the 1975 Racial Discrimination Act. The Crimes Act amendments create a federal criminal offence of incitement to racial hatred and threats of racial violence which carry penalties of imprisonment. I believe that no bill in Australia should result in a person going to gaol as result of what they say.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think a better solution is just to beat the daylights out of them?

—I say that because that is what I used to do. I believe if we are going to have something like that then we should have the civil sanctions that Senator Vanstone pointed out. You may remember that the Governor-General designate spoke out about this about a year ago when there was a change to laws regarding what journalists could say without getting put in gaol.

PARA.TAB: Amendments to the Racial Discrimination Act would enable the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to hear complaints about behaviour which is `reasonably likely to offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate because of race, colour or nationality'. Who knows what the term `reasonably likely' means? No-one knows how you feel. It is hard to legislate for that. The government insists that genuine public debate would be protected by exemptions to aspects of this bill.
So you have a law there. But, by the exemptions that are there, I just cannot see how in an inquiry or a court of law you could really dig into someone's mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Courts do it every day.

—Courts do it every day but there are results. When the courts deal with something, something has happened along the line. But here it is what someone may have thought, may have meant or something like that. It is too deep for me. The interpretation is the worrying aspect of what constitutes a racist insult and what causes people to be offended. We should look at the offended part. I could be offended by what the minister just said or, no insults implied, just by looking at the minister.
—Or just the fact that I am just sitting here, breathing.
—I could be offended by that. I am very hard to offend, as my colleagues on this side know. How can anyone really sit down and work out a degree of offence?

PARA.TAB: I will use the sexual harassment legislation, which is something totally different, as an example. In 1992 the official definition of sexual harassment was changed. It now means that a complainant does not have to demonstrate disadvantage at work but only that he or she felt offended, humiliated or intimidated.

Let us go back to what I said before. So Senator Kemp, Senator MacGibbon and I would feel offended or humiliated to differing degrees. So where do you draw the line? I think the government is playing with fire in dealing with this sort of legislation. I believe it to be very dangerous. If this legislation does get on the statute books in Australia, I believe that we will be in trouble.

The government will have to realise eventually, and this is what I believe, that education is the only way to get over this problem. It has been said by many speakers on this side, and I believe I have shown this through my experience, that education is the way to go. After all, Australians have a capacity to change. If you take the last 20 or 30 years, Australian attitudes to migrants in general and those from particular parts of the world—such as Asia, South America, India and the Arab states—have changed.

Attitudes to various things have changed. Australia is changing. There is no law that says you shall change any of your habits or anything like that, but they have changed. Australia accepts change. It creeps up. What was the average Australian menu 30 years ago? I reckon it was terrible. Unfortunately, I had to put up with it in the different places I lived. When I went home I really appreciated home cooking, continental cooking. Now you cannot find an Australian restaurant that does not have some international sort of cooking.

I place this sort of legislation with the sort of social engineering legislation that we have had at other times. I will use one as an example, though it was not quite social engineering—that is, the war crimes legislation that was debated when I first came into this place. After all the time we spent on it, after all the money that was spent setting up whatever goes with the legislation, what has happened? There has been no conviction in Australia, to my knowledge—one charge but no convictions. There are some figures from New South Wales which have shown it to be extremely difficult to prosecute. They have had three charges recommended by the DPP but none has come to trial.

There is something else that I believe could be reverse racism—that is, migrants to Australians and migrants to migrants. That is happening in Australia. It could give them an avenue to push things far beyond when they could settle something at home, around a meeting table or something like that.

I do believe that the political correctness society has gone to extremes. I say again that it is dangerous. Remember also that racial taunts, racism and discrimination are not only against two or so societies in Australia but, if there are any, right across. When I say against the two societies, I do not mind naming them—that is, the Aborigines or the Jewish community.

Senator Chris Evans, when he spoke in this debate, used the desecration of Eddie Mabo's grave as a reason for this legislation. Perhaps he did not see the article in the Brisbane Courier-Mail which reported that three Aborigines were charged, or interrogated, about that. One does not necessarily want to jump to conclusions. It was the same when the Jewish cemetery was knocked around in Melbourne. The desecration of graves is abhorrent, and I believe there should be other ways of dealing with those responsible. At the same time the Jewish cemetery was damaged, a Catholic one in Melbourne was damaged also and very little was done about it. In short, even the Archbishop of Melbourne condemned the legislation. I certainly do not accept this legislation. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Harassment of an individual or individuals because of their race by threats, intimidation or violence has no place in our society. No reasonable person would challenge that. Indeed, there are currently laws in place which prevent harassment on any grounds, not only racial grounds, with severe penalties.

PARA.TAB: If the Racial Hatred Bill was only an irrelevant bill, it would be one thing but this bill fails to differentiate between what is offensive behaviour and what is harmful or dangerous behaviour. As such, it goes too far. It goes so far as to strike at the basic right of citizens in a democracy: the right of freedom of speech. The Royal Commission into Aboriginals Deaths in Custody and the Law Reform Commission's Multiculturalism and the Law Report concluded that making racial vilification a criminal offence would be too drastic a step and the civil remedies, together with conciliation, would be a more appropriate course of action.

It is certainly the business of this legislature to legislate and regulate by passing laws for the benefit of all. But it has to be eternally on its guard that, in its zeal to protect the rights of members of the society, it does not diminish or remove the basic rights which are the foundations of a free society. This bill does that by openly reducing the right to freedom of expression.

The bill sets out to amend the Crimes Act by adding three criminal offences—the first two involve threats of violence and the third involves an act which is reasonably likely to incite racial hatred. The first offence relates to threats to cause physical harm to a person because of their race, colour, nationality or ethnic origin. The second offence relates to threats to damage or to destroy property because of a person's race, colour, nationality or ethnic origin.

We have no quarrel with this. It has our full support. But we would point out that in all states of Australia both of these actions are against the law, and in many cases the penalties applying are higher than those proposed in this bill. It is the third offence that raises the real problems: doing a public act with the intention of inciting racial hatred if it is reasonably likely that the act will incite racial hatred.

Racial hatred, surprisingly enough, is not defined in the definitions of the bill, which is the usual practice. The inciting of racial hatred must be done `otherwise than in private'—that is, in public. But there is a wide interpretation of what constitutes `in public'. The intention of the accused person must be to incite racial hatred. Then it must be proven that it was reasonably likely that the utterances would incite racial hatred. Note that the bill does not require that there has to be actual incitement to racial hatred, only—in the words of the act—`likely to cause'.

I would submit to the Senate that there are very real problems in applying this bill in the courts if it becomes law. The real danger is that, because of the wide ambit of this particular clause, freedom of expression will be inhibited. Our basic right of freedom of speech will be severely curtailed or it will disappear.

This bill is misconceived. It demonstrates the age old belief of the Labor Party that all human relations problems can be solved and solved instantly by passing a law or laws. It has always been a criminal offence in this country when people assault one another or damage property, whether it is between differing ethnic groups or even between members of the same family. We on this side of the chamber support the prohibitions against those sorts of actions, and we support them unreservedly. There is not the slightest dispute about that. Where we differ from the government on this bill is in the treatment of verbal comment in the way the government treats it in this bill.

We recognise that words can be highly offensive. They can be very wounding. They can be very destructive. You cannot have people destroying the good working and harmonious relationships within society by an irresponsible or malicious use of words. But the answer to that, as so many speakers on this side have said, is education, not the heavy hand of the law. It is just commonsense that you cannot go around being rude to people. At the end of the day, it gets down to having manners, and good manners at that. But the Labor Party never sees any place for manners. They deride manners as having no place. They see them as a relic from the past, retained by a few misguided people who want to live in a former age. But manners are not that. They are one of the essential lubricants of society.

You might smile, Acting Deputy President McKiernan, but I came down in a plane with one of your colleagues who described one of his other colleagues as the rudest person that he has ever met in his life. It illustrates the point I am making that manners are one of the essential lubricants of society. They are the oil that allows people from different backgrounds to mix pleasantly and cooperatively within the community.

One of the key answers to racial tension within our society is education which will bring the tolerance that we need, the exposure of one community group to practices and the habits of another and the encouragement of a live and let live philosophy.

There has been much debate of late in the media, with the community expressing its views on this legislation. I would like to quote from one of the newspaper correspondents on this matter, Mr Damien Grace, from the University of New South Wales. He wrote most eloquently:

SPEECH.PARA: The whole point of living in a liberal society is to accept a kind of secular turning of the other cheek: it is better to have the kind of freedom which enables people to offend you than to have the kind of social controls which might ultimately be used against you.

The Labor Party, controlled by the social engineers with their immature and mechanistic theories of how an ideal society should work, simply does not understand this. The other point is that the Labor Party never has any patience. It will not take the long-term view. It wants an instant fix for all of society's problems.

PARA.TAB: There have always been tensions in Australian society, right from the time of early settlement. No gulf could possibly have been wider than the gulf between the Rum Corps and the convicts, but that gulf was resolved generations ago. As Senator Panizza said, after the Second World War there was great division between the migrants and the native born community. But today that is no longer relevant. It is fair to say that in all societies there is some conflict within them because no society is homogeneous, with the possible exception of Japan.

Australia does have to recognise and should get credit for the fact that it has come a very long way in overcoming these internal tensions and in so doing has made some very real and laudable achievements. Australian society has changed and it will continue to change because the community does have a great deal of tolerance within it, and that tolerance is increasing. The public has a great well of commonsense, far more at times than is shown by members of this parliament.

There are people in Australia who are racially intolerant, but I have lived out of Australia for a long and significant part of my adult life. I have travelled extensively as well. I strenuously reject the claim that Australia is a racist country. It is more tolerant of newcomers and it is more tolerant of different practices than any country I know.

It is important that we maintain a sense of perspective about Australian society. To go down the path of solving our problems—problems which stem from a lack of education and understanding—by resorting to legislative means is doomed to failure. The real tragedy is that, when this legislation fails, the same social engineers who gave us this policy will respond with even harsher and more draconian legislation, and you can be absolutely certain of that. There is a better approach. Let us reduce the problems we have in our society by reason, not by the excessive use of force which destroys our basic rights. (Time expired).
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make a few brief comments in relation to this document. Those who may be listening to this broadcast may be interested to know that this document has 427 pages in it and I am allowed some five minutes to address the matters contained therein. However, a good place to start with these documents is always in the foreword.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, refers to the ACTU as the most representative organisation of workers and thanks them for their contribution. Let me say that this government, unfortunately, has a penchant for dealing with peak groups rather than constituent groups and individuals within the community and has thus alienated large sections of the community. Indeed, the ACTU has alienated large sections of the community, as witnessed by its ever decreasing membership. I am sure that, despite the Labor Party's intentions of moving Mr Ferguson from his role in the ACTU into the federal parliament, the slide will continue even under his proposed successor, Jennie George.

We are discussing the International Labour Organisation and the status of its conventions in Australia. On page 381 we have a most interesting list of the member states of the ILO—those sorts of countries that together provide the excellent examples of the labour relations that we in Australia can learn from. Indeed, there are 171 members. There are countries with such excellent employee relations as China, Croatia, Cuba, Iran, Iraq, the Lao People's Democratic Republic and Vietnam. I am just going through the alphabetical listing at random and I see all these countries listed which, quite frankly, ought be paying a greater regard to the standards that we employ in this country.

I also bring to the Senate's attention that the number of conventions undertaken by the ILO now amount to 175. They also have this animal, apart from their conventions, called recommendations. They have 175 conventions and 182 recommendations, all of course dealing with separate matters. It is interesting to note that when the federal government deals with such things as international treaties it always tells us that the list is about 922 and that the ILO is dealing just with the one issue of labour relations. But as we can see here, the ILO itself has 175 conventions and 182 recommendations. It is under the ILO that so much of this government's industrial relations legislation is based. One cannot help thinking of certain legislation such as unfair dismissals, which at the end of the day the government and that dynamic Minister Brereton tell us is based on our international obligation. `We have to legislate, we have to do this to bring us into line with certain international obligations.'

But, of course, when there is too much domestic pressure brought to bear, all of a sudden this interpretation of what our international obligations are changes; and the minister is prepared to change the legislation. So, methinks that the government relies on the ILO just as a smokescreen for itself—for its domestic legislation—rather than giving due and serious consideration to what its obligations are to the Australian worker and to the Australian economic community. If this government focused more on its responsibility to Australian workers, Australian businesses and the Australian economy, rather than concentrating on its alleged obligations to the ILO, I believe this country and its industrial relations system would be a lot better off.
