TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening I was developing a number of matters in relation to the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and specifically in relation to the preparation of pituitary hormones which were used to treat some 2,600 people over approximately 20 years from the mid-1960s to the mid-1980s. I was developing the theme, within the 10-minute time frame, that during nearly all of that time the CSL had failed dismally to develop a code of good manufacturing practice; and indeed had resisted the application of a code of good manufacturing practice as it was developed during the years which were coincident in part with the manufacture of the pituitary hormones.

PARA.TAB: I then went on and was beginning to develop some specific examples of the way in which CSL had failed to observe that code of good manufacturing practice with respect to therapeutic goods. I was pointing out that one of the criteria for the code of good manufacturing practice with respect to therapeutic goods is that before you actually put any of these goods on the market you have a well developed program for the manufacture of these goods which guarantees the quality of the materials which go into the manufacture, the sterility of the process, the efficacy of the product which you are putting onto the market and so on; so that when you eventually provide that product to the public, it can have assurance that the product is safe, effective, the dose is known and that it has been manufactured by a process which is consistent.

I was making the point that the code requires that there be a set of complete and comprehensive master manufacturing instructions for every product formally authorised by management and that this be changed and updated only through processes of formal authorisation. It must be strictly adhered to throughout the manufacture of each batch of the product. This is to ensure that before any product goes into production for distribution—or even for clinical trials—the manufacturer has developed and fully documented a process which will ensure that the product is consistent and reliable from batch to batch and, likewise, that the product when clinically trialled will be reproduced batch after batch, after production and before general distribution is begun.

It is abundantly clear—and this is where I got to last night—from the Allars report that CSL failed to develop a satisfactory process for the manufacturing of hormone products before they went into production. I gave several examples of batches which were manufactured by quite different processes without any proper documentation; and those batches found their way onto the market.

I pointed out that appendix 2 of the Allars report shows that finished batches not infrequently were unsterile, pyrogenic—that is, they caused temperature increases when injected—contained hepatitis B, could not be assayed for hormone content, contained uncontrolled amounts of extraneous substances and caused stinging on injection. Pyrexia often followed the injection of the hormone.

There were persistent problems with freeze drying of the products, ampoules were sometimes not properly sealed—which, of course, rendered them subject to lack of sterility—and batches were often highly discoloured. In other words, there was enormous variability from batch to batch. In addition, labelling and packaging errors occurred from time to time. So much for the development of a standard protocol for the manufacture of these products and for CSL's adherence to anything approaching a code of good manufacturing practice!

The Allars report notes that batches with unsterile, pyrogenic hepatitis and other faulty batches were sometimes reprocessed and then either released or blended with other batches and then released for distribution. As I have shown clearly already in a previous adjournment address, it was known that the infective agents which were responsible for the transmission of CJD came through chromatography columns first—in other words, they were eluted first—and were especially difficult to kill so that no amount of reprocessing should have allowed these products onto the market.

The code requires that all ingredients and starting materials come from approved and identified sources, be subject to appropriate quality control specifications and, before use, have been examined for compliance with the specifications released for use on the basis of compliance. In other words, one knows precisely, reliably and consistently what goes into the product.

But CSL often did not know the sources of the pituitary glands; it was willing to accept glands from extremely suspect sources that should never have been approved. Such sources include Papua New Guinea, Hong Kong, Mauritius, Malaysia and mental and geriatric hospitals. CSL had no quality control specifications for the glands. The poor quality of the glands was a prime source of the low yields of the hormone, the poor quality and inconsistency of the products, and many of the problems of production.

The complete absence of quality control over the glands is astonishing in itself, but all the more so since their quality was of critical importance to the success of the production process. If these glands were already infected, then the yields of the hormones which were obtainable from those glands were already diminished. It was known from the outset that the glands might contain live viruses or, as we now call the CJD causative factor, prions. There was no way of testing for these agents in individual glands, no way of testing the glands that would destroy those agents if they were present, no way of testing the final product and no way of removing the agents from the final product.

As explained several times, if the agent was present it would elute from the chromatography column first, with the potential that every hormone which eluted from that column afterwards would be contaminated. Considering all this, it was even more essential for there to have been an exceptionally high standard adopted in relation to the source of the glands, the method of collection and their storage and transport.

The code requires that manufacturers have a quality control department which reports directly to top management and is independent of the production department. The quality control department is, among other things, responsible for the quality control specifications of the raw materials as well as the finished product, the labelling and the packaging. It is this department, under the code of good manufacturing practice, which would be responsible for the rejection of any product which did not meet the specification. CSL did not subscribe to this concept of independent quality control. Product release was in the hands of the production department, the very people who were manufacturing the hormone. So there was no independent control until late in the hormone program—until the 1980s.

Storage trials were perfunctory and valid shelf life was not established either before the products were placed on the market or subsequently. Stability data was meaningless. Sterile materials and equipment should have been used throughout the preparation of the hormones.

CSL did not adopt these precautions. The glands were often grossly contaminated; the fractionation columns were not sterile; and there was plenty of opportunity for organisms to multiply, and they probably did, during the long periods in which the materials would have been passing through the fractionation columns. There were then further shortcomings in the sterility of the rooms in which the processing was carried out, in the transfer of the fractionated material to the ampoules for freeze drying and in the transfer of the ampoules to the freeze drier and from there to the ampoule sealing machine. As mentioned already, some ampoules remained not properly sealed and were distributed in that form—where clearly they could become contaminated.

Time does not permit a more detailed and extensive examination of these and a whole raft of other defects which accompanied the manufacture by CSL not only of pituitary hormones but of many of their other products as well. I had hoped that this material would be put before a Senate committee yesterday but, clearly, the coalition still to this stage thinks that its political agenda is more important than the lives and wellbeing of thousands of Australians.

I note that Senator Herron is now in the chamber. I just very briefly say to Senator Herron: there are 660 Australians who have joined a pro-active group because they are very concerned about what they have received, and 140 of them have issued writs against CSL. Those people should not be forced to go into court and be subjected to an adversarial process to establish the basic facts. Those facts should be clearly laid on the table before a Senate committee. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —During this debate on the adjournment, I wanted to take the occasion to briefly pay tribute to a person who passed away recently. There is a notice of motion on the Notice Paper concerning this matter which was put down by the minister for sport yesterday. I refer to Margaret Pewtress, a lady who deserves the credit for the state of netball in Australia at the moment. Margaret passed away shortly after the Australian team won against South Africa in the final of the recent world championship held in Great Britain.

PARA.TAB: Margaret has an enormous reputation both across Australia, wherever netball is played, and all around the world. It is a great credit to her that, in this year when she sadly was lost to Australia, to Australian netball and to sports generally, we were able to win not only the world netball championship at the open level but also the under-21 championship. It was my great privilege during the last sitting session to go out to watch a game being played between the New Zealand and the Australian under-21 teams, and see the Australians win that game.

As shadow minister for sports over the last year or so, I have had the privilege to meet Margaret on a number of occasions, mostly at Confederation of Sport functions. I am privileged to have met the lady. But you do not need to meet Margaret when you travel around and meet people involved in sport in Australia, because she is a legend and will remain a legend.

I note just briefly that Margaret was the President of the All Australia Netball Association. She served as a member on the board of the Australian Sports Commission and made an incredible contribution to the development of that organisation. She was a tireless worker not only for netball but for all sports in this country and, very importantly, made a great contribution to the development of sport for women.

She also did an enormous amount to promote the coverage that the media give to women in sport. I think all of us who follow sports in Australia will know the incredible boost that the coverage of women's sport got out of that thrilling win in the world championships in Sydney in 1991. Indeed, Margaret deserves enormous credit for the work that she did in getting those world championships to Sydney. Her work in organising those championships ensured that she received plaudits and appreciation from right around the world.

Margaret is an example of someone who has gone on from being a player. She played in the Melbourne Netball Club and was regarded as a very good player. After her playing days she went on to become a successful coach, both for Victoria and for Australia; she went on to become a national selector; and then she went on to become a distinguished administrator—one of the great administrators in the relatively short history of Australian sport. She also gave great service to the Victorian Sports Council and went on to accept the great challenge at that stage of chairing the inaugural National Women's Sport Unit, which has certainly done great work in increasing not only the participation of women in sport but also, as I said earlier, the recognition of women in sport in Australia.
I—unusually for men in Australia—have had the rare privilege, you might call it, of actually playing netball. It is one of the attributes that not many people around here know that I have got.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of many, I'm sure, Senator.

—Before entering parliament, one of my many hidden talents was playing mixed netball in the home town of Perth that we both share. So I have a very special appreciation of the incredible skill that is involved in that game. I say to all that the skills needed in netball are not entirely contained in this athlete that stands before you—because I used to get into enormous trouble with the referees and some of the other players—but I do have a very special understanding of the skills involved in playing the game.

PARA.TAB: Having watched the game played at the very top levels, you can see what a tremendous game it is and the incredible skill we have got. I say very sincerely to senators, to all of the Australian public and particularly to Margaret's husband, Bill; her daughter, Elizabeth; her sons, Stephen and Ian; and her grandchildren, Chloe and Bryce: Margaret made an incredible contribution to this nation. A lot of people will watch netball on television. It is something that is only a relatively recent television sporting event. But the fact that so many Australians are able to watch netball on television and be so proud of our champion teams in both the under-21s and the open team is something that we owe Margaret Pewtress in particular. Australia has lost a very, very fine contributor to this nation. I wanted to take this occasion to record that in the Hansard and before this parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish tonight to address some of the underlying issues in relation to the French and Chinese nuclear testing. The achievement and maintenance of a global nuclear test ban treaty must surely be one of our most urgent and enduring goals, because no single issue is more important for the future health and survival of all living creatures. It is not enough, however, to stop radioactive fallout from tests. If this planet is to sustain life, we must outlaw the production and use of nuclear weapons in all forms: large and small, neutron, theatre nuclear or long-range missile deployed.

PARA.TAB: In parallel, too, must go the universal acceptance and enforcement of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty to ensure the effective monitoring of the movement and processing of all fissile material, such as uranium and thorium, to prevent enrichment to weapons-grade. In the absence of full compliance and rigorous surveillance, the world can be held to ransom by nuclear terrorism or political blackmail. In a 1985 policy statement, the Liberal Party said:

SPEECH.PARA: "In a nuclear war there can be no winners, no escape for neutral nations and no protection in so-called nuclear free zones. Nuclear effects are world-wide. No nation, no matter where situated, can opt out of a nuclear war.

"It is not sufficient to try to prevent only nuclear war. Conventional weapons (including chemical and biological weapons) are greatly increasing in lethal and destructive power. Moreover, a conventional war involving significant interests of major powers could rapidly escalate into a nuclear exchange.

There can be no small or limited nuclear exchanges. The initial pre-emptive strike must be of such a magnitude as to totally destroy the opponent and to prevent retaliation. A strike of that magnitude clearly has global consequences.

PARA.TAB: It is not sufficient for nations or scientists to argue that the nuclear tests are such as to be harmless to the environment. This cannot be proven. Scientists are yet unable to state with any certainty the particular threshold of intensity below which radioactivity is not harmful to life on earth. In the face of this, the only sensible policy for governments and individuals alike is to strive to ensure that all avoidable man-made radioactivity is reduced to a minimum. We cannot escape the effects of natural radiation. It is everywhere around us—in the atmosphere, the rocks, the vegetation, the food chain, our own bodies. It is in the building materials of our homes and our offices. It increases significantly too with altitude above sea level.

Throughout history until recently life on earth seems to have coped successfully with natural radiation and adapted to it with skin pigmentation and other defence mechanisms. In those times population size and inventiveness were insufficient to seriously damage the environment, unlike today when the greenhouse effect and acid rain and damage to the ozone layer pose very serious threats to the future.

Restricting nuclear testing to a particular nation's backyard offers no safety to the rest of the globe. The diurnal spin of the earth ensures that wherever new radioactivity is generated there will be a `cosmic mix' resulting over time in an even distribution over the whole planet. In the end we all experience a fallout from Hiroshima, Nagasaki, the Manhattan project, Lop Nor, Muraroa, and, of course, Chernobyl.

Natural radiation at sea level in Sydney is said to average around 100 millirads. To this must be added a further two millirads for the effects of the accumulation of all the previous nuclear fallout from man-made devices. Canberra residents must also add another two millirads in respect of the higher altitude here. In other parts of the world in higher altitudes radiation levels are often significantly higher. However, it is not possible to say with certainty that there are no adverse effects.

Radioactive materials are increasingly used in medical treatment and diagnosis as well as industry. Most of these have a very short shelf-life and are subject to strict regulations. But the long-term disposal of radioactive waste demands expert and thorough scrutiny. All other sources of possible radiation such as high transmission power lines and communication devices merit constant research and investigation to ensure that there are no deleterious effects.

In the complacency which has followed the collapse of the Warsaw Pact, pressure may have well lessened the drive for nuclear arms reduction. There is evidence that in Russia and the Ukraine a number of nuclear weapons are being dismantled and the plutonium component removed. However, nuclear capacity cannot be measured simply by the size and number of warheads. The great scientific advances in the range and accuracy of delivery vehicles have ensured that fewer and smaller warheads can be at least as effective. In any case, for the long range future there will be immensely more nuclear weapons than are necessary to destroy this world many times over.

And what to do with the increasing stockpile of plutonium, a highly poisonous man-made element, whose PU23 fissionable isotope has a half-life of 24,000 years? With perhaps four or five kilograms to make an atomic explosive, Russia is said to have had at least 4,000 kilograms and the USA perhaps 1,500. The suggestion of the creation of an international plutonium bank, a nuclear Fort Knox, has not progressed very far.

The knowledge to make nuclear weapons is now and forever available to all mankind. The fissionable materials are freely accessible on every continent and in the oceans. Any country with a reasonable industrial infrastructure could produce a nuclear device and some form of delivery system. And against that background of potential, it is always possible that a significant conventional war could accelerate into a nuclear holocaust. Clearly then, the immediate and long range issues are bigger and more enduring than any current protest against French and Chinese nuclear tests, however important those protests are.

The need is for Australia and other countries to pursue a concerted and sustained pressure to achieve eight main goals: firstly, to persuade those countries not yet signatories to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty to become parties to the treaty, to observe its provisions and to permit full and open access to international inspection; secondly, to urge all nations to become signatories to the nuclear test ban treaty; thirdly, to work within the United Nations for a sustained and rigorous program to reduce nuclear armaments involving all current and potential nuclear powers; fourthly, to accelerate pressure at the international level for a treaty banning chemical and biological warfare; fifthly, to seek a world conference and ultimate treaty on conventional weapons disarmament and the limitation and regulation of international articles sales; sixthly, to urge the maintenance and strengthening of NATO as demonstrably the one successful collective security force on the European continent; seventhly, to review in-depth the potential and reality of the United Nations as the world agency for peacekeeping and collective security and to endeavour to strengthen its capacity to act with speed and success on those roles; and, eighthly, to review Australia's capacity to participate as a good neighbour in collective security and peacekeeping.

In this year Australia Remembers, it should be constantly stressed that World War II would not have occurred if the League of Nations had functioned effectively, if arms limitations had been enforced and if a reasonable collective security intervention had occurred in the mid-1930s both in Europe and in Asia. In those years our international and regional collective security arrangements were grossly inadequate and nations were unwilling to act. Are we any better equipped today or are we similarly in the grip of complacency, isolationism and a, however natural, unwillingness to risk human lives and resources in what are seen to be, however myopically, not our problems?

In the 1930s Manchuria and China were not seen to be the problem of the USA or other Pacific nations yet they were the very stepping stones to the edge of Australia. The annexation of the Saar and Austria and the invasion of Czechoslovakia were not seen to be the problems of France or the United Kingdom, but they proved to be the springboards to the English Channel. Let us use the background of Australia Remembers to remind ourselves of our past failures to prevent global war and to concentrate our minds on how not to repeat those errors in the future. That is our duty to the generations ahead who, thankfully for them, were not able to remember.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 March 1995:With reference to the helicopter aircraft being used in the construction of the Skyrail near Kuranda in far north Queensland:

PARA.TAB: (1) Can confirmation be given whether a Kamov 32A or a Kamov 32C is to be used in the installation of the remaining towers on the Skyrail site.
(2) What is the name and/or nationality of the pilot who will captain the aircraft.
(3) As the helicopters are Russian owned, what authority, company or nation would be responsible if the aircraft were to crash whilst travelling to or from the Skyrail site.
(4) Does the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) intend to issue a permit for the commercial use of the Kamov 32A or Kamov 32C for the placement of the Skyrail towers.

(5) Is there another type of aircraft that could be used for tower placement that is certified either in Australia or some other country; if so, is the Minister aware of any reason why has it not been used.

(6) Is the CAA to use the provisions of section 27A of the Civil Aviation Act to absolve an operator from complying with the stringent safeguards contained in the Act; if so, what are the grounds for this decision.

(7) Have officers of the CAA satisfied themselves as to the safety regulation and airworthiness of the Kamov 32A or Kamov 32C in respect of minimum crewing standards, cockpit checklists, built standards and maintenance procedures.
(8) At what level of the CAA have the past permits been granted.
(9) Have any recent requests for permits regarding the use of Kamov helicopters been granted; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority has provided the following information:
(1) The Kamov 32A (KA32A) and Kamov 32C (KA32C) Helicopters are Russian registered aircraft which were used by Hevi Lift (PNG) Pty Ltd in the construction of the Kuranda Skyrail project.
The company was initially given a number of permissions under Section 27A of the Civil Aviation Act 1988 for the operation of the KA32C helicopter involved in the construction of the Skyrail.

Following the expiration of these permissions, an Air Operators Certificate (AOC) was issued under Section 27 of the Civil Aviation Act 1988 for a fixed term from 23 May 1995 until 24 June 1995 for the use of the KA32A model helicopter on the project.

The KA32C model helicopter departed Australia when its work in Cairns was completed. The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) understands that the KA32A model aircraft has remained in Australia since completing its work.

(2) As the KA32C and KA32C helicopters are registered in Russia, the helicopters are required to have a pilot in command licensed by the Russian/Commonwealth of Independent States civil aviation authorities or a suitably qualified foreign pilot whose licence has been validated by those authorities.

In addition, the then Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) required each of the helicopters (ie KA32C and KA32A) to have at least one pilot who is the holder of an Australian Commercial Pilot Licence (Helicopter) crewing the helicopter.

(3) In accordance with international protocol, the responsibility for any investigation would rest with the authority of the country in which an accident occurred. In Australia this authority is the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation.
(4) See answer to Part 1.

(5) The operator proposed the use of a KA32A version of the helicopter during the early stages of the project but there were delays in acquiring one of these helicopters. For this reason, the KA32C helicopter was used in the interim.
The KA32A has a civil type certificate and is suitable for carrying out the work associated with this project.

(6) The KA32C helicopter has not been certificated by any civil regulatory authority and therefore could not be issued with an AOC in Australia to allow it to conduct unrestricted commercial operations.
It was possible to issue an AOC for the KA32A helicopter as it has a civil type certificate.

During the early stages of the project the KA32C was the only helicopter in Australia capable of undertaking this task and the CAA issued a series of limited approvals under Section 27A of the Civil Aviation Act 1988.

Section 27A provides a means whereby foreign registered aircraft may be operated within Australia for short periods of time, without the necessity of compliance with the conditions prescribed in Section 28A.
Permissions given under Section 27A of the Act imposed stringent conditions on the operation of the KA32C helicopter.
These conditions were:
(a) the operation must be conducted in accordance with the terms specified in the application for the permission;
(b) the helicopter must be operated and maintained in accordance with a valid Air Service Licence issued by the Department of Civil Aviation of Papua New Guinea;

(c) Hevi Lift (PNG) Pty Ltd must comply with the operational and maintenance standards and procedures which apply to the operation of helicopters within Australia for the class of operation and the category of flight for which the permission is granted, unless the Department of Civil Aviation of Papua New Guinea specifies a more stringent standard, in which case that standard must be complied with;

(d) Hevi Lift (PNG) Pty Ltd must ensure that the operations are conducted in accordance with the provisions of the Civil Aviation Act, the Civil Aviation Regulations, the Civil Aviation Orders and all other written directions issued by the Authority that are applicable to operations of the kind conducted under the permission;
(e) at least one pilot on each flight must be the holder of an Australian Commercial Pilot (Helicopter) Licence;
(f) during flying operations only operating crew may be carried on the helicopter;

(g) Hevi Lift (PNG) Pty Ltd must ensure that the helicopter does not fly over cities, towns or populous areas at any time during the conduct of the operation, including transit to and from the operational areas;
(h) operations must only be conducted under the Visual Flight Rules;
(i) operations must not be conducted at night;
(j) Hevi Lift (PNG) Pty Ltd must ensure that during all operations the pilot in command is a person who is appropriately qualified to engage in the type of operations being conducted; and,
(k) Hevi Lift (PNG) Pty Ltd must extend its legal liability policy to include the CAA as co-insured.

(7) In the issue of permissions under Section 27A of the Act for operation of the KA32C helicopter, officers of the CAA were satisfied that adequate operational and airworthiness procedures and standards were in place for the safe operation of that helicopter on limited operations.
A similar process ensured that delegates of the CAA were satisfied that adequate safeguards were in place for the operation of the KA32A helicopter.
(8) Previous permissions under Section 27A of the Act were issued by officers of the CAA with the appropriate delegations. These officers are at the Branch and Section head level of management.
(9) See answer to Part 1.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Treasurer aware that: (a) Port Kennedy is vacant crown land and is widely used for recreation by the people of the Rockingham area; and (b) the new owners of the Port Kennedy project intend to build an expensive beach resort and golf course for foreign tourists on this site which is already heavily used by local people.
(2) Did the Treasurer receive an application from Fleuris Pty Ltd for foreign interests to finance the Port Kennedy resort development in Western Australia.

(3) Did the Treasurer seek advice from the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories about this application; if so, how many conditions did the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories recommend be attached to the foreign investment approval.
(4) How many of the recommended conditions were attached to the approval.
(5) If some of the recommended conditions were not attached to the approval, did the Treasurer seek additional advice before rejecting these conditions; if so, from whom; if not, why not.
(6) If some recommended conditions were rejected by the Treasurer, what were the reasons for rejecting those recommendations from the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories.
(7) When did the Treasurer receive the advice from the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories.
(8) When did the Treasurer issue his approval for the project to Fleuris Pty Ltd.
(9) Who are the foreign interests involved in the project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) & (b) Yes. The area known as Port Kennedy in Western Australia is vacant crown land available for recreation to the general community. A regional recreational development project has been contemplated for the area by the State Government of Western Australia since 1986. The nature of that development was prescribed by the Port Kennedy Development Agreement Act 1992 of Western Australia.

(2) An application under the Government's foreign investment policy was received in 1994 for the proposed development of the project. It related to foreign parties seeking approval to acquire an equity interest in the development company which was seeking a right to acquire an interest in the land and the development from the Western Australia Government.

(3) In August 1994, the Assistant Treasurer, on advice from the Environment Protection Agency, designated the proposed developer a proponent under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 (the Act). In November 1994, the Environment Protection Agency provided an environment assessment of the proposed development. After consideration of his Department's assessment and assessments conducted by the Western Australian Government, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories determined that neither an environmental impact statement nor a public environment report was required to satisfy the object of the Act in regard to the proposal. I understand that the Minister for the Environment

ANSWER.PARA: forwarded a copy of his advice and recommendations to Senator Chamarette.

PARA.TAB: (4) to (8) In November 1994, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories provided advice and recommendations in relation to the foreign investment proposal. Conditions proposed by Senator Faulkner which duplicated commitments already agreed to by the proponent or conditions imposed by the Western Australia Government and conditions which pertained to the role of parties other than the proponent were subsequently identified in consultation and agreement with the environmental authorities and then removed from the twenty four conditions initially proposed by Senator Faulkner. The Assistant Treasurer, taking into account these further consultations, conditionally approved the proposal in December 1994. The conditions imposed included 10 of the recommendations of Senator Faulkner which were identified as additional to those conditions the proponent was already subject to by the Western Australia authorities and which pertained to the proponent and not to other parties.
(9) Foreign investment approval was given to Port Kennedy Resorts Pty Ltd which is owned by Asian and Australian investors.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What funding was provided by the Federal Government to assist in the preparation of the management plan for Finniss Springs Station's inclusion in the Lake Eyre National Park in South Australia.

(2) Was any money provided by the Federal Government to assist in the purchase of Finniss Springs Station for the purpose of including the station in the national park; if so, to whom was the money provided.

(3) Was an agreement reached between the Federal Government, the South Australian Government or any of its agencies and the Arabunna community for Aboriginal management of the station or of the national park; if so, will the Minister table a copy of the agreement; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Nature Conservation Agency, through the Contract Employment Program for Aboriginals in Natural and Cultural Resource Management (CEPANCRM), has funded a feasibility study for the development and operation of a tourism enterprise on the Finniss Springs lease. The feasibility study was not specifically funded as part of the development of a management plan for Finniss Springs Station. However the study was subsequently included in the draft management plan.

The project was developed by the South Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (SANPWS) and the Arabunna community and the grant provided was for a total of $10,000.00. An amount of $6,000 was provided to SANPWS in

ANSWER.PARA: January 1992 with the balance of $4,000 being provided in June 1993.

PARA.TAB: Another CEPANCRM project was funded in the 1994/95 financial year through the Marree Arabunna People's Committee which addresses the management and interpretation of the Mound Springs sites along the Oodnadatta Track. Some of these sites are within the Finniss Springs Station area. This project was funded in July 1994 for an amount of $50,048.00.
(2) ATSIC has not provided funds for this purpose and has not been able to identify any other Commonwealth agency which might have provided funds for this purpose.
(3) ATSIC is not aware of any such agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 6 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to Employee Assistance Programs (EAPs): (a) what amount was spent by Commonwealth departments and instrumentalities during the 1993-94 financial year; and (b) how much will be spent during the 1994-95 financial year.
(2) Are there any forward estimates for expenditure on these programs across the range of government departments and instrumentalities; if so, what are they.
(3) Which departments and instrumentalities have the highest call for EAPs.

(4) Have any studies been done on why some departments and instrumentalities have a higher demand for such programs than others; if so: (a) what have been the results of such studies; (b) will a copy of such studies be provided; (c) what percentage of counselling involves (i) employees, (ii) families of employees and (iii) stress-related issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Finance does not maintain information of specific aspects of expenditure by individual Commonwealth Agencies. Thus the aggregate details sought about EAPs are not available. For the agencies in the Finance portfolio the information is as follows:
(a) In 1993-4, the Department of Finance spent $22,510, the Australian National Audit Office spent $6,500 and the Commonwealth Superannuation Administration did not have an EAP.
(b) In 1994-95, the Department of Finance has estimated $21,062.50, the Australian National Audit Office $7,500 and the Commonwealth Superannuation Administration $35,300.

(2) Forward estimates for expenditure on EAPs are a minor part of running costs and are not separately identifiable. The future expenditure will depend on the terms achieved in negotiating or renegotiating the relevant contracts with service providers.
(3) Unable to answer.
(4)(a) & (b) No studies have been done therefore there are no reports available.
(c) With regard to the Finance portfolio the percentages are:
(i) 97.6% of the Department of Finance's, 99.6% of the Australian National Audit Office's and 80% of the Commonwealth Superannuation Administration's EAP counselling involves employees.
(ii) 2.4% of the Department of Finance's, 0.4% of the Australian National Audit Office's and 20% of the Commonwealth Superannuation Administration's EAP counselling involves families of employees.
(iii) 7.6% of the Department of Finance's, 50% of the Australian National Audit Office's and 32% of the Commonwealth Superannuation Administration's EAP counselling involves stress-related issues.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What plans has the Government for making the capabilities of the Landing Craft Heavy ships last into the next century and what are the Government's current options.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) As stated in the 1994 Defence White Paper, `the Australian Defence Force maintains its own capability to provide for certain essential transport needs. This involves transport aircraft such as the C130 fleet as well as a large number of trucks and amphibious and afloat support ships'.

The Navy's six Landing Craft Heavy ships form a part of that essential transport capability. These vessels will reach the end of their operational life between 1997 and 2000. Navy and Army have recently commenced a joint development project which is intended to offer options for continuing the Landing Craft Heavy capability into the next century.

Although definite options for replacing the Landing Craft Heavy are yet to be identified, such technologies as air cushion vehicles, wave piercing catamarans and surface effect vessels, as well as conventional landing craft designs, are under consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 29 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: Does the level of parental and student participation in the funding of optimal integration and special education for students with disabilities comply with the National Equity Program for Schools Commonwealth Government agreement with Victoria, given that: The only involvement of parents and students in the procedure for allocating the level of integration and special education funding to students with disabilities in Victorian State schools is as follows: (a) the furnishing of professional reports establishing that certain disability-category based eligibility criteria are met by the students; and (b) the completion of a questionnaire which merely requires the placement of numbers of boxes (which is supposed to establish educational needs); and given that funding levels are then decided by a computer program in $4,000 funding increments and there is no opportunity for any finer discrimination of funding levels.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth has entered into an agreement with Victoria which covers the requirement for parental involvement in funding for students with disabilities under the National Equity Program for Schools (NEPS).

Under the NEPS agreement with the State of Victoria, the Victorian Directorate of School Education is required to establish an advisory committee with a balanced complement of members drawn from "relevant interested parties including principals, teacher unions, parent organisations and community groups". The Commonwealth is satisfied that Victoria is meeting this requirement. Student participation in the consultation process is not a requirement of the NEPS agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 29 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the fact that, of the 13 000 students with disabilities found to be eligible for integration funding in Victorian State schools under the new 1994 procedures, approximately 2 500 were initially denied any funding whatsoever, and given that, of these 2 500 students, 300 subsequently received some funding as their parents were able to demonstrate a `seriously deteriorating condition' and 2 200 eligible students missed out altogether:

(1) Does this comply with the National Equity Program for Schools (NEPS) Commonwealth Agreement with Victoria in terms of both adequate support to all students with disabilities and the distribution of funds on an equitable basis.

(2) Has the Victorian Directorate of School Education included these 2 200 students in the per capita incentives funding under the NEPS incentive element, students with disabilities component, collected from the Commonwealth Government (although the students themselves received no additional State funds for their integration).
(3) Has any other Commonwealth funding relating to disabilities been granted to the Victorian State Government for these students.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commonwealth's role in the area of special education is a supplementary one only. Under the Constitution, the primary responsibility for the education of all children, including those with disabilities, lies with the State and Territory Governments. The Commonwealth's contribution is not intended to cover costs for all students with disabilities. The National Equity Program for Schools (NEPS) agreement with the Victorian Government

ANSWER.PARA: stipulates that priority be given to those students with disabilities with the greatest need.

PARA.TAB: (2) Under the Students with Disabilities component of the Incentives Element of NEPS, the Victorian Directorate of School Education claimed and has been funded for 9.763 (full time equivalents) students with disabilities.

(3) In relation to school education, students who are eligible for funding under the Students with Disabilities Component may also receive assistance under the Special Education sub-component of NEPS.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 29 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware, and is the Commonwealth Government concerned, that in the case of 10 000 Victorian State school students with disabilities who were already receiving integration and special education funding in 1994, the Victorian Government had to abandon the implementation of new computer-calculated amounts because they were widely different (for 60 per cent of students by more that $4 000 and in individual cases by $ 10 000) from the previous level of funding and that funding for 1995 for these 10 000 students remained at the 1994 level.

(2) Is the Minister aware that a second group of 2 500 students who were not receiving funding in 1994 but were found to be eligible under the 1995 criteria, were refused funding unless they could demonstrate a `seriously deteriorating condition'.

(3) Is the Minister aware that the Victorian Directorate of School Education convened a meeting of guidance officers in December 1994 at which the guidance officers were informed that they had found too many students with disabilities who were eligible.

(4) With reference to the fact that a third group of 550 students who were not receiving State Government integration funding because they were due to enter State schools for the first time in 1995, had the computer formula applied to their questionnaires and were funded accordingly: (a) does the different treatment of these three groups of students conform with the principles of equity enshrined in the National Equity Program for Schools (NEPS) agreement; (b) does the different treatment of these three groups constitute a breach of the Commonwealth Disability Discrimination Act, that is, students with comparable disabilities in similar circumstances receiving different levels of funding and some receiving no funding at all; and is it fair and reasonable that families who are already under considerable strain should have to take action with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (or State equal opportunity tribunals) on the discriminatory treatment handed out to them under Commonwealth-funded programs when the Commonwealth is able to require accountability under Commonwealth-State funding arrangements and the NEPS agreements.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The matters raised are not matters for the Commonwealth but are internal to the Victorian Directorate of School Education.

Commonwealth assistance for students with disabilities is supplementary to that provided by the States and Territories and should be directed to those students with the greatest need. The National Equity Program for Schools (NEPS) was established on the principle that States and Territories were in the best position to determine those students most in need.

Under the Commonwealth's NEPS agreement with the State of Victoria, the Victorian Directorate of School Education is responsible for the administration of all funds provided under NEPS for government schools in Victoria. The Commonwealth is satisfied that the Victorian Directorate of School Education is meeting the requirements of its NEPS agreement.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Federal Airports Corporation: Airport Movements Charge

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 3 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that under clause 7(c)(ii) of Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) Determination No. 11, effective 1 July 1995, a certificate of registration holder has only the first 8 days of a month in which to identify the operator of an aircraft which attracts an FAC airport movements charge.
(2) Is it correct that failure to do so means that the certificate of registration holder must pay the charges which they did not incur.

(3) Given that the account takes some days to reach the certificate of registration holder, how can those certificate of registration holders who cross hire and therefore have inadequate time to comply with this determination not be unfairly and illegally penalised.

(4) With reference to the fact that the Minister in the second reading speech identified these charges as being user-pays, how can the FAC charge the certificate of registration holder when they were not the user in a legal sense.
(5) On what basis can the FAC debit a charge against a certificate of registration holder who does not use a service unless it is a tax, and if it is a tax under what Act has it been levied.
(6) Is it correct that the levying of a charge against a third party is a breach of section 56(10) of the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) has provided the following information:

(1) Clause 7(c)(ii) relates to operators using an aircraft during the preceding month, and so the holder of a certificate of registration will be able to provide the FAC with the name and address of an operator using their aircraft at any stage during the preceding month as well as within the first 8 days of the following month.
Also, a certificate of registration holder will not need to give a notice each month if there has been no change in the operator of the aircraft.

(2) When an aircraft uses an FAC airport, the FAC is providing a service to the aircraft. The only publicly available information of the person responsible for the aircraft is the register of certificate of registration holders.
In the absence of any notice to the contrary, therefore, the FAC assumes that a certificate of registration holder was the operator of the aircraft at the time that the aircraft used the FAC airport.
In many cases, of course, the certificate of registration holder will indeed be the operator of the aircraft.

In those cases where the certificate of registration holder was not the operator and has failed to take advantage of the opportunity to notify the FAC of the identity of the operator, the certificate of registration holder would pay the charge.

(3) The FAC assumes that any arrangement whereby a second party has a right to operate an aircraft would be known to the certificate of registration holder or would be easily ascertained by him. Accordingly, the FAC considers that notification within the relevant period is not unfair.
(4) It is correct to say that these charges are classified as `user pays' for the reason that they are levied on the operator and not the holder of the certificate of registration except where-
(a) they are the same person or company; or
(b) the holder of the certificate of registration has not taken advantage of the opportunity to notify the FAC of the identity of the operator.
(5) The charge is not a tax.
The charge is in respect of a service that the FAC has provided to an aircraft. That service has been voluntarily acquired by the person operating the aircraft at that time.

The FAC levies the charge against the operator of the aircraft, except where the certificate of registration holder was not the operator and has failed to take advantage of the opportunity to notify the FAC of the identity of the operator. In those exceptional circumstances, the certificate of registration holder must accept responsibility for the services provided to his aircraft.
(6) No, for the reasons set out in answer to question (5).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the announcement that Australia will participate in the development of the United States (US) theatre missile defence system:

(1)(a) Is it the case that defence officials have not ruled out the possibility of either laboratory or field tests in Australia as reported on page 26 of the Financial Review of 23 June 1995; (b) can a list of the possible sites in which field tests may be carried out be provided; and (c) can a list of the possible sites in which laboratory tests may be carried out be provided.

(2) Is it a fact that the US anti-ballistic missile system violates the Anti-Ballistic Missile (ABM) Treaty whereby signatory States pledged to not defend their territories against strategic or intercontinental ballistic missile attack; if not, why not.
(3) Is it the case that the Theatre High-Altitude Area-Defence would be capable of destroying short and long-range ballistic missiles and this capability will violate the ABM treaty.

(4)(a) Why is Australia happy to be involved in and supportive of a major violation of the ABM treaty; and (b) will this action by the US, in developing a defence against ballistic missile attack which contravenes the ABM treaty, render this treaty null and void with Russia; if not, why not.
(5)(a) Will the US bases at Nurrungar and/or Pine Gap be involved in Australia's contribution to the development of the US theatre missile defence system; and (b) how will they be involved.

(6)(a) What is the purpose and nature of the legislation the Government is drafting to prevent the legal expectation that a treaty ratified would not have to be adhered to if it was not already legislated for; and (b) to what issues is this legislation constructed to respond.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) One cooperative research activity is currently in the planning stage to take advantage of some rocket launches by the US National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) at Woomera in late 1995 under a longstanding agreement with the Australian Space Office. NASA has agreed to notify the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) and the US Ballistic Missile Defense Organisation (BMDO) of the times of the launches, which are separate and independent activities. DSTO, in collaboration with the BMDO, will observe the rocket ascent for missile defence related research. For further background I refer the honourable senator to the answer tabled in response to Senate Question on Notice No. 2221 of 13 June 1995.
(b) Woomera Instrumented Range, South Australia.
(c) DSTO's Electronics and Surveillance Research Laboratory, Salisbury, South Australia.

(2) No. President Clinton has reaffirmed the US policy of adherence to the ABM Treaty. The ABM Treaty (as amended) allows the parties to develop and test systems dedicated to defence against strategic missiles but limits deployment to 100 interceptors at a single location. The US has not exercised this option and has no operational system capable of defending its territory against strategic ballistic missile attack.

As part of its ballistic missile defence effort, the US is pursuing what it terms a technological readiness program in respect of defences against strategic ballistic missiles. As noted, this activity is fully consistent with the ABM Treaty.

The main thrust of the Ballistic Missile Defense (BMD) program in the US in recent years has been the development of systems to protect forward-deployed and expeditionary elements of the US armed forces (as well as any allied or friendly forces) against shorter range theatre and tactical ballistic missiles, including Scud missiles of the type used by Iraq during the Gulf War. The deployment of BMD systems of this kind is not prohibited by the ABM Treaty. There are ongoing negotiations between the US and Russia to explore the scope for more precise criteria to distinguish strategic and theatre ballistic missile defences.

(3) No. The Theatre High-Altitude Area-Defence is the first system designed by the US specifically for theatre missile defence. The system is currently under development in the US and is not scheduled for fully operational deployment until around 2002. Whether the system when developed and deployed will have any capability against long-range intercontinental ballistic missiles, and whether that capability is such as to give rise to an ABM Treaty compliance issue, will be matters for the parties to the Treaty.

(4)(a) Australia is not involved in or supportive of any activity that is a violation of the ABM Treaty. In accordance with US Government policy, the Director of the Ballistic Missile Defense Organisation, Lieutenant General O'Neill, has advised the US Congress in written testimony (Statement to the Committee on Appropriations on 22 March 1995) that the Department of Defense carefully examines each of its experiments, as well as systems in development, to ensure that all its efforts are ABM Treaty compliant. All cooperative projects involving DSTO will be fully consistent with the Australian Government's position on the importance of the ABM Treaty for the stability of the strategic nuclear balance.

DSTO cooperation with the BMDO is expected to benefit Australia for reasons outlined in the answer to part 3 of Question 2221. It will also build on Australia's long record of constructive engagement in activities designed to counter the destabilising effects of ballistic missile proliferation.

(b) As recently as May 1995 in Moscow, the US and Russia reaffirmed their commitment to the ABM Treaty as a cornerstone of strategic stability. On the same occasion, the two parties agreed that each should have the option to establish and deploy effective theatre missile defence systems. As a basis for further discussions on the demarcation between strategic and theatre missile defence systems, they also agreed that any theatre missile defence systems that may be deployed, firstly, will not pose a realistic threat to the strategic nuclear force of the other side; and, secondly, will not be tested to give such systems that capability. In the event of a dispute over the interpretation of the ABM Treaty it would be up to the parties to the Treaty to determine how that dispute should be resolved, having regard to the provisions of the Treaty for dealing with such eventualities.

(5)(a) and (b)There are no plans to involve the Joint Defence Facilities in the cooperative research activities between DSTO and BMDO. The Joint Defence Facility Nurrungar will continue to contribute missile early warning information of ballistic missile launches to the US missile early warning system. Nurrungar's contribution will continue to include warning of theatre ballistic missile launches as it did during the Gulf War for launches of Iraqi Scud missiles.
(6)(a) & (b) I am unable to answer this question as it falls within the portfolio responsibilities of the Attorney-General.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Railway Extensions: Southern Cross and Kalgoorlie

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 6 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Has the Federal Government funded the construction of railway passing loops between Southern Cross and Kalgoorlie in Western Australia with a $500,000 grant through the One Nation statement; (b) why did the Federal Government provide $500,000 for the railway extensions; and (c) what was the total cost of each of the railway extensions between Southern Cross and Kalgoorlie.

(2)(a) Can a detailed breakdown of the federal funding that has been spent on the construction of railways between Southern Cross and Kalgoorlie in the 1993-94, 1994-95 and 1995-96 financial years be provided; (b) what is the reason for federal involvement in the funding of this railway construction; and (c) why is the extra railway construction needed.
(3) Who did the request for extra railway construction come from within the State Government, industry and the community.

(4)(a) Will the extra railway construction benefit or be useful to the transporters of materials to the Intractable Waste Disposal Facility (IWDF) at Mt Walton; (b) who will specifically benefit from the extra railway construction; and (c) will any particular industry or industries benefit from this railway construction; if so, which companies and industries.

(5) Did Rhone Poulenc's decision to resume its proposal for a rare earths processing plant in Pinjarra (with the waste to be stored at the IWDF at Mt Walton) have any bearing at all on the decision by the State or Federal Governments to construct extra railway in the area from Southern Cross to Kalgoorlie; if so, how did this proposal specifically influence the site and length of the railway constructed.

(6) Has Rhone Poulenc or any other company or industry using the IWDF at Mt Walton been consulted or will they be consulted or have any input into the construction of extra railway between Southern Cross and Kalgoorlie.
(7) Has any company or industry been consulted or will any other company be consulted or have any input into the construction of extra railway between Southern Cross and Kalgoorlie.

(8) Are there any avenues by which Rhone Poulenc or any other company can influence the building of rail that may have an impact upon or benefit their industry in some way; if so, what are these avenues.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) The Federal Government provided $10.25m under the One Nation program to upgrade the Perth-Kalgoorlie railway. Of this, $1.5m was to lengthen three crossing loops between Southern Cross and Kalgoorlie, at Bonnie Vale, Stewart and Jaurdi.
(b) The funding was provided to enable more efficient interstate freight operations.
(c) The exact cost of each crossing loop is not readily available, but the work in each case cost in the order of $0.5m.
(2)(a) The work between Southern Cross and Kalgoorlie was limited to the crossing loop extensions and all $1.5m was provided in 1994-95.
(b) and (c) See the answer to 1(b).

(3) The projects funded under the One Nation program were chosen following consultation between Commonwealth and State Governments. In line with practice in other States under the One Nation program projects were approved by the Commonwealth based on detailed proposals put forward by the relevant State rail authorities, in this case Westrail.
(4) (a) The transport of materials to the IWDF is a matter for the WA Government.

(b) and (c) Longer crossing loops allow the operation of longer trains which are more efficient than shorter trains. The benefits from the longer loops will be available generally to users of rail freight services on this line.
(5) It had no bearing on the Commonwealth Government's decision.

(6) to (8) The Commonwealth was not involved in any such consultations. The One Nation project between Southern Cross and Kalgoorlie is now complete, but should any company or industry wish to have an extra railway constructed in this area, they should contact the WA Government, which owns the line and is responsible for intrastate rail transport.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, upon notice, on 6 July 1995 a series of questions regarding the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation and its involvement with the Lihir gold mining project in Papua New Guinea:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Is the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) to underwrite the Lihir gold mining project in Papua New Guinea; if so, what will the terms of this country-risk guarantee be; (b) for how much will it be underwritten; and (c) under what conditions would Australia be liable to pay up to $250 million, or the amount to be underwritten, to secure a further $400 million debt component for the project.

(2)(a) Has EFIC gone through the same risk assessment and loan viability process that would apply to other EFIC loans; and (b) what percentage will the amount used to underwrite the loan for the Lihir project be of EFIC's: (i) budgets for underwriting loans, and (ii) total loans budget.

(3)(a) Is the Australian Government satisfied that sufficient measures are in place for the mitigation of environmental impact given plans for: (i) direct dumping of 330 million tonnes of waste into the ocean, (ii) pumping discharges from the mine dewatering and geothermal wells directly into Luise Harbour, and (iii) pumping of contaminants and chemicals directly into the ocean; if not, why not; (b) what measures are in place to ensure the mine minimises damage through dumping of waste and contaminants; (c) what control does the Australian Government have over these environmental standards; and (d) who set them and who has carriage of environmental scrutiny of the project.

(4) Does the Lihir mine and Australia's involvement in, contravene either: (a) the International Convention on the `Prevention of Marine Pollution By Dumping of Wastes and Other Matters', London Convention 1972 which Australia signed in 1985; or (b) the 1986 SPREP Protocols for the `Prevention of Pollution of the South Pacific Region by Dumping'; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister with policy responsibility for the operations of the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC), I answer the honourable senator's questions regarding EFIC involvement with the Lihir gold mining project in Papua New Guinea as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) EFIC is one of three insurers providing Political Risk Insurance to the banks and financial institutions providing the debt finance to develop the Lihir project. EFIC will insure the lenders against default by the borrowers arising from specific causes of loss which relate to expropriation, blockage of the transfer of funds from Papua New Guinea, or war (or warlike) damage.
(b) EFIC's insurance will cover up to US$250m of the principal of the loan, plus cover on associated interest payments due to the lenders.

(c) EFIC would be obliged to pay a claim to the lenders if the borrower were to default in making a scheduled payment under the loan agreement, provided such a default was caused by events covered by EFIC's policy. The claim paid to the lenders would be for an amount equivalent to 90% of the scheduled payment of principal and related interest on which the borrower had defaulted.
(2)(a) Yes
(b) EFIC is providing Political Risk Insurance. It is not providing a loan to the Lihir project.

(3)(a) Having taken into account environmental assessments undertaken by the project sponsors, the Papua New Guinea Government, independent consultants, the World Bank, and the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency, the Government is satisfied that sufficient mitigants are in place to effectively manage the environmental impacts of the project.

(b) A number of contractual agreements have been executed between the Papua New Guinea Government and the project companies. These contractual arrangements contain certain obligations on the project to comply with all Papua New Guinea laws (including those pertaining to the environment) and to adhere to a specifically approved program of management and monitoring of the environmental impacts.
(c) and (d) The environmental requirements for the Lihir project are the responsibility of the Government of Papua New Guinea. Monitoring

ANSWER.PARA: compliance with those standards is the responsibility of the relevant agencies of the Government of Papua New Guinea.

PARA.TAB: When reviewing EFIC's proposed provision of insurance, the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency recommended, and the companies accepted, that the Lihir companies would have independent environmental performance reviews undertaken on a regular basis with the findings on environmental performance reported in the company's Annual Report.
(4) No. The Lihir project does not propose actions which would be prohibited under international protocols on ocean dumping.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 17 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, which specifically excludes from service pension eligibility a veteran who has served in enemy forces of Australia and its allies or in forces that were assisting the enemies of Australia and its allies, and with regard to the eligibility criteria for veterans claiming the service pension: (a) what are the requirements of the eligibility criteria; and (b) how does the department verify this information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) A person is eligible for service pension if the person:
is a veteran; and
has rendered qualifying service; and
meets the age requirements for age service pension, or is permanently incapacitated for work or is blinded in both eyes.

In addition, if a person is an allied veteran, generally the person must have been an Australian resident for a continuous period of at least 10 years. Refugees do not have to meet the residency requirement.
An allied veteran is defined as a person:
who has been appointed or enlisted as a member of the defence force established by an allied country; and
who has rendered continuous full-time service as such a member during a period of hostilities;

ANSWER.PARA: but does not include a person who has served at any time:

PARA.TAB: in the forces of a country that was, at that time, at war with Australia, or in forces engaged in supporting or assisting the forces of such a country; or
in forces that were, at that time, engaged in war-like operations against the Naval, Military or Air Forces of Australia.

An allied veteran has rendered qualifying service if the veteran, during a period of hostilities, has, as a member of the defence force established by an allied country, rendered, in connection with a war, or war-like operations, in which the Naval, Military or Air Forces of Australia were engaged, service in an area within or outside the country in which the veteran enlisted in those forces, being service in respect of which the veteran incurred danger from hostile forces of the enemy.

(b) Applicants for service pension are required to provide supporting documentation with their claims such as details of their service in the armed forces. Applicants are also required to declare whether they have served with or assisted forces of the enemy or a country at war with Australia. Where the residency requirement needs to be satisfied an applicant is required to provide proof of this.
If there is any doubt in regard to a claim, corroborative evidence either by declarations or records of service colleagues are sought to compare the veteran's history with known facts.

Where an allied veteran states that he or she has no service documentation available or that service documents have been misplaced, a statutory declaration is taken from the veteran. This declaration includes:
full particulars and history of service;
names and addresses of any witnesses who can corroborate the service record; and
which documents were held and how these were lost.
All applicants are required to sign a declaration that the information provided is correct.

Claims which have all the necessary documentation are determined by a delegate of the Repatriation Commission. Each claim is determined on its merits and applicants are advised of their rights of appeal against any aspect of the decision with which they are not satisfied.

The Department of Finance is playing a significant role in the project and is chairing the working party with active participation from a large number of agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 19 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Do Ministers in the department have Internet accounts; if so, what is the mail address of each such account,
(2)(a) What was the installation cost of providing ministerial access to the Internet;
(b) who paid these costs; and
(c) what is the estimated annual cost of operating this Internet account.

(3)(a) Are Ministers in the department physically able to operate Internet accounts from either their Parliament House or any other offices; if so, who was responsible for installing the necessary links; and
(b) what were the costs entailed and who paid these costs.
(4) What plans are there to provide ministerial access to the Internet and when is it estimated that such access will be available.
(5) Does the department use, or has it used, the Internet for on-line publishing; if so, can the addresses for any such Internet sites be provided.
(6) Can a list of all items published since 1 May 1995 be provided.
(7)(a) Is there a code of practice governing the content of departmental material that can be published on the Internet; and
(b) can a copy of any such code of practice be provided.

(2)(a) Additional software totalling $970
(b) The Department
(c) Nil.

(b) No additional costs were incurred.
